entry.title: Boundary marker, set up by C. Julius Zoilos
entry.summary: Upper right corner of a white marble block (0.36 x 0.24 x 0.34). Inscribed on one face. Date: Late Republican or Augustan (lettering, content). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1963 (63.596). Published by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 35, whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.388,An.Ép. 1984.878, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 379, R. R. R. Smith, Aphrodisias I. The monument of C. Julius Zoilos (Mainz, 1993) T5.

entry.title: Building dedication for Aphrodite by C. Julius Zoilos
entry.summary: Three adjoining white marble lintel blocks (0.54, 0.64) a, left corner block, broken to right (1.14); b brokenin two fragments and at both ends (1.04); right corner block, c cut down (2.00), with elaborate moulding. Inscribed on two fasciae; partly erased. Date: Late first century B.C. (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition (Temple 6). Published by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 37, whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.388, AnnEpig 1984.878 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 81, Smith, Monument, T.3; discussed by discussed by Reynolds, 'Inscriptions and the Building of the Temple', Aphrodisias Papers (Ann Arbor, 1990), 37-40, 37-8 , whenceSEG 1990.945.

entry.title: Prayer of the builders
entry.summary: White marble column plinth. Inscribed on upper moulding of face, i: to left; ii: to right. Below ii an indecipherable monogram. Date: First to tenth centuries A.D. (context). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 128, and plate xxxii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 594, 595.

entry.title: Column dedication by Eumachos and Amias
entry.summary: White marble tabella ansata (0.71 × 0.42) cut on fluted column. Cut on the second drum from the base of the column. Date: Early first century A.D. (lettering, context, prosopography). Photos. Noted in 1705 by Picenini (10102, 20) and Sherard (10101, 12); copied by Deering (8, no.33); copied by Bailie; copied by Le Bas; recorded by K&R (no notebook entry); recorded by Gaudin (181); recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Bailie, 68; by Waddington, from Le Bas, LBW 590; by Reinach, from Gaudin, 123; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, 437, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 108.

entry.title: Column dedication by Eumachos and Ammias
entry.summary: White marble tabella ansata (0.71 × 0.44) cut on fluted column. Cut on the second drum from the base of the column. Date: Early first century A.D. (lettering, context, prosopography). Photos. Copied by Sherard in 1705 (10101, 12r) and by Picenini (10102, 20); copied by Deering (2v, no.10); copied by Fellows; copied by Le Bas, and perhaps the same inscription copied by Waddington; Recorded by Gaudin (88); recorded by the MAMA expedition; recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Boeckh, from Sherard, CIG 2748 ; published by Fellows, 13, whence CIG add. p. 1109, and from all these Texier 1. Published by Waddington from Le Bas, LBW 591, and from his own copy, LBW 1587 . Published by Reinach from Gaudin, 124 ; published by Cormackfrom the MAMA records, 438 , whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 109.

entry.title: Column dedication by Eumachos and Amias
entry.summary: Tabella ansata (0.455 × 0.44) on fluted column section, which is broken above. Inscribed in tabella ansata. Date: Early first century A.D. (context, prosopography); this is in a very inelegant hand, on the face of it much later than the parallel column texts (1.4, 1.5); ?perhaps a re-inscription. Photos. Recorded by Kubitschek (V, 22; Abklatsch 112); by Gaudin (51); found by the NYU expedition. Published from Gaudin by Reinach, 122, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 87.

entry.title: Column dedication by Attalos and Attalis
entry.summary: Tabella ansata (0.745 × 0.465) on a fluted white marble column of the Temple. Inscribed in tabella ansata. Date: Early first century A.D. (lettering, context, prosopography). Photos. Copied by Deering (1); copied by Le Bas; recorded by Gaudin (76); recorded by the MAMA expedition; recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Leake, from Deering, 1, whence Bailie 69; published by Waddington, LBW 589; published by Reinach, from Gaudin, 125; published by Cormackfrom the MAMA records, MAMA 8, 450 , whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 101.

entry.title: Column dedication by Attalos and Attalis
entry.summary: Three fragments from a tabella ansata (0.745 x 0.465) on a fluted white marble column; a (left side fragment) 0.30 × 0.30 × 0.14. b (centre fragment) 0.28 × 0.80 × 0.40. c (right lower corner) 0.27 × 0.36 × 0.29. Inscribed in tabella ansata. Date: Mid first century A.D. (lettering). Photos. The text was copied by Deering (5v, no. 21) who saw it complete, except for the end of l.4, and l.8; It was broken by 1893, when fragment b was copied by Kubitschek (V.22a). a-c excavated by the NYU expedition. b published from K&R by Cormack, ABSA 59, 1964, 27, no. 37, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 156; a and c unpublished.

entry.title: Column dedication in Temple
entry.summary: Fragment of a white marble column base (0.75 × 0.35 × 0.47). Inscribed on one face (0.48 × 0.15). Date: Republican period, perhaps second century B.C. Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition (Temple 102). Mentioned by Reynolds, Aphrodisias Papers 1, 39.

entry.title: Names with gameboards
entry.summary: White marble steps. Cut on upper face, each next to a gameboard: i. A board, H.4, deeply cut, (0.13 × 0.28). ii. To the west of i, a mill game, SSS.1 (0.26 × 0.27); iii. To the west of this, two concentric squares, apparently cut for an uncompleted board, type SSS.1 or 2 (0.181 ×0.186). Date: Fourth to fifth centuries A.D. or later (nomenclature). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. i and ii published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 217 and plate xliv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 596; i, ii and iii published by Roueché, Gameboards 10.

entry.title: Place inscription of Loukas, philoponus
entry.summary: White marble column (diam. 0.61). The inscription is cut just below the fluting on the east face. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries A.D. or later (content, location). Photos. Copied by Fellows; recorded by Gaudin (113); by the NYU expedition. Published by Fellows, Acct. 360, no. 70, whence Kirchhoff, CIG 9273, Ramsay, Cities & Bishoprics 554, no. 427; by Reinach, no. 217, from Gaudin, whence Grégoire, IGC 268, Cabrol, DACL 14, col. 795, no. 21; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 187 and plate xli, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 681.

entry.title: Prayer of Theodoretos and Kyriakos
entry.summary: Four blue-grey marble fragments (0.15 × 0.975 (total) × 0.20) which join, from the crowning feature of a balustrade; the top is smooth; one side has a moulded profile, the other is smooth, tapering inwards. The underside has been left rough. Resembles 1.13, 1.14, 1.15, 1.16. Inscribed in one line on upper fascia of moulded profile. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries A.D. (location, script). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1962 and 1968 (62.100, 62.111, 68.292). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 92 and plate xxiii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 648.

entry.title: Prayer of donors, including Theodoretos and Kyriakos
entry.summary: Seven blue-grey marble fragments, H. 0.16, D. 0.20 from the crowning feature of a balustrade: the top is smooth; one side has a moulded profile, the other is smooth, tapering inwards. The underside has been left rough. Resembles 1.12, 1.14, 1.15, 1.16. a: three joining pieces, total W. 0.29; b: three joining pieces, total W. 0.30; c: w. 0.11. Inscribed in one line on upper fascia of moulded profile. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries (location, lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1962 (62.105, 62.201, and unnumbered). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 93 and plate xxiv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 649.

entry.title: Prayer of Anastasios, donor
entry.summary: Six blue-grey marble fragments, H. 0.135, D. 0.21, from the crowning feature of a balustrade; the top is smooth; one side has a moulded profile, the other is smooth, tapering inwards. The underside has been left rough. a: W. 0.375; b: W. 0.61; c: two joining pieces, W. 0.35; d: W. 0.28; e: similar profile. but perhaps different lettering, W. 0.25. Resembles 1.12, 1.13, 1.15, 1.16. Inscribed in one line on upper fascia of moulded profile. Date: Fifth/sixth century (location, lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1962, 1963 and 1965 (62.202, 62.203, 63.602, 65.55 and unnumbered). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 94 and plate xxiv whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 650.

entry.title: Prayer of Anastasios, donor
entry.summary: A blue-grey marble fragment broken at back and below (0.08 × 0.30 × 0.11), from the crowning feature of a balustrade; the top is smooth and one side has a moulded profile; broken at back and below. Resembles 1.12, 1.13, 1.14, 1.16. Inscribed in one line on upper fascia of moulded profile. Date: Fifth/sixth century (location, lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1966 (66.95). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 95 and plate xxiv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 651.

entry.title: Prayer of donor

The underside has been left rough. Resembles 1.12, 1.13, 1.14, 1.15. Inscribed in one line on upper fascia of moulded profile. Date: Fifth/sixth century (location, lettering). Photo. entry.title: Fragment of donor's prayer
entry.summary: Fragment from the lower edge of a blue-grey marble panel (0.083 × 0.13 × 0.027). Inscribed in one line along lower edge, below a moulded groove. Date: Fifth-sixth century A.D. (lettering, content). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1962 (62.74). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 97 and plate xxv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 653.

entry.title: Anatolios, donor
entry.summary: Fragment, with back and upper edge surviving (0.155 × 0.34 × 0.105), from a white marble cornice block; there is a boss, broken away, at the left. Cut in one line on a smoothed band which runs along the face above the boss. Date: Fifth/sixth century or later. Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (71); by the NYU expedition in 1962 (62.361). Published from Gaudin by Reinach, no. 208, whence IGC 256; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 98 and plate xxv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 610.

entry.title: Prayer of Asterios
entry.summary: Masonry block in the wall of the Temple-Church. Texts i and ii are disposed on either side of a design described previously as a table, but in fact a measure. There are three of these marked out on the wall: 1. To the left of 113.ii, worn at the left; at least 0.60. 2. To the right of 113.i; well cut, 0.29, surmounted by a cross. 3. 5th block to east with a central divide - 0.62, divided into two spans of roughly 0.305. Text i, to the left, impinges slightly on this; text ii is to the right. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries or later (lettering, content). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 113 i and ii, and plate xxx, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 635, 654.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Prayer of Theodoros
entry.summary: A column base; the surface is slightly chipped, and broken away at the right. On the upper, flat fascia of the moulding. Date: Fifth-sixth century or later (location, lettering, terminology). Photos. Recorded by Kubitschek (K.V.16; Abklatsch xvii); by Gaudin (31); by the NYU expedition. Published from Gaudin by Reinach no. 210, whence Grégoire, IGC 258; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 114 and plate xxx, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 593.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Prayers on West Door of Temple-Church (south)
entry.summary: A white marble door post. The texts are grouped - i above, ii and iii to the right, iv to the left - around a cross carefully sculpted (0.31) in the centre of the door-post, with the surface of the stone cut away around it; iii was certainly inscribed before the cross was cut. Date: Fifth-sixth century or later (lettering, location). Photos. i was copied by Texier and byFellows; i and ii recorded by Gaudin (28); i-iv recorded by the NYU expedition. i published by Texier, As. Min. iii 167, pl. 156; by Fellows, no. 72, from both of which CIG 8905, Ramsay, Cities & Bishoprics 555, no. 428; i and ii from Gaudin by Reinach, no. 206, whence Grégoire, IGC 261a,261b, DACL 14, col. 796, no. 22; i-iv published by RouechéAphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 117 i-iv and plate xxxi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 638, 644, 882, 883.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Prayers on West Door of Temple-Church (north)
entry.summary: A white marble door post. A cross has been carefully sculpted (H. 0.31), and the surface cut away around it; it is very similar to that on the facing door-post (1.21), but not so well centred. Text ii is arranged around the oval recessed area surrounding it; text i is some way above, text iii some way below. There are several other, less substantial, crosses inscribed on this door-post. Date: Fifth-sixth century or later (lettering, location). Photos. ii copied by Texier, p1. 156; i and ii copied by Fellows; all recorded by Gaudin (i and ii, 26; iii, 27), and by the NYU expedition. i and ii published by Fellows, i on p. 31, ii on p. 361, no. 71; ii by Texier, As. Min. iii p. 156; by Reinach, from Gaudin, i and ii as no. 204, iii as no. 205, whence Grégoire, IGC 260, 257bis; all by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 118 i, ii, iii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 642, 641, 643.

entry.summary: A blue marble column (1.48; diam. 0.43). Inscribed some way to the left of i there is a cross, and some way below is ii. Below ii is another cross. Date: Fifth-sixth centuries A.D. or later (content, location). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition. entry.title: Graffiti: names and prayers
entry.summary: Fragment from a white marble balustrade, broken in two, with a cross in relief on one side (0.36 × 0.31 × 0.155); the upper edge has a boss protruding from it, and a polished surface, on which are several finely cut graffiti. i at upper edge; ii below i; iii along lower edge. There are further traces of letters. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries or later (content, location). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition; read and measured by J.M. Reynolds in 1966, since when some of the surface has been broken away, and the block broken in two. Published Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 132, and plate xxxii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 802, 803, 790, 768.

entry.title: Graffiti: names and prayers
entry.summary: Three fragments from a white marble panel or a coping stone polished at back and front, with upper and lower edges surviving in i and ii. Covered with small graffiti. Inscribed on the upper surface. Date: Fifth-sixth century or later (content, location). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1966 (66.126). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 133 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 791, 792, 793.

entry.title: Fragments from a poem decorating a feature in the Temple-Church
entry.summary: Twenty-two white marble fragments, some joining, from the outer rim of a large circular feature (outer diam. 3 m, inner 2.55). The blocks were designed to be seen from below, and have elaborately ornamented trapezoidal panels on the underside (each 0.98 long); the panels each have a different pattern, which enables the grouping together of several fragments which do not join. The blocks are slightly convex, and the outer edge slopes outwards from bottom to top (H. 0.16); on it are a series of bosses with an ornamental cross (0.40 apart). The text runs in one line between the bosses, with a continuous line incised above and below it. Date: Tenth century A.D. (architecture, terminology). Photos. Part of a, and k recorded by Gaudin (30); a-j excavated by the NYU expedition in 1962, 1963, 1964, or recorded as stray finds (62.104, 62.110, 62.174, 62.175, 62.176, 62.177, 62.178, 62.196, 62.197, 62.198, 62.199, 63.637, 64.129, and unnumbered). a. (part) and k. published from Gaudin by Reinach, no. 211, whence IGC 259; all published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 99 and plates xxv, xxvi (a. and c.), whence Steinepigramme 02/09/98; not in PHI.

entry.title: Boundary marker, set up by C. Julius Zoilos
entry.summary: A block, broken above and very damaged (H 0.60 × 0.62 × 0.32). Inscribed on the face; there appears to be a large rosette below the text. Date: Late Republican or Augustan (prosopography). Recorded by Kubitscheck and Reichel (K iii.35; Abklatsch 53); not reported subsequently. Published from Kubitscheck's copy by Cormack, ABSA 59 (1964), 16, whence extensively reedited by Robert, AC 35 (1966), 401-412; from this BullEp 1967.552; BullEp 1983.388, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 380 . Cited Reynolds, A&R 160.

entry.title: Building dedication to the Divine Augustus by Eusebes son of Menandros
entry.summary: Three fragments (one lost) from a white marble architrave block cornice or lintel; a broken at both sides (0.49 × 0.36 × 0.25); b: no measurements; c: (0.75 × 0.38 × 0.75) right edge, which is the end of the cornice, survives. Inscribed on two fasciae. Date: Julio-Claudian (content, lettering). Photos. b and c were copied in 1705 by Picenini (BM Add 10102, 20 and, from Tisser, 56v), whence Sherard (BM Add 10101 f.31) and ; a and c recorded by Gaudin (72, 73); c recorded by the MAMA expedition; a and c found by the NYU expedition. a and c published (from Gaudin) by Reinach, 192 and 191. B and c published by Boeckh, from Sherard, CIG 2738 and 2773. C published, from the MAMA records by Cormack, MAMA 433; discussed by Reynolds, PCPS 206, 1980, 78, no. 8, whence SEG 1980.1244, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 94;. discussed by Reynolds, 'Inscriptions and the Building of the Temple', Aphrodisias Papers (Ann Arbor, 1990), 37-40, 38.

entry.title: Fragmentary honours
entry.summary: Upper part of a round-headed marble stele (0.33 × 0.48 × 0.15), chipped on either side as well as cut away below; within the head is an incised olive wreath with pendant taenia that impinge on the body of the stele, above the text. There is a hole in the underside for attachment to a shaft below, which must also have been inscribed. Inscribed on the face. Date: Perhaps third to second centuries B.C. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (65.293). Unpublished.

entry.title: i. Fragmentary text; ii. Verse honours for Helladios
entry.summary: Four adjoining fragments (together 0.47 × 0.45 × 0.24) of a white marble statue base shaft, with panels within moulded edges on at least three sides; The lower part of the shaft and the upper right corner are lost. i: on the panel to the right. ii: Inscribed on the front panel, which has a rough but deep groove down the left side of the text. The last letter of l.3 is cut on the moulding. Date: i: (second century (lettering); ii: First half of the fourth century (lettering). Photos. Main fragment copied by Kubitschek (K V.17; Abklatsch 12); recorded by the MAMA expedition; recorded, with three further fragments (70.2, 70.6, 70.584), by the NYU expedition. i: Unpublished. ii. Published, from Kubitschek and the MAMA records, by Cormack, MAMA 8, 531, whence L. Robert, Hellenica 13, 157-158, BE 1966.404, Drew-Bear, REA 82 (1980), 161-164, no. 3 and 182, whence SEG 1981.912, An.Ép. 1981.763; cited by Roueché (1979), 175, note 9, whence SEG 1979.1069; published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 16 and plate v, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 721, Steinepigramme 02/09/14.

Inscribed on the face, below the moulding. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Temple 106a). Unpublished.

entry.summary: Fragment from a white marble sarcophagus front (0.45 × 0.22 × 0.02) with traces of the garland and central panel. Inscribed on the upper moulding of the panel. entry.summary: Lower left coner of a white marble statue base with heavy moulding (0.44 × 0.38 × 0.26). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (48); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin, REG 19, 1906, 210, no. 89; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 493, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 266.

entry.title: Honours for anonymous
entry.summary: Seven fragments from the lower part of a white marble statue base shaft (width 0.52, depth 0.42) with moulded panels on at least two sides. f: (lines 5-8) Left side moulding (0.18 × 0.12 × 0.10). Inscribed on the face, with the text occasionally impinging on the moulding. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (nomenclature, lettering). Photos. e copied by Hirschfeld in 1874; b and c copied by Kubitschek (K.18, Abklatsch 10), when they still formed a single stone; b recorded by Boulanger (notebook B, 41, no.45), and by the MAMA expedition; all were found by the NYU expedition: a Temple 23; b 83.71, SBI 113; c 72.489; d Temple 9, SBI 94; e 83.83; f Temple 26; g: Temple 44. b and c published by Cormack from the MAMA records, and from K&R, MAMA 8, no. 511, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 337; e published by Cormack, from Hirschfeld, ABSA 59, 1964, 29, no. 45, on which Robert, AC 35, 1966, 424, note 3 (l. 5), whence BE 1967.552, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 378.

entry.title: Honours for daughter of Hephaistion
entry.summary: Two adjoining fragments of the lower part of a white marble statue base shaft with moulded panes on at least three sides (0.47 × 0.89 × 0.29). Fragment a. lines 1-10; b. line 11. Inscribed on the face (surviving face 0.37 × 0.50). Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Both fragments recorded by Gaudin (48); a recorded by the MAMA expedition; both by the NYU expedition (SBI 103). Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 208-210, no. 88; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 516, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 250.

entry.title: Posthumous honours for Dionysios, and a foundation
entry.summary: Two fragments from the lower part of a white marble base with moulded panels on four sides. a: right side fragment (0.28 × 0.58 × 0.25) with moulding to right. b: lower left corner fragment, with moulding to left and below (0.25 × 0.34 × 0.34). Inscribed on the face. a. inscribed face 0.19 × 0.45; b. inscribed face 0.17 × 0.39. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. a copied by Kubitschek (KV.19, Abklatsch 22); by Ramsay; recorded (considerably damaged) by the MAMA expedition; recorded, still further damaged, by the NYU expedition. Published by Ramsay, Cities & Bishoprics p. 189, no. 72, whence discussed by L. Robert Villes d'Asie Mineure, second edition, p.64, Rev. de Phil. 1929, 134, n.1, and republished by Squarciapino, La scuola di Afrodisia 12, no. 4, whence BE 1948.211a; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 520bis, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 273; published by Erim and Reynolds, Sculptors of Aphrodisias no. 18, whence SEG 1990.941.

entry.title: Ηonours for anonymous, who has established a foundation
entry.summary: Upper part of a white marble statue base shaft with moulded panels on at least two sides (0.55 × 0.54 × 0.36), damaged above and broken away below. Inscribed on the face (0.35 x 0.42), which is very weathered. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by Kubitschek (KIII.21, Abklatsch 68); squeezed by Gaudin (48); recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (SBI 104). Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 208, no. 86, whence Laum, no. 115, and discussed by L. Robert, Études Anatoliennes 317; by Cormack, from the MAMA records and from Kubitschek, MAMA 8, no. 523, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 362.

entry.title: Honours for Lucius Antonius Karpion Aurelianos, who has established a foundation
entry.summary: Rectangular white marble statue base shaft, with moulded panels on all four sides in two large joining fragments (together 0.49 × 1.125 × 0.49) and one small fragment of ll. 14-16 (0.165 × 0.21 × 0.10);. Inscribed on two adjacent faces. Face a, to the left, has broken moulding, and is broken down the left side. Face b is pitted to receive plaster. The moulding on face a survives at the upper edge; the text must therefore have begun on an upper feature. Traces of the plaster which covered the inscriptions when the stone was re-used are still adhering. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, prosopography). Photos. Deering saw and copied side b (5v, no. 22); complete text, on both sides, recorded by the NYU expedition (Temple 3; SBI 90). Published by Leake, from Deering, 8, whence LBW 1628a whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 948.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.

Inscribed on surviving face (a. 0.08 × 0.020). Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1962 (Temple 103). Unpublished.

entry.title: Building dedication for Hadrian
entry.summary: White marble architrave blocks with decoration, above, of scrolls in relief between bands of egg and dart moulding; below, two fasciae. The inscription has been erased on all blocks except b, and several others which were inscribed, are not now legible; some of the blocks were also recut for re-use. b (Doruk A 12): 2.50 × 0.64 visible x depth not measurable; e, left end survives, broken at right, 0.84 × 0.61 × 0.50; e: Doruk A 11) g: Doruk A 12. Inscribed on the upper of two fasciae. Date: A.D. 117/138 (reign). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition (Temple 6a and Temple 12). Parts published byReynolds, 'Inscriptions and the Building of the Temple', Aphrodisias Papers (Ann Arbor, 1990), 37-40, 39-40; by Doruk, Aphrodisias Papers (Ann Arbor, 1990), 73-74 , whence SEG 1990.946, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 114*5.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary text
entry.summary: A white marble fragment, perhaps from a sarcophagus front, very damaged and worn. Inscribed on one face. Date: Late second to third centuries A.D. (prosopography). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (166); further damaged fragment found by the NYU expedition. Published from Gaudin's squeeze by Reinach, REG 19, 1906, 289, no 189, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 514.

entry.title: Honours for anonymous
entry.summary: Upper part of a white marble statue base shaft (0.53 × 0.33 × 0.40) with moulding surviving above. Inscribed below the moulding, on a face 0.33 × 0.40; the text must have begun on a crowning feature. Date: Late second or early third century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (48); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (SBI 98). Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 207, no. 85, on which L. Robert, Hellenica VIII, 210; published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 527, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 364.

entry.title: Honours for Zenon son of Zenon, wrestler
entry.summary: A statue base shaft (h. not measured, 0.45 x 0.45) with moulded panels,. Inscribed on the face. Date: Early third century (contests). Photos. The complete stone was copied by Deering (f. 6 no. 26). Seven fragments were recorded by Gaudin (29b, 29e, 32, 34b, 45 [twice]). One of these (part of Reinach 143) recorded by the MAMA expedition. That fragment, and three others recorded by the NYU expedition. Published from Deering by Leake, no. 11, whence LBW 1616a, Liermann, Analecta. 27; by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, nos 91, 92, 112, 115, 118, 143: see the reconstruction by J. M. R. Cormack, Inscribed Monuments of Aphrodisias (Reading, 1955), 63, fig.12. Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records and previous publications, MAMA VIII.513; by Roueché, PPA 78.

entry.summary: Piece from the lower part of a white marble sarcophagus (0.90 × 0.35 × 0.13). Inscribed on the bottom moulding. Date: Third century A.D. (nomenclature and lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1962 (62.305). Unpublished.

entry.title: Honours for Marcus Aurelius Zenas
entry.summary: Lower part of a ectangular white marble statue base with moulded panels on three sides, reconstructed from seven fragments and incomplete in the upper part (0.51 × 1.135 × 0.51). Inscribed within the front panel, which is complete above (die 0.375 × 0.995). The text must have begun on a crowning feature, now lost. Date: Third centuries A.D. (lettering, nomenclature). Photos. Three fragments recorded by Gaudin (34a, 29f, g); these fragments, further damaged, recorded by the NYU expedition with four additional fragments (Temple 16; SBI 89). Three fragments published from Gaudin's squeeze by Reinach, 109, 116, 117, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 581, 372.

Date: Probably third century A.D. (lettering; cutting). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1961 (a. Temple 41). Unpublished.

entry.title: Honours for Meliton, kitharist
entry.summary: 18 fragments of a white marble statue base shaft with moulded panels on at least three sides (approximate H. 1.14, W. 0.55, D. 0.55),. Inscribed on two adjacent sides. Line 1 is cut on the upper moulding of Face a; the opening phrases must have been inscribed on a crowning feature. Date: Εarly third century A.D. (contests). Photos. A fragment from the upper left side of face a recorded by Kubitschek and Reichel (unpublished, K.V.18c, Abklatsch 13); recorded with a further fragment by Gaudin (40, 45). The upper of those fragments recorded by the NYU expedition, as well as seventeen further fragments, twelve of which join (inv. no. 86.43, Temple 17, Temple 29, and unnumbered). Published, from Gaudin's squeeze, by Reinach, no. 148bis, whence (in part) Robert, 'Études d'épigraphie grecque', 29-30 (= OMS II, 1129-30), McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 301. Full text published by Roueché, PPA 69.

entry.title: Honours for Aurelia Kelesteina
entry.summary: Seven adjoining fragments of a white marble base. Inscribed on the face within a moulded panel. Date: Probably third century A.D. (lettering). Photos. a (ll. 1-7) recorded by Gaudin (48); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (SBI 102). b (ll 6-9), recorded by Gaudin (29) but not subsequently. c (ll. 2-7), d (ll. 7-9) e (ll. 10-13), f (ll.15-16) and g (Temple 55, SBI 105: ends of ll.13-15) only recorded by the NYU expedition. a published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 208, no. 87; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 515 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 251. b published by Reinach from Gaudin's squeeze, no. 111.

entry.title: Funerary for Chrysaphios the chief-doctor
entry.summary: Left side of a white marble block (0.27 × 0.40 × 0.16). Inscribed within a roughly incised tabella ansata (die, 0.18 × 0.16). The surface of the stone is only partly dressed; the left side may have a rebate. Date: Unlikely to be earlier than third century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1965 (65.418). Published from Reynolds by Nutton, PBSR 45, 1977, 193, no. 3, whence SEG 1977.718, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 468 .

entry.title: Honours for Aurelia Apphia daughter of Epiktetos
entry.summary: White marble statue base shaft, with moulded panels on all four sides, the moulding extensively damaged, broken at the back (0.52 × 1.24 × 0.49). There is a clamp-hole on the top, and a groove down the left side. Inscribed on the front panel (die, 0.35 × 1.075). The text must have begun on a crowning feature, now lost. Date: Third century A.D. (nomenclature). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition (Temple 14; SBI 92). Unpublished.

entry.title: Honours for [...] daughter of ...]lianos
entry.summary: Three joining fragments of a white marble statue base (together 0.51 × 1.38 × 0.47) with moulded panels on all four sides. Inscribed within the front panel; the text must have begun on a crowning feature. Date: Second quarter third century A.D. (reign). Photos. Recorded by Gaudin (91: 'inscription Bonnet') when the stone was still complete; recorded in 3 fragments by the MAMA expedition, by the NYU expedition (SBI 93). Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 147-149, no. 80; published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 514, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 342.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary formula from sarcophagus fragment
entry.summary: Part of the front of a white marble garland sarcophagus, broken at either side and below: see Isik 75 for fuller description. Inscribed along the upper edge (surviving width of inscription, 0.70). In the second line the cutter has had to avoid elements of the decorative relief. The full text muxt have begun on the lid, and finished on the lower moulding. Date: Probably middle third century (lettering, spelling). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1962 (62.378). Published by Isik and Reynolds, no. 75.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Licinius Valerianus
entry.summary: Three adjoining fragments of a white marble statue base shaft with a moulded panel on one face. a, an upper right corner fragment, has lines 1-6 (0.23 × 0.33 × 0.30); b, a fragment with the left side moulding surviving has lines 6-20 (0.38 × 0.53 × 0.34); c, the lower part of the block, with moulding surviving on both sides and below, has lines 16-20 (0.46 × 0.46 × 0.54). Inscribed within the panel; the last letter is cut on the moulding in lines 5, 6, 17, 18 and (presumably) 10. Date: A.D. 253-260 (content). Photos. b recorded by Kubitschek (K V.18, Abklatsch 23); by Gaudin (48); by the MAMA expedition; that and two further fragments (a and c) found by the NYU expedition. Fragment published by Reinach, no. 90, from Gaudin and by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, 509; all fragments published by Roueché (1981), no. 3, whence SEG 1981.906, BE 1982.357; An.Ép. 1981.767; republished by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 4, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 211. Discusssion: Christol & Drew-Bear, Travaux & Recherches 1982, 35 no. 32, Zaccaria, Sodalitas (Festschrift Guarino) vol. 2, 697-709, An.Ép. 1984.884.

entry.title: Warning against approaching the bema (verse); invocations
entry.summary: A white marble masonry block, broken in two (1.20 × 0.67 × 0.29); perhaps a door-post. There is a channel cut down the left side of the face. On the face: i is above ii, which is arranged about a cross (H. 0.085); of iii: immediately below ii, arranged about a cross (H. 0.115). There are other, less intelligible graffiti, and several crosses on this block. Date: Fifth-sixth century or later (content, location). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 129 i-iv, and plate xxxii (iii and iv) whence (i) McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 710, Steinepigramme 02/09/90, (ii-iv) McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 806, 767, 789.

entry.title: i: Elements of a funerary formula; ii: Epitaph of Biktorinos, praefectus vehiculorum
entry.summary: A white marble sarcophagus (0.30 x 1.80) from which part of the front and of the lower sides has been carefully removed. It seems likely, but not certain, that this second inscription should be associated with the cutting away of the front, although it is difficult to envisage how the stone was then used - perhaps to support a coffin?. i: lines 1-2 on the lower part of the inscribed Tabella ansata, and in one line on the lower moulding. ii, published here, was cut along the upper edge of the back of the sarcophagus. Date: Late third/early fourth century (titulature). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1984. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no 152 and plate xxxv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 516.

Inscribed on a prepared face, apparently within a raised tabula ansata, of which the lower right corner survives. All the other surfaces are rough. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1963 and 1983 (63.1, 83.110a and 83.110b). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 72 and plate xvii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 613.

entry.title: Invocation of Ourania
entry.summary: A paving block of the Odeon stage. The block (0.24 x 0.69) may originally have been rectangular, but the top left corner is now formed by a separate block (0.33 x 0.70), which appears to be a subsequent insertion, since it was held in place by metal clamps: these have since been lost, but the grooves for them remain. Since the upper edge of the block forms part of the rim of the stage, it appears that the repair, and others like it, was necessary to improve the appearance of that rim, which may have become worn. Subsequent to the repair, the rim was used for an inscription in the middle or later fifth century (2.19). The text was inscribed, using a metal tool, after the insertion had been made, since the letters in l.1 allow for interruption by one of the clamps. This part of the surface was later scratched, apparently in preparation for a plaster or other coating. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (lettering, content). Photo. Recorded by the NYU exhibition in 1966 (Odeon 1). Published byRoueché, PPA 12.

entry.summary: Wall plaster fragments: a section of plaster very heavily covered with graffiti; there are many other indeterminate traces beyond those described here. Date: First to sixth centuries A.D. (context). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1964 (64.447). Published by Roueché, ALA 218, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 782, 783, 788, and again as PPA 11.A.

entry.title: a: Honours for Claudia Antonia Tatiane; b. Sculptor's signature, of Alexandros
entry.summary: a. White marble statue base in three elements. Multi tiered upper plinth (0.88 × 0.41 × 0.88); shaft with moulding on all four sides (0.565 x 1.31 x 0.54); multi tiered lower plinth (0.81 × 0.405 × 0.88). The statue survives; see bibliography. b. Plinth of statue. a. Inscribed on the shaft; b. inscribed on the plinth of the statue. Date: Second century A.D. (prosopography). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1964 (64.426, 64.427; SBI 111). a. Published by Erim, Archaeology 20, 1967, 22-24; by Reynolds, in Belleten Türk Tarih Kurumu 32, 1968, 21-23, no. 5, whence BE 1969.541; Reynolds in Inan-Rosenbaum Porträtplastik 215-216, no. 187, whence SEG 1982.1100; SEG 1985.10828; McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 290. b. Published by Erim, Archaeology 20, 1967, 22-24; by Alföldi, Erim, & Inan, Belleten Türk Tarih Kurumu 32, 1968, 8-10, no. 5; by Inan & Alföldi-Rosenbaum 214, no. 187, whence SEG 1982.1103, SEG 1982.1082, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 585 ; by Erim-Reynolds, 'Sculptors' no.2, whence SEG 1990.925. Both texts published, with the statue, by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, no. 96.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Numbering for steps, Odeon
entry.summary: White marble steps. 1 inscribed on the lower corridor running round the rim of the orchestra· i. Beside the entry to the staircase adjoining the East analemma; ii Beside the entry to the second staircase from the West analemma. iii Behind the West analemma. 2. On the upper corridor: ii. On the topp step of the second staircase from the West analemma. Date: Second to fifth centuries A.D. (context). Recorded by the NYU expedition. Reynolds, 'Inscriptions of the Odeon' in Ratté, forthcoming..

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment
entry.summary: White marble revetment fragment. Inscribed on the face before re-use. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, context). Recorded by the NYU expedition (Odeon 14). Reynolds, 'Inscriptions of the Odeon' in Ratté, forthcoming..

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Attalos and Diogenes, brothers
entry.summary: Two matching white marble bases, with moulding at top and bottom; a: complete (0.625 × 0.90 × 0.615). Inscribed on the face (0.48 × 0.52) which is broken above and at left side. b: Four adjoining fragments, inscribed on the face. Date: Severan (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition (a. Odeon 18, b. Odeon 19). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for L. Ant. Cl. Dometeinos Diogenes
entry.summary: White marble statue base in three elements. Multi tiered upper plinth 0.95 × 0.35 × 0.85; shaft with moulding on all four sides (0.565 x 1.31 x 0.565; multi tiered lower plinth 0.92 × 0.35 × 0.90. The statue survives; see bibliography. Inscribed on one fascia of the upper plinth (l.1) and on the shaft. Date: Early third century A.D. (prosopography, lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1964 (64.277; SBI 110). Described by Erim, AJA 69, 1965, 145, and Archaeology 20, 1967, 26, fig. 15; full text, by Reynolds, in Belleten Türk Tarih Kurumu 32, 1968, 21-23, no. 6, whence BE 1969.54, and in Inan-Rosenbaum Porträtplastik, 212-213, no. 186, whence SEG 1982.1101, SEG 1985.1082, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 233 . Published, with the statue, by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, no. 48.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Seat inscriptions, Odeon block D
entry.summary: Odeon, seat. Row 6: Inscribed on one seat, whose surface has subsequently been chipped, as if for plastering. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries A.D. (context, content). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Cited by Alan Cameron, Circus Factions, 79, 135; published, Jews and Godfearers, Appendix, 1a; published by Roueché, ALA 180.iii, and again, PPA 47.2.D.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Ampelios, father of the city, restores the 'palaestra'
entry.summary: White marble blocks making up the Odeon/Bouleuterion stage edge, which is 0.10 high. The rim was broken in several places: it has been largely restored, but four fragments are still loose. Cut along the rim of the stage. The total length of the text is 7.65. Date: Mid fifth century (lettering, titulature). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1963. Published by Erim, ILN 21 Dec. 1963, 1028; by Roueché (1979), 176, no. 2, whence BE 1980.473; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 43 and plate, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 620.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Epigram for Pytheas
entry.summary: Six fragments from a white marble statue base shaft with panels within moulded edges on all sides (a 1.40 × 0.51 × 0.43). Inscribed on the front panel; the last letter of l. 11 cut on moulding. Date: Late fifth century (prosopography). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1962-64; statue excavated in 1962-3 (62.484, 62.489, 63.72). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 56 and plate xiv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 726, Steinepigramme 02/09/19. Statue published by J. Inan and E. Alföldi, Roman and early Byzantine portait sculpture from Asia Minor (London, 1966), no. 66; discussed by Smith (1999), 168 and fig. 8, plate iv.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours by People for Council
entry.summary: Two joining fragments from the lower left corner of a large white marble statue base with flat moulding (0.05) below (0.80 × 0.32 × 0.60). Inscribed on the face. Date: III-IV (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1966 (Odeon 13A). Previously unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Mason's mark
entry.summary: Upper part of a white marble statue base with moulding above; there is a rectangular hollow on the top. Scratched on the moulding. Date: Not dateable. Excavated by the NYU expedition; found in the Odeon Store in 1966. Reynolds, 'Inscriptions of the Odeon' in Ratté, forthcoming.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Sarcophagus fragment with mason's mark
entry.summary: Fragment of simple moulding, probably from the top of a sarcophagus front (0.21 × 0.09 × 0.08). Inscribed on one face. Date: Impossible to determine. Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (62.345, SD 71C). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment from Bouleuterion/Odeon
entry.summary: White marble fragment without back or edges (0.18 × 0.175 × 0.14). Inscribed on the face. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition in 1963 (63.64). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment
entry.summary: Fragment without edges (0.08 × 0.07 x 0.035). Inscribed on one face. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition in 1963 (63.343). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Monumental revetment fragment
entry.summary: White marble revetment fragment, with upper and lower edges surviving (0.58 × 0.45 × 0.04). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition in 1964 (64.272). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment from Odeon
entry.summary: White marble fragment without edges (0.39 × 0.10 × 0.18). Inscribed on the surviving face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Odeon 21). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragmentary honours from Bouleuterion/Odeon
entry.summary: One loose (0.20 × 0.15 × 0.27) and two joining white marble fragments (0.29 × 0.14 × 0.23) moulded above. Inscribed on one face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Museum 104). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Statue dedication of Aphrodite
entry.summary: White marble statue base upper plinth, with moulding on three sides and roughed out, but not completed, on the back (0.36 × 1.20 × 1.03) There is a clamp hole on the underside for an attachment; the top is not currently visible. The plinth supported the statue of Aphrodite now in the Aphrodisias Museum. Inscribed on the lower fascia (0.865 × 0.085). The stone is complete except for chipping at the upper right corner and along edges; the text must have been completed on a lower feature. Date: Late second to early third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (SBI 119; Odeon 17). Previously unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: i. Honours for Septimus Severus; ii. Building inscription of Antonius Priskos
entry.summary: Six fragments of a white marble statue base shaft inscribed on two faces. i. (1.06 × 0.77 × 0.355) with moulding above and below which mostly survives on the left side, but has apparently been chipped away from the right. ii. was cut on the underside of the base (0.355 x 0.77) with a simple stepped moulding above, and traces of the same below. i. inscribed on the face; ii. inscribed later on the underside. Date: i. A.D. 198-210 (titulature); ii. A.D. 388/392 (prosopography). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition (Odeon 20; SBI 116). i. Mentioned by Roueché under ALA 28, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 207 . Published by Reynolds in Ratté 2007; ii. published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 28, and plate viii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 634.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours by Council for People
entry.summary: White marble statue plinth (0.70 x 0.15). Inscribed along the front in one line. Date: third-4th centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1962 (62.452). Previously unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment of building inscription
entry.summary: Fragment from a white marble panel, with lower moulding surviving (0.36 × 0.36 × 0.10). Inscribed on the face. Date: Fourth-fifth century (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1963. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 228, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 760.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Statue dedication by Flavius Andronikos
entry.summary: A rectangular white marble statue base shaft, with moulding at the upper and lower edges (0.57 × 1.165 × 0.485), which has been re-used. The first line—on the upper moulding—is from an earlier text, which has been erased from the face and replaced by the present text. Date: c. A.D. 324-350 (lettering, content). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1964 (64.278). Published by Erim and Roueché (1982), no. 3, whence SEG 1982.1107; BE 1984.405, SEG 1985.1082 and discussion by D. Rössler, 'Andronikos IV', in Künstlerlexikon der Antike (Munchen/Leipzig, 2001); by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 13, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 169; by Erim and Reynolds (1991), no. 14, whence SEG 1990.937..

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment, possibly dedication
entry.summary: Fragment from upper left corner of a white marble statue base (0.16 × 0.115 × 0.105). Inscribed on the face. Date: Probably first century B.C. (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1967 (67.489). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment, Augustan date, from Odeon area
entry.summary: Fragment of white marble architrave, with three fasciae and moulding above (0.34 × 0.35 × 0.25); no edges survive. Inscribed on middle fascia. Date: probably Augustan (lettering). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition in 1967 (67.493). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Building inscription by [—]nius Lysias
entry.summary: Fragment of white marble architrave block (1.14 x 0.80 x 1.30), with moulding above; badly damaged. Inscribed area 0.71 x 0.08. Date: Perhaps first to second centuries A.D. (letter-forms). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1972 (Odeon 22). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment of honours
entry.summary: Fragment from the right side of a white marble panel with ? a bevelled edge (0.23 × 0.27 × 0.06). Inscribed on one face. Date: Perhaps first century A.D. lettering. Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1968 (68.95). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Sarcophagus fragment
entry.summary: White marble fragment, possibly from a sarcophagus front (0.13 × 0.17 × 0.09) with moulding above; lower edge survives. Inscribed on the face. Date: Probably second century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (68.322). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment from North Bouleuterion
entry.summary: Fragment without back or edges (0.11 × 0.21 × 0.15). Inscribed on the face. Date: Probably Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1970 (70.1). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Letter from a Roman official to Aphrodisias
entry.summary: Fragment from the bottom of a white marble stele moulded below (0.30 xh. 0.16 x 0.115). Inscribed on one face, which seems very slightly concave. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1973 (73.156). Published by Reynolds, A&R 51, whence BE 1983.391, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 65 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary for Publius Aelius Klaudius Smaragdos Julianos and his father
entry.summary: Four joining fragments from a large marble block: a. without edges (0.57 × 0.85 × 0.23); b. right edge fragment, with lower edge surviving (0.32 × 1.10 × 0.67); c. small triangular fragment, (circa 0.145 × 0.18); d. left edge fragment (0.20 × 0.45 × 0.14). Inscribed on one face. Date: second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, prosopography). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition, a. in 1967 (67.554), b in 1983, d. in 1964 (64.359; SBI 17). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary formula from sarcophagus
entry.summary: Front of a white marble garland sarcophagus (2.27 × 0.96 × 0.09) damaged to the left and at the top along the edge, broken away at right. For description see Isik 100. ll. 1-8 cut on the upper part of the front of the sarcophagus, avoiding the decorative features, except that l. 8 impinges on the upper moulding of the tabella; ll. 9-20 within the tabella. The text probably began on the lid. Date: Probably second to early third centuries (lettering, spelling). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1973 (73.266). Published by Isik and Reynolds, no. 100.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for M. Au[relius - ]
entry.summary: Piece from the top left corner of a moulded white marble panel, probably from the side of a base with moulding above and to left, but without back or other edges (0.12 × 0.15 × 0.06). Ιnscribed within a recessed panel. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1970 (70.4). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragmentary honours from the Gerousia
entry.summary: Piece from the lower part of a white marble base (0.30 x 0.11 x 0.85). Nothing interpretable survives above; there is a left edge, but the lay-out suggests that this is a section from a composite monument. Inscribed on the face. Date: ?Third century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1973 (73.258). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Zotikos
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus lid re-used as a trough (1.965 x 0.29 x 0.81). Inscribed on the edge of the sarcophagus lid (1.965 x 0.08), which is rubbed in places and pierced by several holes; some of the damage was done before the inscription was cut. The text must have continued on the box of the sarcophagus. Date: Probably third century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Odeon 8). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Storage jar of Polychronios: measurement
entry.summary: A large white marble storage jar (H. 0.895, maximum diam. 0.77), which is cracked. Inscribed in one line along the shoulder. Date: Fourth-sixth century (content). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 214, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 869; republished by Roueché, PPA 87.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Table/dish fragment
entry.summary: Fragment of a curved white marble rim (of dish/table) (0.045 × 0.075 × 0.065). Inscribed in one line along edge. Date: Fourth to fifth century (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition (69.108). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 225, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 873.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary verse for Arkimos
entry.summary: A white marble plaque (0.43 × 0.33 × 0.05), chipped at sides and broken at upper left corner. Inscribed on the face. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries A.D. (lettering, metre). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1968 (68.321). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 162, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 729.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Gameboard and pavement designs, Bishop's Palace
entry.summary: White marble paving slabs. Cut on the face. Date: Second-tenth century A.D. (context). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Gameboards 16.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Graffiti: Prayers and names
entry.summary: A blue marble column. ii. below i.; iii. below ii.; iv. to left of iii., arranged in a cross monogram; v. below iii.; vi. below and to right of v. There are other, less intelligible, graffiti. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries A.D. or later (content, location). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 134 i-vi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 769, 770, 794, 795, 796, 797.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment, undated, from Odeon area
entry.summary: White marble revetment fragment without edges (0.16 × 0.175 × 0.03). Too fragmentary to describe. Date: No useful indication. Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (65.369). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment of mason's mark
entry.summary: Block with top and left side as originally prepared with a very slight moulding along the edges; right side and bottom as subsequently cut down (0.32 × 0.195 × 0.125). Inscribed on one face. Date: ... Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (65.451). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Decree of the koinon of Asia
entry.summary: Fragment of a white marble panel from a composite monument (0.60 x 0.58 x 0.30), broken away on an uneven edge on the left side, chipped along all edges. Inscribed on the face; text began on another block above, and probably continued on a further block to the right. Date: First century B.C. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1966 (66.26). Published by Erim, PBSR 37, 1969, 94-95, no. 2, whence discussed by Oliver, AJP 93 (1972), 195-197, Drew-Bear, ZPE 8, 1971, 286-287, no. IV, whence BE 1972.413; published by Drew-Bear, BCH 96, 1972, 443-445, whence BE 1973.398-399; published by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 5, whence SEG 32, 1982.1097, BE 1983:366, SEG 35, 1985.1081; from all these McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 2 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication to Theos Hypsistos
entry.summary: Upper right corner of a white marble altar (0.12 × 0.135 × 0.09), with the upper moulding chiselled away and the face damaged, perhaps by burning. Graffiti scratched on the face. Date: Perhaps first century B.C. to first century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1965 (65.433). Published by Reynolds & Tannenbaum, Jews and Godfearers at Aphrodisias, appendix, 12, whence BE 1988.888, SEG 1987.854, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 174.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment, of honours
entry.summary: Fragment of a panel with moulded lower edge and back surviving (0.19 × 0.15 × 0.04). Inscribed on face and on moulding (l. 4). Date: First century B.C. to first century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition in 1963 (63.158). Unpublished.

entry.summary: Two joining fragments of a white marble panel (together 0.42 x 0.56 x 0.16). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to first centuries B.C. (lettering, prosopography). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1963 (inventory number 63.145). Published by Erim, PBSR 37, 1969, 92-93, no. 1, whence Drew-Bear, ZPE 8, 1971, 286-288, no. II, BullEp 1972.413; by Drew-Bear, BCH 96, 1972, 435-436, whence BullEp 1973.398, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 1.

entry.summary: White marble column base broken away to the left side (0.78 × 0.09). Inscribed on the moulding. Date: Probably first century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (68.262). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary honours for Kastor son of Menekrates
entry.summary: Part of a plain white marble base chipped on all edges, with upper and lower left corners broken and the front face water-worn (0.46 × 0.77 × 0.39). There are holes in the top for an attachment. Inscribed on the face. The text must have begun on a lost upper feature. Date: Probably first century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1967 (67.474). Unpublished.

entry.summary: Piece from the right side of a white marble statue base shaft (0.09 × 0.17 × 0.08). Inscribed within a simple moulding. Date: 1st-6th century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition in 1968 (68.242). Unpublished.

entry.title: Dedication to Theos Hypsistos
entry.summary: Two joining fragments forming a small rough white marble altar (0.10 × 0.26 × 0.10), with moulding above and below. Inscribed on two adjacent faces (ll. 1-4 on a., 5-7 on b) with a text that runs from one to the other. Date: First century A.D. or later (nomenclature). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1965 and 1967 (65.357, 67.199). Published by Reynolds & Tannenbaum, Jews and Godfearers at Aphrodisias, appendix, 11, whence BE 1988.888, SEG 1987.853, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 175.

entry.title: Fragment from SW Bouleuterion
entry.summary: Fragment without back or edges (0.15 × 0.18 × 0.15); just possibly the top edge. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Found by the NYU expedition in 1965 (65.129). Unpublished.

Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition in 1965 (65.251). Unpublished.

entry.summary: Corner fragment of an elaborately moulded feature, probably a sarcophagus front (0.115 × 0.29 × 0.09). Inscribed on two adjacent faces. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1967 (67.193). Unpublished.

entry.title: Building dedication to divinity/emperor
entry.summary: Upper right corner of white marble statue base without moulding (0.25 × 0.31 × 0.48). Inscribed on one face. Date: Late second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1968 (68.261, SBI 20). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary formula from sarcophagus
entry.summary: White marble garland sarcophagus 2.12 × 0.94 × 0.89 with a central tabella (0.49 x 0.53); for full description see Isik 101. Inscribed on the front. a beside a bust of the dead man; b on the upper moulding of the tabella (ll. 1-2) and within it. The text clearly began on the lid. Date: Perhaps late second to early third centuries (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1964 (64.235; sarc. catalogue 35). Published by Isik and Reynolds, no. 101.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment of a Latin text (Regulation)
entry.summary: A fragment (0.125 × 0.16 × 0.02) from a white marble panel, with upper edge surviving. Inscribed on the face. Date: Third-fourth century (language, lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition (66.153). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 220 and plate xlvi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 945.

entry.title: Fragments of a consolatory decree
entry.summary: Five fragments which join to form 2 parts of one text: i: (a & b): Left side fragment, broken on all other sides; ii: (c, d, e) three fragments, broken on all sides. Inscribed on the face. Date: Third century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1963 and 1965 (e: 63.172, a-d: 65.469). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary verse
entry.summary: Lower right corner of a white marble block with a panel, within a slightly raised rim, on the 3 surviving faces 0.25 × 0.25 × 0.27. Inscribed on one face. Date: Third-fourth century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1965 (65.363). Unpublished.

entry.title: Flavius Septimius a benefactor
entry.summary: Four fragments—three of which join to form a.—from a series of white marble panels with three fasciae, divided by grooves, and diminishing in height from top to bottom; a: three joining fragments, with left edge surviving (0.30 × 0.69 × 0.025). b: broken at both ends (0.30 × 0.51 × 0.055). Such variation in the thickness of revetment panels over a large area is not unusual. Inscribed on the upper, tallest fascia. Date: ?Fourth century (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1966 (66.155). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 35 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 666.

entry.title: Epitaph of Rufinianos
entry.summary: Fragment from the upper edge of a white marble plaque with flat moulding (0.44 × 0.40 × 0.13). Inscribed in one line on upper moulding. Date: Fourth century or later (style, lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1963 (63.575). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias 177 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 751.

entry.title: Table fragment
entry.summary: Two joining fragments from a circular white marble disc or table-top, which is flat and has no raised rim (0.185 × 0.29 × 0.03). Inscribed in one line on the flat surface, along the edge. Date: Fourth to sixth century (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition (67.206, 68.233). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 223 and plate xlvi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 871.

entry.summary: Fragment from the edge of a white marble dish or table (0.13 × 0.12 × D. at rim 0.04), with a raised rim. Inscribed along rim. Date: Fourth to fifth centuries A.D. or later (lettering, type). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition (67.510). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 224, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 872.

entry.summary: Two fragments, which do not join, from a white marble dish or table with a raised rim (depth at rim 0.06); a: 0.33 × 0.16; b: 0.13 × 0.215. Inscribed on the rim. Date: Fifth or sixth century or later (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition (65.368, 66.278). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 222, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 876, 877.

entry.title: Building inscription of bishop Euphemius
entry.summary: Two fragments, not joining, of white marble revetment or paving whose lower edge survives; a: 0.50 × 0.41 × 0.065; b: 0.44 × 0.28 × 0.065. Inscribed in one line, 0.165 from lower edge. Date: Early sixth century (prosopography). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1966 and 1975 (66.287 and 75.323). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 60 and plate xv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 632.

entry.summary: Left corner block of a white marble architrave block broken on all sides (0.695 × 0.30 x 0.60). Inscribed on two fasciae. Date: First century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1973 (73.379). Unpublished.

entry.title: Sculptor's signature of Apollonios Aster
entry.summary: Lower part of an statue, which has been published (see bibliography). Inscribed on a helmet next to the left foot. Date: ?Early 1st century A.D. (lettering, sculpture). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1972 (72.439). Published, Erim, Inan Rosenbaum, under no. 79; by Erim-Reynolds, 'Sculptors' no.5, whence SEG 40 1990.928; published C. Hallett, AJA 102 (1998), 59-89, 67, whence BullEp 1998.384. Published, with the statue, by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, no. 14.

entry.summary: Column, fluted above, smooth below. Inscribed below fluting at the west side. The surface has been lost to the left. Date: No indication. Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Portico 1). Unpublished.

Excavated by the NYU expedition (Odeon 12). Published by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 39, whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.388, AnnEpig 1984.878, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 82.

entry.title: Building dedication to a god
entry.summary: White marble architrave fragment (1.14 x 0.36 x 0.60); lower fascia broken, but apparently uninscribed. Inscribed on upper fascia. Date: First century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Found by NYU expedition (Village 3). Unpublished.

entry.title: i. Dedication to Patris by Zenon son of Euthymos and others; ii. The Phrygian Metropolis honours Alexandros, in verse
entry.summary: An octagonal white marble statue base shaft (1.05, on a plinth 0.21; 0.495) with two inscriptions. The first, probably dating from the first or early second century A.D., has been partially erased, and the base placed so that it faces the wall. i. inscribed on the reverse face, now against the wall, the letters at the right ends of the lines being partially erased; ii. occupies two faces, diametrically opposite the first text. Date: i. probably second century A.D. (lettering); ii. Late fourth or fifth century (lettering, content). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1965 (65.396; SBI 108). The statue accompanying ii, whose head is lost, was found lying beside the base, and is now in the Museum. i. forthcoming by Reynolds in publication of Bouleuterion Odeon. ii. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 32 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 713, C. P. Jones, Hermes 125 (1997), 212-14, Steinepigramme 02/09/02. Statue: K. T. Erim in Turk Ark. Derg. 15.1 (1966), 61, 66; Smith (1999), 165-7.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Place inscription of Philippos
entry.summary: White marble column. Cut a little way below the fluting. Date: Third-fourth centuries A.D. (lettering, context). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 198 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 391.

entry.title: Fl. Pelagius Ioannes gives a column
entry.summary: A white marble column fluted above and smooth below. 'Höhe: 154, Breite: 220.'. Inscribed on the smooth surface, below the fluting. Date: Later fourth century (titulature, lettering). Photo. Copied by Kubitschek (K.III.38, Abklatsch xxx); not reported subsequently. Published by Cormack, ABSA 59 (1964), no. 22, from Kubitscheck's copy; whence Robert, AC 35, 1966, 381, Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 29, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 608.
