entry.title: Menandros, curialis, gives a column
entry.summary: A white marble column fluted above and smooth below. Cut on the smooth surface, 0.145 below the fluting. Date: Later fourth century A.D.. Photo. Copied by Kubitschek (K. III.38, Abklatsch xxxv); recorded by the NYU expedition. Published from Kubitschek's copy by Cormack, ABSA 59 (1964), no. 21, whence Robert, AC 35, 1966, 381-2; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 30, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 603.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: i. Verse honours for Oikoumenios; ii. Invocation
entry.summary: A white marble statue, and a rectangular white marble statue base shaft with panels within moulded edges on three sides (1.27 × 0.60 × 0.53). i. Inscribed on the central panel of the base; the surface is rough, either because it was badly prepared, or more probably because an earlier inscription had been erased. ii. Inscribed on the head of the statue, behind the front line of hair, to the left of centre. Date: Later fourth century A.D. (style, language). Photos. The base and the body of the statue were excavated by the NYU expedition in 1965 (base: 65.198); see K. T. Erim in Turk Ark. Derg. 15.1 (1966), 61. The head was excavated in 2000. Published by Ševcenko (1967), 286, whence BE 1968.508 ; republished by Ševcenko (1968) 29, whence BE 1969.543 ; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity, no. 31 and plate ix, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 724 , Steinepigramme 02/09/17 . Statue: K.T. Erim, 'Two new early Byzantine statues from Aphrodisias', DOP 21 (1967), 285-6, no. 2; Smith (2002) 134-156.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Marcus and Publius Vinicius
entry.summary: Two white marble statue base shafts (i. 0.89 × 0.79 × depth not measurable; ii. 0.805 × 0.86 × depth not measurable). Inscribed on the face. Date: Statue base i: Augustan (lettering). Statue base ii: Tiberian (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (SBI 125, 124). Published by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 45ab, whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.391, AnnEpig 1984.880a, 1984.880b, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 313, 314.

entry.title: Building inscription
entry.summary: Part of a white marble architrave block which originally had cornice and three fasciae (0.14, 0.125-13, 0.10) with simple intercolumnar decoration below. Inscribed on the upper fasciae. Has been subsequently cut for reuse with part of the moulding and fasciae cut away and the back roughed out for a garland frieze. Date: Probably first century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1988 (88.i). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Column dedications by Claudia Antonia
entry.summary: Three white marble columns, fluted above: i. standing, facing north west; very weathered. ii. standing, facing north west. iii. fragment of a column shaft. Each inscribed below fluting; i. at 1.35 above base; ii. at 1.34. Date: Second century A.D. (lettering). Photos. i. and ii copied by K&R, 'southern portico' (iii.38); i and ii recorded by the Italian Mission; i, ii and iii recorded by the NYU expedition. i and ii published from K's notebook by Cormack, no. 24, on which see L. Robert, Ant. Class. (1966) 399-400, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 88, 89, 90. i and ii published by Jacopi, MiItal. no. 7, p.226, whence BE 1948.211.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Graffito illustrating munera
entry.summary: White marble column: cut on the smooth surface. A lightly cut graffito. Date: First to seventh centuries A.D. (content, context). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, PPA 42.

entry.title: Building dedication to an emperor
entry.summary: White marble architrave block, slightly chipped on the upper edge and at both sides (2.05 × 0.14 × 0.11). Inscribed on the external face on two fasciae; the text was clearly continued on the adjacent block. Date: First to second century A.D. (terminology, lettering). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition in 1969 (Portico 2). Published by Reynolds, PCPS 206, 1980, 78, no. 7, whence SEG 1980.1255, AnnEpig 1980.871, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 102.

entry.title: Building dedication to Aphrodite and emperors
entry.summary: 13 white marble architrave blocks (each 2.84 × 0.29 × 1.04) which consist of cornice and three fasciae. On one block, on the top, a gameboard was cut. Inscribed only on the uppermost fascia. Date: A.D. 14/29 (reign). Photos. Found by the Italian expedition in 1937; found again by the NYU expedition, with further fragments, 1986-8. Published by Jacopi, MonAL 38, 1939, 86-96, 1, whence BE 1948.211; by Reynolds, PCPS 1980, 77-8, no. 6, whence SEG 1980.1244, AnnEpig 1980.870, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 104.

entry.title: Pavement designs and place inscriptions, South Agora pool
entry.summary: White marble seating along the edge of pool. Inscribed roughly on the upper face. i: Beside the design. ii: Texts are cut outside the frame; a. Along east edge. b. Along north edge; deeper letters, ave. 0.06. the text apparently continued on an adjacent block, now lost. c. Along west edge. d. Along south edge. Date: Second-tenth century A.D. (context). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Gameboards 14.

entry.title: Fl. Eutolmius Tatianos honours Arcadius
entry.summary: The upper part of a white marble columnar statue base shaft (H. 0.66, din. 0.565) with a simple moulding above; The stone has weathered very badly and, especially in the erased area, has been covered in moss which has partially destroyed the surface. Inscribed on moulding (l. 1) and on drum (ll. 2 ff.). Date: A.D. 388/392 (emperor, prosopography). Photos. Excavated and transcribed by Mendel in September 1905; copied by Boulanger (Notebook A, 51, no. 2, whence B, 3, no. 1); copied by J. and L. Robert; recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Mendel, Catalogue, no. 506.1; by Grégoire, IGC 275, from Mendel's copy; by L. Robert, Hellenica 4, 50-51, from Boulanger's notes and his own copy, whence BE 1949.178; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity, 26, and Plate vii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 661. Statue: Published most recently by J. Inan and E. Alföldi, Roman and early Byzantine portait sculpture from Asia Minor (London, 1966), no. 66; discussed by R. R. R. Smith (1999), 162.

Date: A.D. 388/392 (emperor, prosopography). Photos. Excavated and transcribed by Mendel in September 1905; copied by Boulanger (Boulanger (Notebook A, 61, no. 22, whence B, 3, no. 2); copied by J. and L. Robert; recorded by the NYU expedition. Statue excavated by the NYU expedition in 1975 (75.248). Published by Mendel, Catalogue, no. 506.2; by Grégoire, IGC 276, from Mendel's copy; by L. Robert, Hellenica 4, 50-51, from Boulanger's notes and his own copy, whence BE 1949.178; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity, 27 and Plate vii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 662. Statue: R. R. R. Smith (1999), 162.

entry.title: Acclamation of the sellophoroi
entry.summary: A white marble masonry block (0.87 × 0.34 × 0.35) built into the rim of the pool in the South Agora. Cut on the upper, longer, face. It is unclear whether the text was cut in situ, or whether the stone has been re-used. Date: Fifth/sixth century (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1985. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 80, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 825.

entry.title: Acclamations of the Greens, the City and the Blues
entry.summary: Three white marble column bases. Cut on the southern faces of the three bases. The columns stand on a fairly high stylobate, so that the inscriptions, although below eye-level, would have been clearly visible. Date: Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1985. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity 186, i-iii, and plate xl, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 837, 838, 839.

entry.title: Place inscription of Theoktistos
entry.summary: White marble column. 1.35 above base of column. Date: Fifth-sixth century or later (content, location). Photos. Recorded by Kubitschek (K. III.38, Abklatsch xxxi; by the NYU expedition. Published by Cormack, ABSA 59, 1964, no. 23.1, whence Robert, AC 35 (1966), 381; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 202 and plate xli, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 685. Cormack suggests that there were two identical inscriptions, whence , ABSA 59, 1964, no. 23.2, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 686; this may have been a reference to 4.17, which is not identical.

entry.summary: The upper part of a columnar statue base shaft (0.40, diam. 0.50) of bluish marble, chipped above and broken below. Inscribed on one side. Date: Sixth century (lettering, prosopography). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 82 and plate xix, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 712, Steinepigramme 02/09/01.

entry.title: 1. Acclamations for Albinos, clarissimus; 2. Acclamation for the city
entry.summary: Nineteen out of an original twenty white marble columns, all on identical bases. The columns, 0.75 in diameter, are smooth to a height of 1.73, and fluted above. They are made in two sections; the join between the two is not always at the same point, being sometimes below, and sometimes above the line where the fluting begins, but the overall effect is uniform and elegant. Each of the surviving columns bears an inscription, cut just below the fluting, at a distance varying from 0.3 to 0.05, on the west face of the column. The inscriptions were, therefore, on the face sheltered by the roof of the portico, and have preserved traces of red paint in the letters. They form a series to be read from left to right—that is, from north to south. They were probably carved in that order; the lettering is at its most formal at the northern end of the portico, and becomes more cursive towards the south. Date: Sixth century A.D. (lettering). Photos. i Excavated by Mendel in 1905; copied by Boulanger (notebook A, 61, no. 20, whence B, 13, no 13). iv Excavated by Mendel in 1905; copied by Boulanger (notebook A, 61, no. 19, whence B, 13, no 12); viii copied by Fellows, recorded by Gaudin (33); xi: First letters of ll. 1 and 2 uncovered by Mendel and copied by Boulanger, (notebook A, 60, no. 25; not transcribed in B); xiii Lines 2-3 Copied by Mendel in 1905; by Boulanger in 1913 (Notebook A, p.53, no. 3). All recorded by the NYU expedition. i, iv published from Mendel by Grégoire, IGC 271, 274, whence i published by Peterson, 78 no. 4; viii published by Fellows, no. 63, whence CIG 2809b (p. 1112); by Reinach, no. 212, from Gaudin, whence Grégoire, IGC 273. 83, i-xx, and 84 published by Roueché, (1984), 191-3 nos. 1-20, whence SEG 1984.1046-1065, BE 1987.466; An.Ép. 1984.883; republished by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity nos. 83.i-xx, 84 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 656, 845-862, 864; vi and vii discussed by Daniel, ZPE 61, 1985, 127-130; vi by D. Bain, 'Six Greek verbs of sexual congress', CQ 41 (1991), 51-77, 53; vi, vii, x, xi cited in Steinepigramme 02/09/01.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for an anonymous benefactor, ?Solon son of Demetrios
entry.summary: White marble block, chipped along all edges and also on the surface ; there are dowel-holes for an attachment above. Inscribed on the face. This is the conclusion of a text which must have been laid out in several columns. The supplements are hardly in doubt. In 1. 5 the long vacat at the end is likely to have been balanced by another at the beginning and that seems to be confirmed by the little that survives of the surface there. Date: late Republican/Augustan (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1978 (inventory number 78.2. Published byReynolds, A&R 41 whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.390, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 326 .

entry.title: Honours for Antoninus Pius
entry.summary: Plain white marble statue base shaft (0.755 × 1.15 × 0.52) reconstructed from four fragments. The top is complete, and shows holes for attachment of a feature . The statue has survived, and has been published (see bibliography). Inscribed on the face. Date: A.D. 138-161 (reign). Photos. Excavated, with the accompanying statue of Antoninus Pius, by the NYU expedition in 1980 (80.24; SBI 32). Published, with the statue, by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, no. 17.

entry.title: Verse honours: i. for Ampelios, father of the city; ii. and iii. for Doulkitios, governor, on the Agora Gate
entry.summary: 'Agora Gate', at the east end of the South Agora. i., ii. and iii are all cut, clearly set out as a group, on the façade, on the highest remaining course of blocks, which was capped above by a moulded course. i. is cut on the northernmost of a series of projecting bastions; ii. is on the next bastion to the south, whose surface is largely lost; three loose fragments were found in 1983. The third bastion shows no sign of any inscription; iii. is cut on the fourth. i. and ii. are on a smooth face, but iii. is cut partly on a rough surface. Date: Mid fifth century (titulature). Photos. Excavated in 1980 by the NYU expedition (80.28, 80.29 and 80.53). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity nos. 38, 39, 40 and plates x and xi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 714, 704, 717, Steinepigramme 02/09/03, 02/09/08, 02/09/07; iii. republished by Roueché, PPA 65 whence Mentzou-Meimares BZ 89 (1996), 58-73, whence SEG 1996.1395.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for anonymous
entry.summary: Fragment without edges (0.24 × 0.155 × 0.03). Inscribed on the face. Date: Probably first century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1980 (80.11). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Sculptor's signature: Menodotos
entry.summary: White marble statue of a draped woman, on an oval plinth; for publication, see bibliography. Inscribed on the front face of the plinth. Date: First century A.D. (lettering, sculpture). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1983 (83.122). Published by Erim-Reynolds, 'Sculptors' no.7, whence SEG 40 1990.930. Published, with the statue, by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, no. 85.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Sculptor's signature of Apellas
entry.summary: Two joining fragments of a white marble statue plinth, carrying two sandalled feet; for publication of the statue, see bibliography. Inscribed on the front face (0.57 × 0.125), which is chipped along the upper edge and at the centre. Date: 1st century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1987 (87.445). Cited, Erim, AS 39 (1989), 176; published by Erim-Reynolds, 'Sculptors' no. 4, whence (partially) SEG 1990.927. Published, with the statue, by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, no. 54.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Latin funerary inscription
entry.summary: White marble ossuary (0.565 × 0.33 × 0.34), the front partly lost; reliefs of rams' heads, joined by a swag, on the front face, and blanks for the same on the sides. Inscribed below the swag on the front face, and presumably also within it, unless the text began on the lost lid. Date: First to second centuries A.D. (lettering, style of decoration). Photos. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (83.66). Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 558, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 502.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Polykrates
entry.summary: White marble fragment from the top of a stele (0.41 × 0.38 × 0.18); above, a relief of a gable with acroteria containing a circular object. Inscribed on a moulded panel below the relief. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1983 (83.70). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Donor's inscription of Kapitoleinos
entry.summary: White marble relief sculpture panel showing Pan and a seated female figure. Inscribed on upper moulding, which is broken away. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1978 (Agora Gate 1, previously Nymphaeum 1). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragmentary title for Amazonomachy sculpture
entry.summary: White marble relief sculpture panel, showing an Amazonomachy. Inscribed on upper moulding, which is broken to right. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (context, lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1978 (Agora Gate 2, previously Nymphaeum 2). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication and restoration of statues after an earthquake, authorised by Trajan, undertaken by Kallikrates Grypos.
entry.summary: White marble statue base shaft. Inscribed on two adjoining faces; b to left, a to right. Date: A.D. 102-116 (titulature). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1977 (77.134). a and b published by Reynolds, PCPS 206, 1980, 73-74, no. 3a, whence SEG 1980.1254, BullEp 1982.355, AnnEpig 1980.868; a republished by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 55, whence SEG 1982.1097, BullEp 1983.391; from all these McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 155 and 184. .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for T. Oppius Aelianus Asklepiodotos
entry.summary: White marble statue base capital and shaft (0.84 × 1.10 × 0.84) with moulding on three sides. Inscribed on the moulding of the capital (ll. 1, 2) and within the front panel (ll. 3-12). Date: A.D. 284-301 (prosopography). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1977 (77.135). Published by Roueché, (1981), no. 6, whence SEG 1981.910, BE 1982.357, An.Ép. 1981.770, An.Ép. 1982.893; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 7 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 311.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: i. Verse honours for Anthemios; ii. Invocation
entry.summary: A rectangular statue base without moulding, recomposed from two fragments (1.05 × 0.61 × 0.575). i. is inscribed on the front face, whose rough surface may indicate that a previous inscription had been erased; the surface has been worn away by water at the left side. ii. is cut on the right side, on a surface from which a previous text appears to have been erased, and which is oddly pitted. Date: i. A.D. 405/414 (prosopography); ii. fifth to sixth centuries A.D. or later (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1977 (77.76, SBI 47). i. published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 36, and plate ix, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 716, Steinepigramme 02/09/04 and discussion, Feissel (1991), 372; ii. Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no 144 and plate xxxiv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 779.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for an Emperor, Justinian
entry.summary: A white marble panel, restored from eight fragments, but with the corners and the lower part lost (0.16 × 0.74 × 0.025). Inscribed on the face. Date: Sixth century (lettering, ?emperor). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1983 during dismantling of the wall (83.127). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 81 and plate xix, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 663.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Epitaph of Nikolaos
entry.summary: A large white marble plaque (0.90 × 1.10 × 0.16) broken either end; the right end has been further broken since 1893. Inscribed across the centre of the face. Date: Tenth century or later (lettering). Photo. Copied by Kubitschek (K.III.22, Abklatsch viii); recorded by the NYU expedition in 1980. Published by Cormack, in ABSA 59 (1964), 11, from Kubitschek, whence L. Robert, AC. 1966, 281 n. 3; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 173 and plate xxix; not in PHI.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Pavement designs and an acclamation
entry.summary: Geometric black marble and white marble paving in 8 sections, each with a larger central panel. On the central panels. i. South side, second panel from the east, ii. South side, third panel from the east iii. North side, 1st panel from east. iv. North side, second panel from east. v. North side, third panel from east. Date: Second-tenth century A.D. (context). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Gameboards 1.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Column dedication to Demos by Artemon son of Adrastos
entry.summary: Four blue marble columns; i. Broken above and below (0.48); ii. Broken above, moulding survives below (c. 0.83); surface damaged. iii. Fragment broken on all sides (0.40 × 0.355); iv. broken column drum of blueish white marble (0.46; total height not reliably measurable). ii. Inscribed just above (c. 0.07) moulding; iv. inscribed at about 1.60 from base of column. Date: Second century A.D. (monument, lettering). Photos. The text informs us that there were originally 6 columns, presumably each bearing the same text; Mendel copied ii and cited i (notebook A 7, a; C, 9); all four recorded by the NYU expedition: i in 1985, ii and iii in 1988 (88.18), iv in 1978 (Theatre 20). i and ii published by Mendel, CRAI 1906, 172, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 128, 129.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Column dedication to Demos
entry.summary: Upper part of the shaft of a blue-white marble column (diam. across the top 0.42). Inscribed in an area which is worn or broken away. Date: Second century A.D. (monument, lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1984 (84.64). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Warning against theft
entry.summary: Pilaster block. Inscribed (0.29 × 0.175) at 2.30 above present ground level. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Seen and copied by Kubitschek (K III, 46; Abklatsch: 37). Recorded by Gaudin (74 and 140). Copied by Boulanger in 1905 (notebook p.39); recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by K&R, no. 3, Reinach (from Gaudin), 17, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 930 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Building dedication to Aphrodite and emperors
entry.summary: 28 pieces, complete or fragmentary, of white marble architrave blocks. Inscribed in a single line on one fascia. Date: A.D. 117/138 (reign). Photo. Excavated by the French expeditions in 1904, 1905 and 1913. Boulanger published fragmentary versions, but gives a fuller account in his notebook, put together after Mendel's publication: "M. Mendel qui n'avait pu rapprocher sur le terrain les fragments de l'architrave du portique E., n'a transcrit seulement la 1ere partie du texte de la dédicace" (CRAI 1906 p. 167). Several blocks or fragments (indicated by highlighting) have been found again by the NYU expedition. partially published by Mendel, CRAI 1906, 167 , whence cited by Marshall, CR 20, 1906, p. 381; by Boulanger, CRAI 1914, 49, note 2, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 111, 132.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Building dedication of the Eusebian Bath to the Emperors and Aphrodite
entry.summary: White marble panel carrying a moulded tabella ansata (1.51 × 0.85 × 0.25); broken in two pieces and chipped on the moulding, especially down the left side and at the upper left and lower right corners. Inscribed on the face. Date: Not before A.D. 70 (dedication). Photos. Excavated by Boulanger 13 November 1913 (notebook A.79, 26, whence B 33); found again by the NYU expedition in 1984 (84.57). Cited by Robert, from Boulanger's copy, EtAnat 542, n.2, Hellenica I, 51; AntClass 1966 394, n.1, and 416-417, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 151; published by Reynolds, 'The dedication of a Bath Building at Carian Aphrodisias', Studien in honorem Georgii Mihailov, (Sofia, 1997), 397-402, whence SEG 1995.1504, BullEp 1998.382.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication of a caryatid by Attalis
entry.summary: White marble statue base (0.53-0.61 × 0.66 × 0.535) with egg and dart moulding above, and with a hole in the top for the attachment of the statue. Inscribed on the face. Date: Mid second century A.D. (lettering, monument group, prosopography). Photo. Excavated by the Italian expedition; found again by the NYU expedition (SBI 75). published by Jacopi, MonAL 38, 1939, 225, no. 6, whence BullEp 1948.211, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 162.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication of a caryatid by Gaia Tatia Chresteina
entry.summary: A rectangular white marble statue base: 'largeur, 0.61', with moulding above on at least three sides. Lines 1 and 2 inscribed on the two fasciae of the upper moulding, 3 ff. on the face. Date: Second half of second century A.D. (monument group, prosopography). Photos. Excavated by Boulanger, 27 October 1913 (notebook A, 77 no. 19 whence B.34-5, no. 19); found by the NYU expedition in 2002. published, from Boulanger, Robert, Laodicée du Lycos, 317-318, note 8, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 166.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Building dedication to Aphrodite and Hadrian
entry.summary: Fragments of white marble architrave blocks, with a heavy egg and dart moulding above the inscribed face; a-e, g, no measurements; f, 1.75 × 0.30 x depth not measurable; edge survives at right. Inscribed on two fasciae. Date: A.D. 117/138 (reign). Photos. f copied by Kubitschek (K iii. facing 1); g recorded by Gaudin (126); a-e excavated by Mendel in 1905 (notebook A.5). a-c, and fragments of d and g recorded by the NYU expedition. a-e published by Mendel, CRAI 1906, 171-172; f published by Cormack, from K&R, ABSA 59, 1964, 16, no. 1, whence Robert, AC 35, 1966, 391, BE 1967.548, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 114; g published by Reinach, 134, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 127.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: i. Honours for Marcus Antonius Popillius Andronikos; ii. Fl. Photios gives a gameboard
entry.summary: A rectangular white marble statue base shaft (0.57 × 1.20 × 0.55) with panels within moulded edges on all four sides; the upper left corner of face i., including most of text ii., has been broken off, but survives. i. Inscribed on the front panel; the text must have begun on a crowning feature now lost. ii. On the opposite face, upside down to i., is a gameboard (type 3Rows.4, 0.47 × 0.97, carefully cut, with circles 0.03, central rosettes in circles 0.085); the text is on the lower moulding, which is now broken away. Date: i. Probably late second to third centuries A.D. (lettering); ii. Late fifth/sixth century (titulature). Photos. Recorded, complete, by Gaudin (i. 111, ii. 109); by the NYU expedition in two fragments. i. Published from Gaudin's squeeze by Reinach, 71, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 71; cited from Reinach by Oikonomos, Arch Delt 1921/22, 294. ii. Published by Reinach, no. 213, from Gaudin, whence Grégoire, IGC 264; cited by Roueché (1979), 176, ad no. 1, whence SEG 1979.1071, BE 1980.473; published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 68 and plate xvii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 622; republished by Roueché , Gameboards, no. 2.i.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Place inscription of Epiktetos, cloakroom-attendant
entry.summary: A white marble revetment panel, re-used in the flooring of the baths. In its present position the inscription is difficult to see, and l.6 is truncated. Date: Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 190 whence PHI 675.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: i. Fragment of verse. ii. Place inscription of Synodios
entry.summary: A white marble base capital fragment, with moulding on three sides, smooth surface on fourth. Broken at one side. (0.35 × 0.49 × 0.69). i: Inscribed on the smooth face; ii: Inscribed upside down on lower moulding of central moulded side (so secondary use) opposite 233 (and the other way up). Date: i: Fourth to sixth century (lettering, metre); ii; later than i. Photos. First found by Mendel; recorded by Boulanger, 15 October 1913 (notebook A, 67 no. 3, whence B, 3); recorded by the NYU expedition in September 1988. Published by Grégoire IGC 278, from Mendel, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 646; republished by Roueché (2004), 233.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: -getos, exceptor, gives a gameboard
entry.summary: A white marble rectangular block (1.58 × 0.57 × 0.43) with a recessed panel on one face. The panel is inscribed with a gameboard, type 3Rows.4, and the text is cut on the upper rim. Date: Fifth/sixth century (titulature). Photos. Excavated by Boulanger, 15 October 1913 (notebook A, 69 no. 5, whence B, 39, 5); recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 70 and plate xvii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 624; republished by Roueché, Gameboards, no. 3.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fl. Photios gives a gameboard
entry.summary: A rectangular white marble statue base (1.14 × 0.57 × 0.44) with moulded edge above and below on three sides. Inscribed on central panel with a board, type 3Rows.4, (0.45 × 1.00) carefully cut: circles 0.03, central rosettes in circles 0.10; the text is inscribed on the lower moulding. Date: Late fifth/sixth century (titulature). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché (1979), no. 1, whence BE 1980.473; republished by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 69 and plate xvi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 623; republished by Roueché, Gameboards, no. 2.ii.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Flavius Photios gives a gameboard
entry.summary: A plain white marble statue base shaft (0.54 × 1.25 × 0.55), complete above and broken below. The right side was hollowed out, to create a recessed panel. The text is on the lower edge of a gameboard (type 3Rows.4, 0.43 × 0.97, carefully cut, circles 0.03, central rosettes in circle 0.10), within the recessed panel on the right side; the text is cut level with the top of a second text (not yet published) on the adjacent side. Date: Late fifth/sixth century (titulature). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1988 (88.9; SBI 42). Published by Roueché, Gameboards 2.iii; republished by Roueché (2004), 238.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: First honours for Rhodopaios, in verse
entry.summary: A rectangular statue base shaft, without moulding, of bluish marble, chipped at upper right corner, and broken in two (1.53 × 0.50 × 0.37). The inscription is laid out with unusual elegance: the epigram itself is cut within a decorative margin, and each couplet is inscribed in four lines (five for the third) with each line starting slightly to the right of the one above, but returning to the margin at the start of the next couplet. Date: Sixth century (prosopography). Photos. Excavated by Boulanger, 16 October 1913 (notebook A, 69 no. 6, whence B, 31, no. 6; recorded by J. and L. Robert; recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by L. Robert, Hellenica 4, 127 and plate vii, from Boulanger and his own copy, whence BE 1949.178, BE 1972.473; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 85 and plate xxi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 727, Steinepigramme 02/09/22.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Second honours for Rhodopaios
entry.summary: A white marble columnar statue base shaft, broken above, and with the surface lost at the left edge of the text (ll. 1.13, diam. 0.44). Inscribed on the face. Date: Sixth century (prosopography). Photos. Recorded by Gaudin (90); by the NYU expedition. Published from Gaudin by Reinach, no. 75, whence Robert, Hellenica 4, 127-128, BE 1949.178; discussed by Roueché (1979), 182; published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 86 and plate xxii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 671.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Eugenios is honoured by the boule
entry.summary: A white marble statue base shaft (1.48 × 0.535 × 0.41with a central recessed panel. Inscribed on the central, recessed face. Date: Sixth century (lettering). Photos. Excavated by Boulanger, 30 October 1913 (notebook A, 78, no. 22, whence B, 39 no. 22); recorded by J. and L. Robert; by the NYU expedition. Published from Boulanger's copy and his own by L. Robert, Hellenica 4, 133 and plate v, whence BE 1949.178; discussed by T. Drew-Bear, REA 82, (1980), 163; published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 88, and plate xxiii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 719, Steinepigramme 02/09/10.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Ioannes undertakes restoration works in the Hadrianic Baths
entry.summary: Several fragments, some joining, from a series of white marble revetment panels, 0.36 high. Inscribed in one line. Date: Fourth to sixth centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition (Baths 11). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 48, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 597.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Building works in the Hadrianic Baths
entry.summary: A fragment of white marble revetment panel with upper and lower edges (0.26 × 0.21 × 0.04); there are traces of cement on the face from subsequent re-use. Inscribed in two lines on the face. Date: Fourth/fifth/sixth century (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1963 (63.356). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 49 and plate xii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 598.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Flavius undertakes building works in the Hadrianic Baths
entry.summary: A white marble revetment panel (0.30 × 0.41) with only lower edge surviving. Inscribed in one line on the face. Date: Fourth/fifth/sixth century (lettering, nomenclature). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 50 and plate xii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 599.

entry.title: Flavius E undertakes building works in the Hadrianic Baths
entry.summary: A fragment of white marble revetment panelling, with only lower edge surviving (1.40 × 0.31. Inscribed in one line on the face. Date: Fourth/fifth/sixth century (lettering, nomenclature). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 51, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 600.

entry.title: Restoration work in the Hadrianic Baths
entry.summary: White marble revetment panelling: a, a complete panel, with lower edge missing (0.37 × 1.97 × 0.03), b, a fragment, broken at both ends (0.79 × 0.445). Inscribed on the face in one line. Date: Fourth/fifth/sixth century (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 52, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 601.

entry.title: Acclamations for imperial family, and a New Theodosius
entry.summary: Fragments of fresco on wall plaster. The original design appears to have been a series of circular garlands of green leaves, outlined inside and outside with a sold band; The fragments come from at least three such garlands; fragment iv may well come from the same text as fragment iii. The lettering is inscribed inside the garlands, in red on a white background. Date: A.D. 583 or A.D. 491 - 518 (emperors). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1962, removed in 1966-7: 67.102 and 69.473 (together, 61.i), 69.471 (61.ii), 69.470 (61.iii). 69.472 (61.iv). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 61.i-iv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 843, 844, 628 and 894.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Gaius Julius Zoilos
entry.summary: White marble block, broken. Inscribed on one face. Date: Augustan (lettering, prosopography). Recorded by Gaudin (110); not reported subsequently. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 127-128, no. 54, whence R. Vagts, 35, n.8, Giuliano, ASAA 27-28, 1959-1960, 392, Robert, AC 35, 1966, 414, discussed by S. Weinstock, Divus Julius (Oxford, 1971), 140 ff. Published by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 33, whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.388, AnnEpig 1984.878, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 284, Smith, Monument, T.6.

entry.title: Warning against theft from the Baths
entry.summary: Large white marble block without moulding (0.815 × 0.61 × 0.59), with right side and bottom edge surviving; an adjoining fragment to the left was seen in 1967. There are clamp holes from later use on the face. Inscribed on the face. Date: Hellenistic (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Baths 1). Unpublished.

entry.summary: White marble statue base shaft with moulding below (0.50 × 1.12 × 0.54). Inscribed on the face. Date: First to second centuries A.D. (nomenclature, lettering). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (7); recorded by Mendel/Boulanger (notebook A 41, no.2); found again by the NYU expedition (SBI 135). Published by Reinach, 19, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 158.

entry.summary: White marble statue base shaft with moulding above and below (0.545 × 1.08 × 0.53). Inscribed on the face?. Date: First to second centuries A.D. (nomenclature, lettering). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (152); found again by the NYU expedition (SBI 136). Published by Reinach, 20, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 159.

entry.title: Fragment, stray
entry.summary: Fragment from a panel, without edges; (0.13 x 0.135 × 0.038). Inscribed on the face. Date: Probably first century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1994 (94.32). Unpublished.

entry.summary: Piece from the bottom of a white marble block, without back or other edges (0.27 × 0.14 × 0.14). Inscribed on a surface which is partly eroded. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Found by the NYU expedition in 1966 (66.246). Unpublished.

entry.title: Votive offering to Asklepios by Amias
entry.summary: Rectangular white marble panel/votive relief with round-headed projection above (0.17 × 0.145 × 0.04). Inscribed on one face on the projection with one line impinging on the block below, which carries a relief of two breasts. Date: Perhaps second century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1963 (63.568). Unpublished.

entry.summary: White marble? statue base fragment without back or edges (0.07 × 0.22 × 0.10). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1967 (67.17). Unpublished.

entry.summary: White marble fragmentpossibly with a left edge (0.31 × 0.095 × 0.105). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1967 (67.490). Unpublished.

entry.title: Fragment from Hadrianic Baths
entry.summary: White marble fragment, perhaps from a statue base, without back or edges (no measurements). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition (Baths 8). Unpublished.

entry.title: Honours for Marcus
entry.summary: Upper left corner of a white marble statue base 0.30 × 0.26 × 0.26. Inscribed within a moulded panel (die, surviving, 0.18 x0.13); there was a similar but uninscribed panel on the left face. Date: Second-third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition (65.208). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Votive offering to Asklepios
entry.summary: White marble panel/Votive relief, approximately square (0.155 × 0.14 × 0.06). Inscribed on one face, in a rectangular area above a relief of two breasts. Date: Third century A.D. Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1963 (63.570). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Building inscription of Helladios
entry.summary: A rectangular white marble block, perhaps from a lintel (0.285 × 0.665 × 0.50) with simple moulding above and below on one face. Chipped to the right, but complete. Inscribed on the moulded face, in one line on the surface between the mouldings, which is slightly concave. The text must have continued onto an adjacent block. Date: First half of the fourth century (lettering, prosopography). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity, no. 18, whence PHI 605.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication by Flavius Palladios
entry.summary: Fragment of white marble cornice or perhaps column capital, with a face between simple upper and lower moulding, and moulding on the underside. Broken at both sides. Inscribed on the face. Date: First half of the fourth century (lettering, formulae). Photo. Excavated by Boulanger, 15 October 1913 (notebook A 67, no.2, whence B 38-9, no. 2); recorded by the NYU expedition in 1988 (88.13). Published, from Roueché's copy, by Erim and Reynolds (1991), no. 16 and plate, whence SEG 1990.939; republished by Roueché (2004), 252.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Verse honours for Eupeithios
entry.summary: A rectangular white marble statue base shaft with panels within moulded edges on three sides (0.97 × 0.485 × 0.38). Inscribed on the central panel. Date: Mid to late fourth century (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1966 (66.542; SBI 4). The plinth of the accompanying statue, with a fragment of a foot and the edge of a chlamys was found with the base. . Published by I. Ševcenko, Synthronon (1968), 38 n. 55, whence BE 1969.543; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 33 and plate ix, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 720, Steinepigramme 02/09/11.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Verse honours for Menandros, vicar
entry.summary: A bluish marble columnar statue base shaft, broken below (height 1.45. diam. 0.55). Inscribed on the face. Date: A.D. 385/388 (prosopography). Photos. Excavated by the French expedition in 1905, and copied by A. Boulanger in 1913 (notebook A, 49 no. 1, whence B, 10-11, no. 9); copied by J. and L. Robert in 1946; recorded by the NYU expedition. Published from his own copy and from Boulanger, by L. Robert, Hellenica 4, 133-5 and plate vi, whence BE 1949.178; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 24 and Plate vii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 723, Steinepigramme 02/09/16.

entry.title: Donor prayer from a church
entry.summary: White marble fragment (0.28 × 0.08 × 0.07), from the crowning feature of a balustrade; the top is smooth; one side has a moulded profile, the other is smooth and vertical. The underside has been left rough. Resembles 1.12, 1.13, 1.14, 1.15, 1.16, 1.192, 15.359. Inscribed in one line on upper fascia of moulded profile. Date: Fifth/sixth century or later (lettering, content). Photos. Recorded by the NYU excavation in 1994 (94.33). Published by Roueché (2004), 240.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Column dedication to Patris by Attalos Andron son of Peritas
entry.summary: White marble column base. None. Date: First to second centuries A.D. (nomenclature, context). Excavated by Boulanger in 1913 (21 October: Boulanger notebook A, 74 no 14, whence B 21, no. 27; C, no.5); not reported subsequently. Published from Boulanger's notes by Haussoullier, RPh 44, 1920, 74, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 133.

entry.title: Column dedication to Demos
entry.summary: Fragment, broken at both sides, of a simple white marble moulding or column base (0.21 × 0.135 × 0.175) with one simple fascia. Inscribed in two lines on the fascia. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Found by Boulanger, 5 November 1913 (notebook A 78, 25, whence B.21, 28, C5, 6). Found by the NYU expedition among the old museum holdings, with an early museum inventory number (Museum 154). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment, from caryatid dedication
entry.summary: Fragment from the left side of a white marble statue base without moulding; no back or edges (0.23 × 0.09 × 0.105). Inscribed on the face. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1990, 1990.F.57 (90.p). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: i. Honours for Pyrron son of Itharos; ii. Verse honours for Hermias, benefactor
entry.summary: A rectangular white marble statue base shaft (0.56 × 1.24 × 0.50) with panels within moulded edges on all four sides. Cut on opposite faces within the panels (1.08 × 0.46); the upper edge is complete, although the right side of i. (= left side of ii.) is broken away. Text i. must have begun on a crowning feature. Date: i. Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering); ii. Late fifth/sixth century (language, lettering). Photos. Excavated by Mendel in 1905; recorded by Boulanger (notebook A, 58 no. 15 & 59 no. 16, whence B, 7, no. 6 & 9, no. 7); recorded by J. and L. Robert; recorded by the NYU expedition (Baths 4, SBI 137a). i. (lines 1-17) from Boulanger's copy by L. Robert, Etudes Anatoliennes (Paris, 1937), 299, n. 2, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 275 . ii. Published by Grégoire, IGC 277, from Mendel; by Robert, Hellenica 4, 130 and plate, whence BE 1949.178; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 74 and plate xviii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 705, Steinepigramme 02/09/15.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Column dedication to Demos
entry.summary: Two blue marble columns; i. 0.48, 1.13. i. inscribed at about 0.06 above moulding. Date: Second century A.D. (monument, lettering). Photos. Mendel copied i and referred to ii (notebook A, 7, b; C, 9); the NYU expedition rediscovered i in 1988. Published by Mendel CRAI 1906, 172-173, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 130 & 131.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Column dedication to Demos by Menippos Kodios and Papianos Kodios
entry.summary: White marble column bases, inscribed on a square face; i. (0.59 × 0.09) is chipped along the upper and lower edges and broken away to the right; ii. no measurements. Inscribed on the square face of each base. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. i and ii excavated by the French in 1913 (i: 22 October: Boulanger notebook A, 74 no 16, whence B 21, no. 25; ii: 20 October: Boulanger notebook A, 74 no 13, notebook B 21, no. 27); i recorded by the Italian Mission in 1937, and by the NYU expedition in 1973. i published by Jacopi, MonAnt 38, 1939, 227, no. 8, whence BE 1948.211, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 91.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Building dedication to Aphrodite and Hadrian by Pereitas Attalos
entry.summary: White marble lintel block, slightly damaged at right end (2.16), with egg and dart moulding above three fasciae. Inscribed in one line on all three fasciae (heights 0.09, 0.08, 0.06). Date: A.D. 117-138 (reign). Photo. Excavated by Mendel in 1905; copied by Boulanger (notebook A, p.3); recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Mendel, CRAI 1906, 168a note 1, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 112 ; mentioned by Wilhelm, Jahreshefte 1933, 55-61, 56.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Building dedication to Aphrodite and Hadrian by Pereitas Attalos
entry.summary: White marble lintel block, with egg and dart moulding above three fasciae, now broken into two fragments. Inscribed on all three fasciae, two lines on the upper fascia and one each on the lower two. Date: A.D. 117-138 (reign). Photos. Excavated by Mendel in 1905; copied by Boulanger (notebook A, p.3); recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Mendel, CRAI 1906, 168 note 1b, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 113 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication of a caryatid by Claudia Seleukeia
entry.summary: White marble statue base; probably with egg and dart moulding above. Inscribed on the face. Date: Mid second century A.D. (lettering, monument group, prosopography). Recorded by Gaudin (151); transcribed from Reinach by Boulanger (notebook A 41, no.28); not reported subsequently. Published from Gaudin by Reinach, 28, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 161.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication of a caryatid by Julia Paula, with sculptor's signature
entry.summary: White marble statue base with egg and dart moulding on three sides (0.645 × 0.75 × 0.59). Inscribed on the face (i) and on the right side (ii). Date: Mid second century A.D. (lettering, monument group, prosopography). Photos. Recorded by Gaudin (115); transcribed from Reinach by Boulanger (notebook A, 45 no.7); recorded by the NYU expedition (SBI 168). Published from Gaudin by Reinach, 69, whence Squarciapino no. 2, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 280. Published by Erim and Reynolds, Sculptors, no. 3, whence SEG 1990.926.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication of a caryatid by Claudia Apphia Chaeremonis.
entry.summary: White marble statue base (0.635 × 0.625 × 0.565) with egg and dart moulding above on three sides; the left side has been hollowed out for later re-use. Inscribed on the face. Date: Mid second century A.D. (lettering, monument group, prosopography). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (89); transcribed from Reinach by Boulanger (notebook A 43, no. 6); found again in 1971 by the NYU expedition (SBI 145). Published by Reinach, from Gaudin, 37, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 291.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication of a caryatid by Flavia Attalis Aeliane.
entry.summary: White marble statue base (0.65, 0.485), with moulding above. Inscribed on moulding (l. 1) and on face (ll. 2 ff.). Date: Second half of second century A.D. (lettering, monument group, prosopography). Photo. Recorded by Boulanger, 30 October 1913 (Notebook A.77, no.21, whence B, 35, no. 21); not reported subsequenly. Published by J. M. Reynolds, A new inscription from Carian Aphrodisias, in P. McKechnie ed., Thinking Like a Lawyer, Essays for John Crook (Leiden, 2002), 247-251.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication of a caryatid by a Daughter of the City
entry.summary: White marble statue base (0.45 × 0.63 × 0.55), with simple moulding above, which is badly damaged. Inscribed on the face. The text must have begun on the moulding. Date: Second half of second century A.D. (lettering, monument group, prosopography). Photo. Copied by Kubitschek (K III, facing 1) and by Boulanger (Not in A; B15, 22bis); recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, 455, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 170.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Aurelius Achilles
entry.summary: A plain statue base shaft (1.28 x 0.55 x 0.53) without moulding, chipped at edges but complete above and below. Inscribed on two adjoining faces, i to the right, ii to the left. The text of i must have begun on a crowning feature; so perhaps did that of ii. Date: Third century (after 212) (nomenclature). Photos. Excavated by Boulanger, 26 October 1913 (notebook A, 75-6, no. 18, whence B 25-29, no. 18); recorded by the NYU expedition. i. published by L. Robert, from Boulanger, Anatolian Studies Buckler (Manchester, 1939), 230-44 (= OMS I, 614-28), whence republished by R. Merkelbach, ZPE 14 (1974), 91-4, and H. Wankel, I.Eph. I, 12. i and ii published by C. P. Jones 'Two inscriptions from Aphrodisias', HSCP 85 (1981), 107-29; from this i has been reprinted as SEG 1981.903, and ii, with the comments of R. Merkelbach, ZPE 49 (1982), 282-3, and J. Ebert, Stadion 7 (1981), 203-10, as SEG 1981.904; further comments Bull Ép. 1984.410 & 1984.411, whence SEG 1984.1045, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 11.. Published from all these, with further comments from Jones, Roueché, PPA 72, whence ii published by Merkelbach and Staufer, Steinepigramme 02/09/27.

entry.title: Honours for a comes
entry.summary: White marble statue base shaft, with moulded panels on all four sides (0.60 × 1.35 × 0.54); broken above, and at the right. Standing on a plinth. Inscribed within front panel. Date: First half fourth century A.D. (lettering, titulature). Photos. Excavated by Mendel in 1905, copied by Boulanger (Notebook A 55, no. 10, whence B 4-5, no. 5); recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 14, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 664.

entry.title: Honours for Aelia Flaccilla
entry.summary: A white marble columnar statue base shaft (H. approx 1.30, diam. 0.55), broken in two. Inscribed on the face: the surface is chipped (as it already was in 1904) at the upper left corner of the inscription. Date: A.D. 383-386 (prosopography, titulature). Photos. Recorded by Gaudin (104) and noted by Boulanger (Notebook A, 43); the stone appears subsequently to have broken into two fragments, of which the lower was recorded by J. and L. Robert in 1946. Both fragments were recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Reinach, 30, from Gaudin, whence IGC 280, ILS 9466; by L. Robert, Hellenica 4, 14 and plate v; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity 23 and Plate vi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 659.

entry.title: Fl. Eutolmius Tatianos honours Honorius
entry.summary: A white marble columnar statue base shaft (H. 1.31, diam. 0.59), broken above. Inscribed on the face. Date: A.D. 388-392 (emperor, prosopography). Photos. Recorded by Gaudin (11); by Boulanger, Notebook A, 43; by J. and L. Robert in 1946 and 1947; by the NYU expedition. Published by Reinach, 31, from Gaudin's squeeze, whence Grégoire, IGC 281 and in Anatolian Studies Ramsay (Manchester, 1923), 151-154, whence SEG 1930.398. Discussed Grégoire, Byzantion 4, 1928, 342; published by Robert, Hellenica 4, 49-50 and plate iv, whence BE 1949.178; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity 25 and Plate vii whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 660.

entry.title: Tatianos, governor, restores the statue of Tatianos, PPO; verse
entry.summary: A white marble rectangular statue base shaft (1.18 × 0.60 × 0.48) with panels within moulded edges on three sides. Inscribed on the central panel; last letter in l. 15 cut on right moulding. Date: First half of the fifth century A.D. (prosopography). Photos. Excavated by Mendel in 1905; recorded by Boulanger (notebook A, 59, no. 17, whence B, 9, no. 10); recorded by J. and L. Robert in 1946, Found by the current expedition standing in the same position. Published from Boulanger and his own copy by Robert, Hellenica 4, 47-53, and plate vii, whence BE 1949.178; Discussed by W. Peek in Wiss. zu Univ. Halle 4 (1954-5), 217-18, whence SEG 1958.661, and by R. Merkelbach in ZPE 6 (1970), 132, whence BE 1971.616; published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 37 and plate x, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 725, Steinepigramme 02/09/24. Discussed by E. Livrea, 'I de Taziani in un'iscrizione di Afrodisia', ZPE 119 (1997), 43-49, with D.Feissel, BE 1998.646, SEG 1997.1555.

entry.title: Dionysios, doctor, undertakes building works in the Hadrianic Baths
entry.summary: Five fragments (two joining) from a white marble architrave with sculptural decoration and egg and dart moulding above three stepped fasciae of diminishing height; there is a decorative panel on the underside. Measurements: a: complete block, 0.48 × 2.86 × 0.62. b: two joining fragments, 0.47 × 1.20 × 0.62 and 0.52 × 0.38 × 0.45. c: two joining fragments, 0.49 × 1.90 × 0.98. d: 0.47 × 0.22 × 0.24; e: 0.43 × 0.52 × 0.25. This is probably part of the same architectural feature as 5.303, but inscribed in only one line, on the upper fascia (H. 0.14). Date: Fifth century A.D. (lettering). Photos. a copied by Mendel; a-c by Boulanger (Notebook A, 9); by the NYU expedition (the second fragment of b in 1988, d and e in 1989). a published by Grégoire, IGC 272 (part), from Mendel; a, b and c published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 67 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 626.

entry.title: Statue dedication by Flavius Zenon
entry.summary: A white marble columnar statue base shaft (1.67, diam. 0.48) with a moulded upper rim; the stone is badly weathered, and partly broken away above. Inscribed very lightly on the upper part of the column. Date: c. A.D. 324-350 (lettering, content). Photos. Excavated by Boulanger, 16 October 1913 (notebook A, 71, whence B, 37); recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Erim and Roueché (1982), no. 1, whence SEG 1982.1105, BE 1984.405, SEG 1985.1082; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 11 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 167; by Erim and Reynolds (1991), no. 15a, whence SEG 1990.938.

entry.title: Dedication (post mortem) by Flavius Zenon
entry.summary: A white marble masonry block, without features (0.56 × 0.30 × 0.56). Inscribed on one face. Date: c. A.D. 324-350 (lettering, content). Photos. Excavated by Mendel in 1905 (Boulanger notebook A, 55; whence B 3); recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Erim & Roueché, PBSR 50, 1982, 103-104, no. 2 whence SEG 1982.1106, BE 1984.405, SEG 1985.1082; published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 12, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 168; by Erim and Reynolds (1991), no. 15b, whence SEG 1990.938.

entry.title: Building inscription of Pytheas, in verse
entry.summary: Three fragments, not joining, from an white marble architrave with decoration (which is broken away) above three stepped fasciae, diminishing in height; a and c: not measured; b: 0.52 × 1.37 × 0.54. Inscribed on the upper two fasciae. Date: Late fifth century (prosopography). Photos. a and b excavated by Boulanger, 1 November 1913 (notebook A, 78, 23 and 24, whence B 23, 29); a, b and c recorded by the NYU expedition, c in 1989. a and b published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 58 and plate xiv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 708, Steinepigramme 02/09/20.

entry.title: Titles for relief sculptures
entry.summary: Three white marble relief panels, their subjects described and discussed by Yildirim in Ratté (Basilica of Aphrodisias, forthcoming). Beside the figures. Date: probably Flavian (lettering, sculpture, probable text). When the panels were first found, many thought the reliεfs to be of the third century A.D., a view abandoned after their detailed study. Yildirim, however, still regards the lettering as post-Flavian; it is indeed not quite standard in form for the Flavian period, but it is often the case that the lettering of captions is not quite standard for their period, since they were cut, commonly, by the sculptors rather than by professional letterers. Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1978. Published by Erim, Aphrodisias (London, 1986), 26-7, 99-101.; id, Aphrodisias, a guide to the site (Izmir, 1989), 49-51; Reynolds, in Ratté (Basilica of Aphrodisias, forthcoming). Note, among many published comments, R. R. R. Smith in Aphrodisias Papers 3, 10-72; L. Robert, À Travers l'Asie Mineure (Paris, 1980), C.P. Jones, Kinship Diplomacy in the Ancient World (Harvard, 1999), 139-43; Yildirim, and Stinson, in Ratté (Basilica of Aphrodisias, forthcoming); and the articles on Bellerophon, Gordios, Ninos, Semiramis in LIMC.

entry.title: Building dedication for Titus
entry.summary: Fifteen fragments from blocks of a white marble architrave, with a simple moulding above and three fasciae. When complete, average height 0.495, 0.765. a & b. two adjoining fragments, with upper and lower edges surviving. (a: left edge survives, 1.02 × 0.51 × 0.69; b: 1.08 × 0.515 × 0.73). c. complete block (1.73 × 0.48 × 0.69); . Fragments:d. without edges (0.38 × 0.31 × 0.31); e. with upper moulding surviving, no other edges. f. without edges (0.41 × 0.22 × 0.20);g. with upper moulding and right edge (0.09 × 0.31 × 0.32); h. without edges (0.30 × 0.20 × 0.23); i. with right edge (0.50 × 0.30 × 0.45); k. without edges (0.27 × 0.25 × 0.08); l, complete to left (0.13, 0.385); m: broken at both ends (0.80, 0.13); n, complete to left; o: complete to left; p. complete to right (0.50, 1.03, 0.55). Inscribed on the upper of three fasciae, average 0.0145; there is a simple moulding above the upper fascia. Date: Flavian, A.D. 79-96 (probable reign, architecture, lettering). Photos. l and p recorded by Kubitschek (K.iii.26); a-k excavated by the NYU expedition in 1977 and 1978 (Portico 11); l, m, n and o recorded by Reynolds. l and m published from K's notebook by Cormack, ABSA no. 12; others unpublished. ished.

entry.title: Basilica, gameboard
entry.summary: White marble paving slab, broken into several pieces. Inscribed on the face of the paving. Date: Second to sixth centuries A.D. (context). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Gameboards 15.

entry.title: Building inscription by Fl. Constantius, governor
entry.summary: Black and white floor mosaic. Set within Tabella ansata (0.47 × 1.42), which is broken away to left. Date: A.D. 365/370 (prosopography). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1988 (88.21). Published by K. T. Erim, Aphrodisias Papers 27, p. 28 whence SEG 1996.1398, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 609, cited Anatolian Studies 39 (1989), 175-7, 177, whence BE 1989.138, 1989.517; republished by Roueché (2004), 235.

entry.title: Verse honours for Ioannes, governor of Caria
entry.summary: Four fragments, none joining, from an white marble architrave, with a single fascia (0.10). There is one line of carved decoration below this fascia; above it is an egg and dart moulding, and above that a panel of scroll decoration. a: 0.635 × 2.42 × 0.65; decoration survives above and below, the right end is complete and so, probably, is the left. b: 0.29 × 1.28 × 0.24; broken both ends, decoration broken away above. c: 0.23 × 0.64 × 0.48; broken both ends; decoration above still buried; underside revealed with a decorative panel. d: 0.33 × 0.86 × 0.22; broken at both ends; decoration broken away above. Inscribed in one line on the fascia, which shows traces (on a) of an earlier, erased inscription. Date: Fifth century (lettering; titulature). Photos. d copied by Reichel (RI.28); a and b recorded by the MAMA expedition. a, b and c recorded by the NYU expedition. a and b published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, 429 and 604, whence a discussed by Robert, Hellenica 13, 158, BE 1966.394; d published by Cormack, from Reichel, Cormack (1964), 40; a - d published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 45 and plate xi (a and b), whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 706, Steinepigramme 02/09/95.

entry.title: Dedicatory poem
entry.summary: Four fragments, two of which join, from a series of long, slightly concave white marble cornice blocks. a., two joining fragments, with left edge surviving, 0.76, 0.355; b., apparently a complete block, 0.535, 0.39; c., complete at right, perhaps at left, 0.485, 0.36. Inscribed in one line along the slightly concave edge (0.16). Date: Sixth century A.D., or later. Photos. c copied by Kubitschek (K.V.6) and by Reichel (R.I.30) and by the MAMA expedition; b recorded by Gaudin (69); a, b and c recorded by the NYU expedition in 1961, 1962 and 1969 (a: 62.437, c: 69.360). b. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin, no. 207, whence IGC 263 and, from Reichel, 264bis; c. published from the MAMA records by Cormack, MAMA 8, no. 603; all published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 100 and plate xxvi, whence discussion by Feissel (1991), 372, n.25, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 709, Steinepigramme 02/09/97.

entry.title: Monogram capitals from the Triconch Church
entry.summary: Four matching white marble column capitals. On each of the capitals, one side (back) is left plain, and there are crosses on either side. They all show signs of having been re-used subsequently. Inscribed on the face of each capital. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries (monogram). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition. An inferior account published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 101 and plate xxvii, whence PHI 614-7.

entry.title: i. Building dedication to Aphrodite and Demos; ii. Invocation to Ourania; iii. Acclamation for the City
entry.summary: Thirteen fragments or complete blocks making up ten blocks of a white marble combined architrave and frieze (normal blocks 1.95 × 0.58 × 0.50; block over central door 2.66 wide. Two blocks re-used with inscriptions and moulding on the rear. i. Inscribed in one line on the frieze. ii. Painted in red, on a white background. iii. inscribed on the face below the moulding. Date: i. 28 B.C. (prosopography); ii. & iii. First – sixth century A.D. (context). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition (Block 8 71.164b; Block 10 71.172). i. Mentioned, BE 1971.609; published by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 36a, whence Orth, EA 3, 1984, 63, SEG 32, 1982.1097, BE 1983.388, An.Ép. 1984.878, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 92, Smith, Monument, T2. ii. Published by Roueché, PPA 2; iii. by Roueché, PPA 3.

entry.title: Letter of Quintus Oppius
entry.summary: Pilaster (0.66 x 0.81) inscribed on two faces. The west face has been damaged above and on all edges, and is pierced by a round hole near the left edge towards the top. It is in two planes, one stepped back from the other, and bears 503b; the north face bears 8.24. Pilaster capital (0.27 x 0.98 x 0.27) with heavy moulding above the face. a. inscribed on the face of the capital; b. inscribed on the pilaster, one column on each of the stepped faces. Date: Document: 85 B.C. (prosopography, content); inscription second century A.D. (lettering, context). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (67.549 & 67.550). Published by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 3, whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.364, AnnEpig 1984.859; discussed by Bowersock, Gnomon 56 (1984), 51 (l. 24), whence SEG 1984.1043; by Jones, AJP 106 (1985), 264 (ll. 33a-35), whence SEG 1985.1081 from all of these McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 63 .

entry.title: Decree of Plarasa/Aphrodisias
entry.summary: Two white marble blocks (together 3.06 × 0.59 × 0.43) from a Doric entablature with architrave and frieze in one piece; block a. is chipped at both sides, block b. is broken in two. Inscribed a on one metope and b on the frieze. The decree is laid out in two columns. Date: Document: 88 B.C. (prosopography, events). Inscription: Second century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU excavation (67.749, 68.399, 70.406). Published by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 2, whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.363, AnnEpig 1984.858, SEG 1984.1043, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 28.

entry.title: Letter of Nikomedes IV
entry.summary: Left-hand face of the white marble pilaster which carries 8.2 on its front face. The upper course consisted of one block; the top, badly chipped, and the left hand side survive (0.625 x 0.67 x 0.83), together with nine further fragments. The lower course, which includes the dado, consisted of two adjacent blocks; at least 10 fragments survive. Date: Document; text: Second to third centuries A.D. Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition; the main block in situ (67.552) the remaining fragments over several years (67.311 , 67.451 , 67.452 , 67.456 , 67.457 , 67.458 , 67.460 , 67.469 , 67.470 , 67.490 , 67.526 , 67.552 , 69.312 , 69.372 , 69.451 , 76.11 , 76.12 , 76.196.2 , 76.196.12). Published by Reynolds, A&R 4 whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.365; discussed, with emendations, Jones, EMC 29, 1985, 309-317 (lines 1, 2, 4, 18, 20-21, 24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 30-31), whence SEG 1985.1083 ; from all these McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 36 .

(lettering, context). Document : 39/38 B.C. (content). Photo. Recorded by Sherard in 1705 (10101, 38-39), with further corrections (S.2); fragment recorded by the NYU expedition in 1972 (72.487). entry.title: Triumviral decree
entry.summary: Seven fragments of white marble blocks from the archive wall: column 1, lowest register. a (0.97 x 1.06 including the dado, x depth not measurable) damaged at the left side. b reassembled from three pieces (0.81 x 1.06 including the dado x 0.40). c two small fragments fitting onto the damaged surface of b. d. fragment of a block (0.81 x 0.29 x 0.55). Inscribed immediately above the dado. a contains the right ends of the lines. b contains the left ends of ll.3-11. c contains parts of ll.3-11. d contains part of l.1, below part of document 508, ll.90-95. Date: Inscription: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, context). Document, 39/38 B.C. (prosopography). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition, a in 1967; b, c and d in 1975 (inventory numbers, c 75.187, d 75.141). Published by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 7whence BE 1983.369, AnnEpig 1984, 861, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 74 .
