entry.title: Senatus consultum de Aphrodisiensibus
entry.summary: White marble blocks, and fragments from the North Parodos wall of the Theatre. Inscribed on the first surviving column on the archive wall (inscribed area in situ, five courses, 1.41 x 2.36); the remainder of the text is on loose blocks, A-F, and fragments. These three additional courses took the area covered by the inscription to a height of c. 3 40 m (-= eight courses) and included a heading for this document, but it is possible that a heading for the whole series of texts on the wall was cut on a yet higher block. The width of the inscribed column can be calculated as c. 2.96 m. There is outspacing at the beginning of paragraphs, and variation in line-length is very marked ; apart from the outspacing, reasons for it are that some lines are extended a little beyond the norm at the right end, that ligatures are common, that stops or blank spaces (of varying width) occur from time to time and occasionally wider spacing of letters in words which are to be emphasized, e.g. the names of the triumvirs in l.26. In l. 14 part of ΟΣ is cut on an inset piece of marble. Date: Inscription: second to third centuries (lettering, context). Document: 39/38 B.C. (content, prosopography). Photos. Block A (ll. 46-62) recorded by Sherard in 1705; the upper left hand corner recorded by Gaudin (36, not recorded subsequently). Block B (which adjoined A) recorded by the NYU expedition in 1975, with a further fragment (75.141). Block C recorded by Loew in 1841; by Gaudin (143); recorded by the NYU expedition in 1976 with a further fragment (76.28). Blocks D, E and F from the three courses above those in situ, recorded by the NYU expedition in 1969-70 (70.246 + 69.313 + 69.482; 70.249, 70.251). Part noted by Reichel, R.1.25v . Block A: published by Chishull, from Sherard, Antiquitates Asiae (1728), 150 f, by Boeckh, from Sherard papers, CIG 2737.b, whence Texier, As. Min. iii 155; by Reinach, from Gaudin, 16; Block C: Franz, from Loew, Ann. d. Inst. 19, 1847, 113 no. b.5; by Waddington. LBW 1627; by Reinach, from Gaudin, 1; by Cormack, from the MAMA exedition, MAMA 8, no. 405. From these Viereck, Sermo Graecus nos. 5, 19. OGIS 455; Abbott & Johnson, no. 29, Bruns, Fontes no. 43, Ehrenberg & Jones no. 299.C ; Sherk 28B and 29; BE 1970.536. The full text published by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 8, on which Bowersock, Gnomon 56 (1984), 52 (l. 14), Badian, ZPE 55, 1984, 101-111 (ll. 7, 9, 11), whence SEG 32, 1982.1097; BE 1983:367,370, AnnEpig 1984, 862. From all these McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 72 and 73. Discussion by Schlesinger, Die griechische Asylie (Giessen, 1933) 79; J. M. Reynolds, JRS 61 (1971), 285 (on ll. l, 4); F. Millar, JRS (1973), 57, no. 12 (triumviral procedure); discussed by Reynolds, 'Inscriptions and the Building of the Temple', Aphrodisias Papers (Ann Arbor, 1990), 37-40, 37.

entry.title: Extracts from senatus consultum, with awards to Plarasa/Aphrodisias
entry.summary: Archive wall, column four, second and third courses, immediately below 517. Inscribed area 2.075 x 0.22. The marked change of letter size in l. 10 is accompanied by outspacing of the line, much closer horizontal spacing and very free use of ligatures; it looks as if the cutter was squeezing in a section for which space (or adequate space) had not originally been allowed. Date: Inscription: second to third centuries (lettering, context). Document: 39/38 B.C. (content, prosopography). . Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1967. Published by Reynolds, A&R 9 whence SEG 32, 1982.1097; BE 1983.370; AnnEpig 1984, 863, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 3 (lines 1-6), 35 (lines 7-9), 4 (lines 10-15).

entry.title: Letter of Severus and Caracalla to Aphrodisias
entry.summary: Archive wall, column five, second course. The block to the left is substantially intact although damaged at the upper right hand corner; the block to the right is broken away and lost except for small fragments. Immediately below 8.35. Surviving inscribed area 1.31 x 0.435; lines 1, 5, 9 outspaced. Date: Inscription: second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, context). Document: A.D. 198 (titulature). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1967, and fragments found over subsequent years (67.449, 69.315, 69.458, 69.459, 69.460, 69.463, 76.62, 76.107, 76.196.1-8). Published by Reynolds, A&R 17 whence Mitchell, CR 34, 1984, 296 (l. 10); SEG 32, 1982.1097, BE 1983.378, AnnEpig 1984, 871, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 54 . Discussed by C.P. Jones in V. Fromentin and S. Gottelend edd., Origines Gentium (Bordeaux 2001) 183, whence SEG 2001.1492.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Letter of Severus and Caracalla to Aphrodisias
entry.summary: Archive wall, column 5, third course. The left side, covering one and a half blocks, is complete except for the upper right corner of the second block, but on the right side one block is broken and partly lost and the right end is wholly lost ; fragments of the lost areas have been found fallen in front of the wall. Inscribed area 1.56 x 0.18; l. 1 outspaced. Date: Inscription: second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, context). Document: A.D. 198 (titulature). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1967; and fragments found over subsequent years (inventory nos. 67.310 , 67.454, 69.310, 69.458, 69.459, 69.463, 69.469). Published by Reynolds, A&R 18 whence BE 1983.379, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 55 . Discussed by Millar, ERW 416.

entry.title: Honours for Hosidius Ioulianos
entry.summary: Two blocks: a (in two pieces) 0.98, marked ΓΑ ; b 1.27, marked ΔΑ. Inscribed in two lines on the fascia, which has an extra moulding above the text, only here. Date: Second century A.D. (lettering, institutions). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1971 (a: 71.430 & 71.478; b: 71.1024). Published by Roueché, PPA 55a, whence PHI.

entry.title: Honours for Hosidius Ioulianos
entry.summary: Three frieze blocks: a, in two fragments (length, together, 0.78) has a space with a small moulding above, at the left end, before the text; it has the assembly mark ΗΑ. The other two blocks have no assembly marks; b, broken to the left, is 0.75; c, broken at the right, is 0.47. Inscribed in three lines on the fascia. Date: Second century A.D. (lettering, institutions). . Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1971 (71.175 and an unnumbered block; a fragment found in 1988, 88.k). Published by Roueché, PPA 55b.

entry.title: Statue dedication of a statue of Demos by Nikomachos and Menodotos.
entry.summary: White marble statue base with elaborate moulding above and below, chipped at the upper right corner (0.84 × 0.68 × 0.84). The statue of the Demos was found with it. Inscribed on one face. Date: First to second centuries A.D. (titulature, nomenclature). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1970 (70.1023; SBI 151). Published (in majuscule) with the statue, by K.T. Erim & R. R. R. Smith, Aphrodisias Papers 2, 74, whence SEG 1991.921.

entry.title: Seat inscriptions: Theatre, Block E
entry.summary: Theatre, seats. On surface of seats. Row 2: two texts on one seat; (a) at right angles to the edge, (b) parallel to edge. Row 5: i and south end, then a blank seat, then ii.Row 8: at front edge of seat at east end, which has a damaged surface. The last two lines are written at right angles to the rest, at the left; but they seem to be of the same hand, and to belong. Row 9: on 2 separate seats, i to the east. Row 10: On the seat at the west end. Row 11: on one seat. Row 15: on seats at east end. Row 24.i: on seats at west end. Row 26.i: on a seat which is broken away above. Date: Second-sixth century A.D. (context). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Row 2, published by Roueché, ALA 137. iii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 775. Row 26.i: Roueché, ALA 137. iv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 776. All published by Roueché, PPA 46.E.

entry.title: Seat inscriptions: Theatre, Block F
entry.summary: Theatre, seats, central block, into which a raised seat was rather roughly inserted, almost certainly for the provincial governor in the third or early fourth century. Rows 1-3 have been lost. Row 5.i: at north end. The letters below are from another text, and there are further traces on the stone. Row 6.i: towards south end. The kappa in the first line appears to be added, and probably belongs to another text. Row 6.ii: on second seat from north end; The lambda must be from another text. Row 6.iii: on seat at north end. Row 11; on two seats. Row 16.i: a seat with several superimposed texts. Row 16.ii: On risers of seats. Row 17: on one seat at south end. Row 18.i: on one seat towards north end. Row 22.i: At north end, next to steps. Row 23.i: a text superimposed on traces of much larger letters. The text was apparently left unfinished. Above it is a horizontal line, with verticals at either end and in the centre; this could be the remnants of another letter associated with the T, but it may be a design connected with the lower text. Date: Second-sixth century A.D. (context). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, PPA 46.F.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.

Row 12.ii: On second seat from west end. Row 21.i: On risers at east end. Date: Second to sixth centuries A.D. (context). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. All published by Roueché, PPA 46.G.

Row 8.i: On one seat, which is broken to left.Row 8.i: On one seat, which is broken to left. Row 8.ii: On seat to west of 8.1, broken at right. Row 21.i: on risers. Row 22.i: on seat faces. Row 22.ii: On risers. Row 26.ii: On risers. Date: Second-sixth century A.D. (context). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. entry.summary: Two fragments from a white marble architrave frieze; a: (surviving fascia 1.08 × 0.075) with a relief of a theatre mask above; b (0.45 × 0.52 × 0.20) with a relief above, much damaged. Both pieces: inscription on the upper of the two fasciae below. Date: Probably first century A.D. (letter-forms, content). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition, a at an unknown date (Theatre 16), b in 1967 (67.215). a unpublished; b published by Reynolds, Aph.Papers 2, 15-28, no.A.6, whence SEG 1991.916.

entry.title: Honours for Claudius Zelos
entry.summary: Six fragments of four white marble frieze blocks, length a, 0.965, b 0.78, c. (two fragments) 1.12, d 1.27 - total approximately 4.14. The first block carries Θ, the second Η, the third Ζ, the fourth ζ. Inscribed in two lines; height of inscribed area 0.12. Date: 139-161 A.D. (prosopography). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1970 (a. 70.230 & 70.231; b. 70.244; c. 70.232 & 70.233; d. 70.234 ). Published by D. Macdonald, Coins, p. 20, whence BE 1977.459 (l. 1), SEG 1976.1219, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 300.

entry.title: i: Building dedication to Aphrodite and emperors by T.Cl. Zelos. ii: Verse honours for Androkles, a benefactor
entry.summary: Eleven white marble cornice blocks which form the front of the present stage. i: Inscribed along the upper fascia of the blocks, running in a single line from a point c. 1 m. to the right of the north end of the stage, to the south end. ii: Below i is a protruding moulding, and below that two fasciae, on the upper of which (0.07 high) this text is cut. The letters are very lightly cut, with red paint still to be seen in some of them. Those that survive are below the centre of the stage, on the fifth, sixth and seventh blocks from the north end; since all the blocks are in place, it seems likely that the rest of the text, including the gaps in this fragment, was painted, and either not incised at all, or cut so shallowly that it can no longer be detected. Date: i:A.D. 139-161 (reign). ii: Fourth century (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1967 (67.536). i: Published by MacDonald, Greek and Roman Coins from Aphrodisias, p. 20, no. 1, whence BE 1977.459 (l. 1), SEG 1976.1220, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 115, C. P. Jones, HSCP 85 (1981) ; by Reynolds, Aph.Papers 2, 15-28, no. B.1. ii: Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 34, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 715, Steinepigramme 02/09/94.

entry.title: Restoration of statues by Grypos
entry.summary: Parts of the combined architrave and frieze from the north side of the Doric entablature of the theatre stage. Four pieces from three white marble frieze blocks. a: a complete block (length 1.43) b two fragments, (0.64 and 0.62); c broken, length 0.585. d is the left, recessed end of the block bearing the opening of 565. Inscribed in one line on the fascia, height 0.055. Date: A.D. 167-8 (prosopography: Maximus recorded as quaestor Asiae). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1967 (a: 67.548, b: 67.547, c: 67.546, d: 67.540). Published byReynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 53, whence SEG 1982.1097, BullEp 1983.391, AnnEpig 1984.882, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 196.

entry.title: Honours for Kandidianos, circuit-victor
entry.summary: A plain white marble statue base, moulded on either side, made up of two fragments (0.24 x 1.06 x 0.50); there is a depression on the top for the attachment of the statue. For the statue, see bibliography. Inscribed on the face. Date: Third century (lettering, sculpture). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1968 and 1971 (excavation inventory nos. 68.400) and 1971 (71.167). Published by Roueché, PPA 74; published, with the statue, by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, no. 40.

entry.summary: A statue (for description see bibliography) and blue marble statue base with simple moulding above, broken below and to the right (0.25 x 0.57 x 0.28). i. Inscribed on the face of the base; ii inscribed on the plinth of the statue. Date: Third century (lettering, sculpture). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (71.337, 70.509). i published by Roueché, PPA 75;. ii published by Erim-Reynolds, 'Sculptors' no.8, whence SEG 40 1990.931. Both published, with the statue, by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, no. 39.

entry.title: List of Muses
entry.summary: White marble doric half-column, supporting stage architrave. On the east face. a: Bottom line at 1.53 above ground level; there is a square hole, apparently intended to hold a beam, immediately above the text. The text has been erased, but it is possible to make out all the letters. b: Below a, 1.375 above floor. The first word is deeply and clearly cut, with a square sigma, the remaining letters were lightly cut, and a shallow cross was later cut over them; apparently unfinished; immediately below there are traces of red paint.. c: Below b, at 0.48 above floor. ll. 1 and 2 very lightly cut; l. 3 deep cut. Date: Third to fifth centuries A.D. (context, lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, PPA 6.2.

entry.title: Letter of Severus Alexander to Aphrodisias
entry.summary: Archive wall, column 5, on the third and fourth courses. The left-hand part is cut on one and a half blocks which are intact, the right-hand part shows increasing damage and the right end is almost wholly lost except for a few small fragments found fallen. lnscribed area in situ, 1.56 x 0.145; line 1 outspaced. Date: A.D. 224 (titulature, lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1967; a few small fragments found fallen (inv. nos. 67. 454, 67.457, 67.459 and unnumbered items). Published by Reynolds, A&R 19 whence SEG 32, 1982.1097, BE 1983.380; AnnEpig 1984, 873, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 56 .

entry.title: Letter of Gordian III to Epaphras
entry.summary: Block broken in two but now recomposed and substantially complete (W. 1.53 x H. 0.72 x D. 0.72). The inscription was cut in an especially prepared area, around which the unpolished surface survives and forms a frame. The first word of l. 9 is cut in the margin and appears to be an afterthought. Date: 238-244 A.D. (reign, lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1967. Published by Erim and Reynolds, JRS 59, 1969, 56-58 , whence AnnEpig 1969, 599, BE 1970.536, Oliver, GRBS 11, 1970, 137-138, W. Seston, XIII Congrès international des Sciences historiques (Moscow, 1970), M. Wörrle, Chiron 1 (1971), 333, BE 1971.612, Wieling, ZRG 91, 1974, 364; republished by Reynolds, A&R 22 whence SEG 32, 1982.1097, BE 1983.383, AnnEpig 1984,876, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 57 .

entry.summary: Fragment from a white marble door post (1.26 x 0.50 x 0.28) from one of the two door frames in the Ionic register of the stage front decoration. Inscribed with a graffito at 0.26 from edge on the inner face. There seems to have been an attempt to erase the second line. Date: Fifth-sixth centuries A.D. (content, context). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1967 (excavation inventory no. 67.539). An inferior text published by Roueché as ALA 183; republished by Roueché, PPA 10.

entry.title: Building dedication by Aristokles Molossos
entry.summary: White marble panelled block (1.11 × 0.86 × 0.40) with a moulded tabella ansata (die, 0.85 × 0.65), whose handles must have been completed on adjacent blocks. The upper left corner is broken away, and the bottom moulding is chipped along the edge; there are deep grooves, probably natural, on the face in the area of ll. 12 and 13, which the letter-cutter had to avoid. Inscribed on one face within the tabella. Date: Julio-Claudian (prosopography, terminology). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1969 (69.317). Published by Reynolds, Aph.Papers 2, 15-28, no. A.2, whence SEG 1991.912.

entry.title: Fragmentary acclamations
entry.summary: A series of frsco fragments on wall plaster, some joining to make up ten fragments. Letters painted in green on a white background; there are slight traces of a border at the lower edge of a. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries (terminology). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1970. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 76 a-e, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 810, 811, 812, 813, 814; republished by Roueché, PPA, 9.

entry.title: Building inscription by Aristokles [Molossos] son of Ar[temidoros]
entry.summary: Two adjacent, but not adjoining, fragments of a white marble panel, 0.17-0.19 thick, with a simple moulding above, complete but damaged at either side and broken below. a 0.395 × 0.685, b 0.42 × 0.68. Inscribed on the face. The text must have been presented in columns, with one at least to the left of this one. Date: Julio-Claudian (prosopography, terminology). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition, a in 1968 (68.333), b in 1977. published by Reynolds, Aph Papers 2, A.1, whence SEG 1991.911.

entry.title: Building dedication by Aristokles Molossos
entry.summary: White marble masonry block (2.19 × 0.68 x depth not measurable). Inscribed within a recessed panel. Date: Julio-Claudian (prosopography, terminology). . Photo. Copied in 1705 by Picenini (10102, 21v ) whence Sherard (10101,34); by Deering (3, no.13); by Fellows; by Loew; by Waddington; by Choisy; by Gaudin (141); by the MAMA expedition; photographed by L. Robert in ?1946; recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Boeckh from Sherard, CIG 2747; by Fellows, 14, whence CIG IV. p.1109, Bailie 66, Texier pp.163-4. Corrected from Loew by Franz, a.12. Published by Waddington, LBW 1585; cited from Gaudin by Reinach, 133; published by Cormackfrom the MAMA records, MAMA 8, 436 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 100.; by Reynolds, Aph.Papers 2, A.4 , whence SEG 41, 914.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Building dedication by Aristokles Molossos
entry.summary: Five white marble fragments from a long feature with moulding above a cornice (ave. 0.55 x ave. 0.30). Width, from left to right: a, 0.63; b, 0.34; c, 0.53; d, 1.03; e, 1.11; f,. 1.30. Inscribed on the face. Date: Julio-Claudian (prosopography, terminology). Photos. The blocks in the walls (e. & f.) copied in 1705 , near 12.413 by Picenini (10102, 33v) whence Sherard (10101, 45); copied by Deering (7, no. 30); copied by Fellows; copied by Loew; copied by K&R (no notebook entry); copied by Le Bas and by Waddington; recorded by Gaudin (121, 122); recorded by the MAMA expedition in 1934. Rediscovered by the NYU expedition, together with three further fragments (a. 68.709, b. 67.216, c. & d. 69.351) excavated in 1967-1969. e. & f. published by Boeckh, from Sherard, CIG 2755 and 2808; by Fellows, 19 whence CIG add. p. 1109; from these Bailie, 67. Listed by Franz from Loew, a.13. Published by Waddington, LBW 592 and 1586; by Reinach, from Gaudin, 132; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, 435a, 435b, whence Hellenica 13, 127-128 (l. 3), BE 1966.396, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 99. All fragments published by Reynolds, Aph.Papers 2, A.5, whence SEG 1991.915.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Letter of Traianus Decius and Herennius Etruscus to Aphrodisias
entry.summary: White marble block (1.61 x 0.78 x 0.33). Inscribed on the face. Date: December 250- January 251 (reign, titulature, lettering). Photo. Copied by Picenini in 1705 (10102, 30v), whence Sherard (10101, 41); by Wood (14, f45v); by Fellows; by Raoul-Rochette. Perhaps by Bailie; copied by Loew; by Waddington; recorded by Gaudin (142); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition in 1965. Published by Boeckh from Sherard and Raoul-Rochette, CIG 2743 and, from Fellows, p. 1109; by Fellows, p. 302. no. 16; from these, Texier, As. Min. iii 154. by Bailie, ? from these, Fasc. ii 14-16 and 269-272, no. 44; by Franz, from Loew, no. a.9; by Waddington, LBW 1624; by Reinach, from Gaudin, no. 2, whence Abbott & Johnson no. 145; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8.424; Published by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 25, whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.384 AnnEpig 1984.877, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 61 . Discussed: Millar, Emperor in the Roman World, 417.

entry.title: Building dedication by M. Aurelius Menestheus Skopas
entry.summary: Three white marble orthostats. Inscribed on a surface roughly smoothed for teh purpose, which is now chipped, particularly at the edges of the stones.. Date: Early third century (reign, titulature). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Theatre 23). Published by Reynolds, Aph.Papers 2, 15-28, no. C, whence SEG 1991.912.

entry.title: Honours for Gaius Julius Zoilos
entry.summary: Left side of a white marble upper statue base plinth comprising a rectangular inscribed area set on a curved element cut in one piece with it (0.55 × 0.25 × 0.54). The upper surface is treated to receive an upper element. Inscribed on one face. Date: Late first century B.C. (prosopography). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition (Theatre 10, SBI 67). Published by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 38, whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.388, AnnEpig 1984.878, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 258, Smith, Monument, T.7.

entry.title: Votive offering to Zeus
entry.summary: Round-topped white marble stele (0.24 × 0.37 × 0.22) with sculptured relief of a god holding up a double axe in his left hand (?Zeus Labraundeus or Nineudios). Inscribed on the base below, on a roughly dressed surface, which is chipped at left edge and broken away at right. Date: Probably comparatively early , first century B.C. to first century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1973 (73.104). Unpublished.

entry.title: Oath of Plarasa/Aphrodisias, Kibyra, and Tabae
entry.summary: White marble altar (0.55 × 1.09 × 0.44) moulded at top and bottom of the front face, both mouldings badly damaged, the face chipped all along the right edge and approximately in the centre of the left. Inscribed on the face; the last line cut on the lower moulding. Date: Probably second century B.C. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1969 (69.327). Mentioned by R. Mellor, ΘΕΑ ΡΩΜΗ (1975), 49 f. (dedication in l. 2), whence J. and L. Robert, Bull. Ep. 1977.76 (commenting on the geographical relationship of the three cities).Mentioned by Reynolds PCPS 206, 1980, p. 70; and published as Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 1, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 179.

entry.title: Dedication by Gaius Volousios, mime actor
entry.summary: Small white marble altar moulded above and below (0.115 × 0.255 × 0.10) with damaged relief of a winged figure with cloak behind on the face: the head is lost (but without a scar) and the place of the letters of the cognomen allows for it. There is a further figure to the left. Inscribed i. on the upper moulding, which is damaged, ii. on the face above the relief, iii. on the lower moulding. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition in 1968 (68.117). Unpublished.

entry.summary: White marble base capital (0.705 x 0.325 x 0.65). Two cuttings for feet on the top. Inscribed on two upper fasciae (lines 1 and 2) and on the face below. Well-preserved; some chipping on the moulding. Date: Late first or second century (lettering, nomenclature). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1974 (74.48; SBI 24). Unpublished.

entry.title: Honours for Domitian
entry.summary: White marble statue base (0.60 × 0.46 × 0.78) with moulding above and below. There are holes on the top surface for the attachment of the statue, which has its own semi-circular base. The moulding is chipped on a edges; and a round hole has been cut in the centre of the front face. Inscribed on the upper moulding (lines 1-2) and on the face. Date: A.D. early 84-96 (reign, titulature). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1967 (67.282; SBI 150) with the statue. Published by Reynolds with the publication of the statue by Erim in Opusc. Rom., 9, 1973, 135-142, and in Inan-Rosenbaum, Porträtplastik 91, no. 38, whence SEG 1982.1099, SEG 1985.1082, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 206.

entry.title: Funerary fragment from Theatre
entry.summary: Piece from the top of a moulded feature, perhaps a sarcophagus front (0.09 × 0.155 × 0.07). Inscribed on the face, with traces of a relief to the right of the text. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1970 (70.253). Unpublished.

entry.title: Fragment of funerary panel from Theatre
entry.summary: Part of the right side of a panel (0.215 × 0.36 × 0.09) inscribed partly within, and partly on, a tabella ansata. ll. 1, 3, 6 inscribed on the moulding; b. on the ansa. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1972 (72.223). Unpublished.

entry.summary: Fragment of a stele or panel/sarcophagus front, with back but no edges (0.15 × 0.16 × 0.065). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1973 (73.85). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary fragment from Theatre
entry.summary: Piece from the lower part of a stele moulded below (0.23 × 0.22 × 0.12). Inscribed in the inset face (ll. 1-4) and on the lower moulding (ll. 5-6). Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1974 (74.136). Unpublished.

entry.summary: A block (0.54 × 0.44 × 0.24). Scratched on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (nomenclature). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Theatre 26). Unpublished.

entry.summary: Fragment from the bottom of a white marble panel (0.255 × 0.26 × 0.09). Inscribed on a rather rough surface. Date: A.D. 128/9-138 (reign, titulature). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1970 (70.254). Unpublished.

entry.summary: Fragment of white marble sarcophagus front (0.27 × 0.335 × 0.12) back survives, and traces of a moulding above. Inscribed on a face. Date: Third-fourth century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1968 (68.362). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary verse, fragmentary
entry.summary: Fragment from the lower part of a stele (0.29 × 0.295 × 0.21). Back, and perhaps lower edge, survive. Inscribed on one face, which is very worn and abraded. Date: Possibly after A.D. 250 (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1971 (71.46). Unpublished.

entry.title: Honours for an amicus principum
entry.summary: White marble masonry block (0.35 × 0.22 × 0.42) with upper and lower edges surviving, and with rough sides; either cut down, or from a composite monument. Inscribed on the face, which is extremely worn. Date: First half of the fourth century (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1968 (68.401; recatalogued as 74.280). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 15, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 454 (wrongly) and 665.

entry.title: Dedication (building inscription), to a saint
entry.summary: Fragment, broken on all sides (0.18 × 0.38 × 0.21), from a white marble architrave block, from which two stepped fascia survive. Inscribed on the two fasciae. Date: Fourth/fifth/sixth century (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1971 (71.18). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 104 , and plate xxviii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 602.

entry.title: Epitaph of Athanasios
entry.summary: Four joining fragments of a white marble plaque (0.40 x 0.42 × 0.09). Inscribed on both sides within a raised and moulded edge. On face a the moulding is slightly more elaborate, and the lettering, which is more regular than on face b, is surrounded by an incised margin; the last letter of 1.4 interrupts the margin, which seems to have been cut after the letters. Date: Fourth to sixth centuries or later (lettering, content). Photos. Recorded by the NYU in 1968, 1969 and 1977 (68.354, 69.30, 69.31, and an unnumbered fragment). Published by Roueché, ALA 163a whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 744, 745.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Epitaph of Polychronios
entry.summary: Upper left corner of a white marble plaque with flat moulding (0.25 × 0.34 × 0.145). Inscribed in one line on upper moulding. Date: Fourth century or later (style, lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1971 (71.356). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias 176 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 750.

entry.title: Reserved benches for associations
entry.summary: Seven white marble benches: i: 0.46 × 1.25 × 0.335. ii: Broken below, and to right, 0.45 × 1.35 × depth not measurable. iii: No measurements. iv: 0.45 × 1.02 × 0.39. v: 0.44 × 0.98 × depth not measurable. vi: 0.42 × 1.53 × 0.32. vii 0.46 × 1.24 × 0.33. Inscribed in the centre of the upper face; vii is partly hidden. Date: Fourth to sixth centuries A.D. (lettering, re-use). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (i-vi before 1989, vii in 1992). i-vi published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 212, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 701, 693, 694, 695, 696, 697.

entry.title: Fragment of building inscription.
entry.summary: White marble panel fragment without edges (0.09 × 0.12 × 0.02). Inscribed on the face. Date: Fourth-fifth century (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition (71.389). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 229, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 761.

entry.title: Graffiti representing menoroth
entry.summary: A marble block, perhaps part of a door post which has been cut down for re-use (0.43 × 1.29 × 0.41). Graffiti incised on the front face. Date: Possibly no earlier than last quarter of fourth century (if indiction on l. 3), but very uncertain. Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (date?). Published by Reynolds & Tannenbaum, Jews and Godfearers at Aphrodisias, appendix, 2.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragmentary acclamations
entry.summary: Two fragments from two separate rectangular white marble (column) blocks, which look very much like doorposts. i. Upper part (0.87 × 0.81 × 0.42) broken below. ii. Lower part (0.60 × 0.51 × 0.38) broken above. i:. Just above the break a rectangular area of white plaster was outlined in red (H. 0.33, W. 0.55) and inscribed with a painted text; there are at least two levels of text (as in 8.408, 8.508). ii. A similar rectangular area is outlined below the break (H. 0.17, W. 0.53); only one level of text can be deciphered. Date: Fifth/sixth century (terminology). Photos. Excavated during dismantling of the defence wall in 1982. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 78, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 822, 823, 824.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Invocation
entry.summary: The lower right corner of a large plain white marble masonry block (0.23 × 0.65 × 0.13). Inscribed on the face. Date: Fifth-sixth century or later (content). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1970 (70.228). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 136, and plate xxxiii whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 772.

entry.title: Funerary verse for Jordanes
entry.summary: Two joining fragments of a thick white marble plaque (0.34 x 0.27 × 0.13), chipped at right edge and broken below. Inscribed on the prepared face. Date: Fifth/sixth century (content, metre). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1975, during the removal of the old mosque (75.57). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 156 and plate xxxvi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 733, Steinepigramme 02/09/30.

entry.title: Table/dish fragment with numerals
entry.summary: Fragment without edges from a large white marble dish/table (0.18 × 0.165 × 0.025), slanted on the underside and curved on the inside. Inscribed on the inside between lightly scored guidelines. Date: Fifth or sixth century. Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition (74.75). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 221, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 875.

entry.title: Acclamations of Mardaetus and of the Pytheanitae (gameboard)
entry.summary: Four joining fragments of a white marble panel with a raised rim on all sides (1. 0.89, W. 0.65, 0. 0.16), inscribed on the face with a board, type 3Rows.4, carefully cut on the central panel (0.55 × 0.75; circles 0.04; central rosette in circle, 0.09). One side is entirely preserved, and the two ends survive in part. Inscribed along one long side (a) and the short side to the left of it (b). The other end was not inscribed. Date: Late fifth century A.D. (prosopography). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1969 (69.378). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 59 a and b, and plate xv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 841, 842; republished Roueché, Gameboards, no. 5.

entry.title: The city honours Bitianos, governor
entry.summary: A rectangular white marble statue base shaft (0.86 × 0.47 × 0.40) with panels within moulded edges on three sides. Inscribed on the central panel; on the right side panel the letters ΤΑ have been cut. Date: Late fifth/early-mid sixth century (offices; titles). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1970 (70.226, SBI 26). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 65 and plate xvi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 669.

entry.title: Orthagoras, bishop, undertakes building work
entry.summary: Fragment from a white marble panel (0.25 × 0.23 × 0.07), of which part of the left side survives. Inscribed on the face. Date: Sixth century (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1971 (71.343). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 90 and plate xxiii , whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 631.

entry.title: Epitaph of Theodokios
entry.summary: Two joining fragments of a white marble plaque (0.29 × 017 x 0.065), with upper and right edge partly surviving. The stone appears to have been cut down—rather than simply broken—to the left, so that it is difficult to know what length of lines to assume. Inscribed across the centre of the face. Date: Sixth century A.D. or later (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1971 (71.348). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias 174 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 753.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedicatory poem, church of SS. Barbara and Anastasia
entry.summary: Three white marble fragments which join to form two blocks of a composite lintel (H. 0.15-0.18, D. 0.31-0.35) with moulding along the front and the surviving right edge; probably only a small fragment is lost to the left—the total surviving W. 1.50. Inscribed in one line along the uppermost fascia of the moulding, which is chipped away above. Date: Ninth to tenth centuries A.D. (lettering, metre). Recorded by the NYU expedition (69.354, 70.224, 79.190). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 107 and plate xxix, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 612.

entry.title: Tetrastoon: pavement designs
entry.summary: White marble stylobate blocks. Inscribed on the upper face of the blocks. Date: Second-tenth century A.D. (context). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Gameboards 6.

entry.title: Place inscription of people of Hierapolis
entry.summary: White marble column. Cut on east side of column. Date: Late imperial (location, lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 196, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 389.

entry.summary: White marble column. Cut on east side. Date: Late imperial (lettering, location). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 197, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 390.

entry.title: List of commodities
entry.summary: Plastered wall, in a recess. The text is scratched on the north side of a recess, at 1.40 above ground level; it occupies a space 0.28 high and 0.12 wide. The surface is lost at the lower left. Date: Fourth century (terminology, location). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 213, and plate xlv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 764.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Julian by Antonius Tatianos
entry.summary: a. A white marble statue base capital, for a columnar base, and b. the white marble columnar shaft of a statue base with simple moulding above and below (H. 1.16; diam. 0.53). The moulding is cut into on both sides, as is the shaft itself on one side, as if it had served as a support for a balustrade (or perhaps for re-use in the defence wall). The moulding is half smoothed, and half left rough. The statue also survives: see Smith (2001). Line 1 is on a simple column capital, inscribed at the top of the drum; lines 2-13 are on the shaft, but the inscription is not centred in respect of the moulding. Date: A.D. 361/363 (reign). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1976 and 1977 (base: 77.136, SBI 27, capital: 76.112). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 20, and Plate vii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 657. Statue: R. R. R. Smith (1999) 161-2; R. R. R. Smith, 'A portait monument for Julian and Theodosius' in C. Reusser ed. Griechenland in der Kaiserzeit (Berlin, 2001) 125-136.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: i. Honours for Titus Falvius Sallustios Athenagoras; ii. Honours for Valens by Antonius Tatianos
entry.summary: A rectangular white marble statue base shaft (1.21 × 0.60 × 0.575); panels within moulding on four sides (0.40 x 0.98). Inscribed on two opposite faces within the panels. Date: A.D. 364 (reign). Photos. Excavated in 1972 by the NYU expedition (72.54). i. Unpublished. ii. cited by J. R. Martindale, Historia 29 (1980), 494; published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 21 and Plate vi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 658.

entry.title: Verse honours for a governor
entry.summary: Two joining fragments of a white marble columnar statue base shaft (total H. 1.35. diam. 0.53); the substantial part found standing on a plinth (H. 0.33) cut down from the socle of a fluted column; the upper left corner fragment found separately. Inscribed on the face. Date: Fifth century (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition, main part in 1972, fragment in 1973 (73.206). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 64 and plate xvi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 728, Steinepigramme 02/09/26.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Acclamations for governors
entry.summary: Several columns (diam. 0.46) of blue marble, from the western portico of the Tetrastoon. Several of these columns showed traces of paint, but on only two could anything be deciphered. Even on these little can be made out; not only have they suffered from re-use, but it is clear that there had, as in 8.508 and 8.268, been several layers of plaster. Painted in red on several layers of white plaster. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries (terminology). Photos. Found during the dismantling of the wall by the NYU expedition in 1982. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 75, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias nos. 808, 809.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Sundial
entry.summary: White marble columnar altar; the diameter of the top surface, which is slightly ovel, is 0.78 (north-south), 0.885 (west to east), to serve as a sundial. Inscribed on the top surface; there is a hole where the gnomon may have stood. Date: Fifth-sixth century (context, lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition. Published, from Reynolds, by P. Pattenden, JHS 101 (1981), 101-112 whence SEG 1981.931; BE 1982.360, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 868; republished by Roueché (2004), 249.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: The city honours Fl. Palmatos, governor
entry.summary: A rectangular white marble statue base shaft (1.01 × 0.48 × 0.60) with moulding, broken above and below. The stone was re-used; on the opposite face there is a half-moon in relief, suggesting that it perhaps had had a religious function. It stood rather awkwardly on a plinth formed by cutting down another base. Inscribed on upper moulding (line 1) and on face below (lines 2 ff.). Date: Late fifth/early sixth century (titulature). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1972 (SBI 1) together with its accompanying statue. Published by Erim in Porträtplastik, 238, no. 208, whence An.Ép. 1977.605; by Roueché (1979), 173 with plate, whence SEG 1979.1070, BE 1980.473, SEG 1982.1102; republished by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 62 and plate xvi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 670. Statue published by Erim, Porträtplastik, 236 - 8, no. 208; discussed by Smith (1999), 168 and fig. 9, plate iii.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Altar dedication by Diogenes son of Damonikos
entry.summary: White marble altar with moulding above and below on three sides, a little chipped along the edges (0.29 × 0.39 × 0.27). The face carries a relief showing a thunderbolt and below this an inscription. Date: Second to first century B.C. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1973 (73.126). Unpublished.

entry.title: Sundial fragments
entry.summary: Two pieces of a white marble sundial—not certainly both from the same monument. a: two joining fragments without edges (0.21 across cord × 0.34 × 0.20); b: fragment with lower rim (0.26 across cord × 0.52 × 0.175). Inscribed on the cord. Date: First to second centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1973 (73.58). Unpublished.

entry.title: ?Title for a statue of the Council
entry.summary: Badly worn white marble statue base, simply moulded at the top and bottom of the front face (0.56 × 0.28 × 0.43). Inscribed on the face, which is very worn. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1976 (76.108 or 111). Unpublished.

entry.title: Gladiator memorial for enis
entry.summary: Upper part of a white marble panel-stele (0.45 x 0.46 x 0.16) broken below and chipped on all edges. The relief, which is broken at the waist, is of a facing gladiator, with his head turned slightly to his right. He wears a highly decorated cuirass, with a rose and other designs on it in relief, and a decorated belt. On his left arm he holds a long shield with a decorated rim and the letter Γ in the top right corner. His right arm has an arm guard on the upper arm, which is all that survives. In the field on either side of the head are two wreaths, each decorated with a ribbon. Inscribed on the upper moulding, which is broken. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. . Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1972 (excavation inventory no. 72.140). Published by Roueché, PPA 19.

entry.summary: Piece from a white marble sarcophagus front 0.57 × 0.412 × 0.17 figuring arcades enclosing figures of which the upper part of one survives complete, with two in fragmentary form on either side. Inscribed on the upper lip (a) and around the arcades (b ). Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1973 (73.23). Unpublished.

Published by Reynolds & Tannenbaum, Jews & God-Fearers 135-136, no. 8 and plate, whence SEG 1987.850, BE 1988.888; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 195, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 676.

entry.title: Fragmentary acclamations
entry.summary: Seven columns (i, 0.54 diam.; others all 0.29-0.30 diam.) of blue marble, mostly broken at both ends. All showed traces of white plaster, apparently applied to form a panel. Painted in red on the plaster within a painted square. As in 8.408 and 8.268, there seem to be several layers of plaster and of script. Decipherment is made more difficult by the condition of the surface after re-use in the wall. On only three of the columns could anything of substance be discerned: the readings are fragmentary and unsatisfactory. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries A.D. (terminology). Photos. Excavated during dismantling of the defence wall in 1976. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 77, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 815, 816, 817, 818, 819, 815, 816, 820, 821.

entry.title: Prayer
entry.summary: Blue marble column. The inscription is cut 0.26 above the lower end of the column, and the inscribed area measures 0.43 × 0.23. Above the text is a depiction of a Christian sanctuary: two spiral columns support an arch, with a pointed roof surmounted by a cross. From the arch hangs a lamp, flanked by two candles and two birds. The candles stand on a rail between the columns, from which hang curtains, looped back to reveal a large cross, flanked by an angel and a saint. Two birds are perched on the capitals of the columns. The design and the letters have been cut with a fine-pointed implement. Date: Fourth century A.D. or later (content). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 142 and plate xxxiv; not in PHI.

entry.title: i. Verse honours for Doulkitios from Balerianos; ii. Place inscription
entry.summary: A rectangular statue base with panels within moulded edges on three sides (1.07 × 0.44 × 0.44). i. is cut on the central panel. The final letters, or stops, in ll. 6, 7, 8, 11 and 12 are cut on the moulding. ii., a graffito, is on the left panel, and was apparently left unfinished. Date: i.Mid-fifth century (titulature, prosopography); ii. Late fifth century or later (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1972 (72.200, SBI 54). i. Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 41 and plate x, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 718, Steinepigramme 02/09/09; ii. Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 194, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 388.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Eirenion, gladiator

Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1974 (excavation inventory no. 74.227). Published by Roueché, PPA 43.

entry.title: Building restoration dedicated to Aphrodite and emperors
entry.summary: Fragments of white marble architrave blocks (1.63 × 0.31 × 0.57-0.69 in depth) from the entablature of the north portico of the Sebasteion. Above is a decoration of mutules, spaced at intervals of 0.30. The inscription runs in one line on a single, unstepped, face. The face is drafted above, below and at the ends of each block; the upper drafting line rises to follow the line of the moulding between the mutules. The inscription was cut when the blocks were in place, and letters run across joins. Date: First century A.D. Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition, in the Sebasteion in 1981 (from left to right, 81.88, 81.89, 81.87, 81.85, 81.94, 81.95) and in the East wall of the Theatre between 1967 and 1972 (71.440, 72.215, 72.162, 73.167, 73.151, 75.258, 73.111, 71.431, 67.471, 71.432, 72.164, 72.216, 70.247, 70.248, and 2 unnumbered fragments). Also 83.150. Cited by Erim, Britannia 13, 1982, 278, note 8, Smith, JRS 77, 1987, 90, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 95.

entry.summary: False 'base' in relief comprising upper and lower elements; lower element has a youthful smiling mask flanked by garlands in relief. The base was repaired in antiquity, and there are clamp marks. Inscribed on upper element. Date: 1st-century A.D. (lettering, context). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1980 (80.150). Published by Reynolds, ZPE 43 (1981), 317-27, no.15, whence SEG 31 1981.924, BullEp 1982.356; mentioned SEG 35.1082; published by Smith, JRS 78 (1988), 55, no. 15, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 902 .

entry.title: Honours for anonymous, high-priest
entry.summary: Left end of a white marble corner architrave block (0.495 × 0.42 x depth not measurable). Above the front fasciae, which are not inscribed, is a relief of bovine heads. Inscribed on two fasciae at the left end. Date: First century A.D. (reign). Photos. Recorded by the MAMA expedition in 1934; excavated by the NYU expedition, in 1974 (74.254). Published by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 432, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 83 .

The base was repaired in antiquity, and there are clamp marks. Inscribed on upper element. Date: 1st century A.D.(lettering, context). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1980 (80.145). entry.title: Building dedication of Sebasteion portico for Aphrodite, Emperors and Demos
entry.summary: Nine fragments of six white marble architrave blocks. Inscribed in two lines on the two fasciae. Date: A.D. 41-54 (reign). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1979 and 1980 (a. 79.109; b. 80.66 + 80.67; c. 80.60; d. 80.62 + 80.65; e. 80.64 + 80.63. f. 80.91). published by Reynolds, ZPE 43 (1981), 317-27, no.1, whence SEG 31, 1981.913, BE 1982, 356, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 106 ; mentioned Erim, RA (1982) I, 165, Erim, Britannia 13, (1982), 278 (l. 1).

entry.title: Honours for Antonia Augusta
entry.summary: White marble statue base, with moulding above and below on three sides (0.54 × 0.405 × 0.47). The back and much of the moulding have been broken away, probably to facilitate re-use. Top worked smooth. Inscribed on the face. Date: Julio-Claudian (context, lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1980 (80.172; SBI 83). Published by Reynolds, ZPE 43 (1981), 317-27, no.5, whence SEG 1981.915, BullEp 1982.356, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 204.

entry.title: Honours for Lucius Caesar
entry.summary: White marble statue base, with moulding above and below on all sides (0.75 × 0.26 x surviving 0.45) and damaged. Fragments of the statue have been published 9see bibliography). Inscribed on the face. Date: Julio-Claudian (context, lettering). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition during excavation of the Sebasteion in 1982 (82.108; SBI 72). Mentioned by Reynolds, StudClas 24, 1986, 112; by Smith, JRS 77, 1987, 95, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 194 . Published, with fragments of the statue, by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, no. 28.

entry.title: Honours for Drusus Caesar
entry.summary: Two joining fragments of a white marble statue base with moulding above and below on all sides (0.67 × 0.32 × 0.57) damaged at lower left corner, on top front moulding and back left corner. Fragments of the statue have been published (see bibliography). Inscribed on the face. Date: Julio-Claudian (context, lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1981 and 1982 (82.116 + 81.153; SBI 84). mentioned by Reynolds, StudClas 24, 1986, 112; by Smith, JRS 77, 1987, 95, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 195. Published, with the statue fragments, by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, no. 27.

Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1982 (82.118; SBI 85s). mentioned by Reynolds, StudClas 24, 1986, 112; by Smith, JRS 77, 1987, 95, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 193 .

Inscribed on the face (area 0.395 × 0.15). Date: Julio-Claudian (context, lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1984 (84.41; SBI 78). Mentioned by Reynolds, StudClas 24, 1986, 112; by Smith, JRS 77, 1987, 95, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 197.

entry.title: Honours for Marcus Lepidus
entry.summary: Rectangular white marble statue base, with moulding above on four sides and below on three sides (0.63 × 1.17 × 0.43). Chipped on all edges, upper front corners broken. Inscribed on the face. Date: Julio-Claudian (context, lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1977 (77.123; SBI 48). published by Reynolds, PCPS 206 (1980), no. 15, whence SEG 1980.1251; BE 1982.355; AnnEpig 1980.876, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 202.

entry.title: Honours for Aphrodite ancestress of the Augusti
entry.summary: White marble statue base, with moulding above and below on three sides (0.55 × 0.49 × 0.53). Top prepared for an upper feature; bottom face prepared for fitting. Inscribed on the face. Date: Julio-Claudian (context, lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1982 (82.117; SBI 81). Published by Reynolds, StudClas 24, 1986, 111-112, whence BE 1988.884, SEG 1986.988, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 182.

entry.summary: Left side of a composite white marble statue base with damaged moulding above and below on three sides (0.612 × 0.30 × 0.55). Inscribed on the face, which is damaged. Date: Julio-Claudian (context, lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1982 (82.109; SBI 82). Published, with the statue, by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, no. 81.

entry.title: Honours for Agrippina
entry.summary: White marble statue base, originally with moulding above and below on three sides, but with the lower front moulding chiselled away (0.66 × 1.15 × 0.62). Top prepared for an upper feature. Inscribed on one face within a slightly raised panel (0.48 × 0.915); chipped down the right side. Date: Julio-Claudian (context, lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1972 (72.224; SBI 57). published by Reynolds, in PCPS 206, 1980, 80-81, no. 13, and in Inan-Rosenbaum, Porträtplastik, 78-79, no. 24 (accompanying the statue), whence SEG 1980.1250, BullEp 1982.355, AnnEpig 1980.874, SEG 1982.1098, SEG 1985.1082, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 201.

entry.title: Honours for Germanicus Caesar
entry.summary: White marble statue base, originally with moulding above and below on three sides (0.75 × 1.20 × 0.69). Inscribed on the face (0.57 x 0.95). The upper moulding has been chiselled away on the front face. Date: Julio-Claudian (context, lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition, in 1972 (72.237; SBI 56). Published by Reynolds, PCPS no. 14, whence SEG 1980.1252; BullEp 1982.355; AnnEpig 1980.875; McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 199.

entry.summary: White marble statue base with moulding above and below on three sides (0.74 × 0.36 × 0.61 surviving), badly damaged. Top has traces of cuttings. Excavated by NYU expedition in 1972 (72.275; SBI 58). published by Reynolds, PCPS no. 17, whence SEG 1980.1249; BullEp 1982.355, AnnEpig 1980.877, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 192. entry.title: Honours for Atia mother of Augustus
entry.summary: White marble statue base with moulding above and below (0.77 × 0.40 × 0.50). Inscribed on the face (0.67 × 0.215); chipped at all corners, especially on the right side. Date: Julio-Claudian (context, lettering). Photos. Found by the NYU expedition in 1973 (73.145; SBI 8). entry.title: Letter of Valerian and Gallienus
entry.summary: Two adjoining pieces (a: 1.15 × 0.76 × 0.285; b: 0.78 × 1.44 × 0.285) constituting the upper left corner, the left hand edge, and the lower part of a white marble panel with moulding at all edges. Inscribed on the face, within the moulding. Date: A.D. 257 (see commentary). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1982 (a: 82.195, b: 82.103). Published by Reynolds in Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 1, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 62.

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Fragment from the upper edge of a white marble sarcophagus front, broken at sides and below (0.72 × 0.33 × 0.08). A line of relief decoration above the inscription has been chipped away, presumably to facilitate its re-use. Inscribed on the face. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1981 (81.3). Unpublished.

entry.summary: Fragment from the upper edge of a white marble sarcophagus front, broken at sides and below (0.30 × 0.235 × 0.11). Inscribed above (l.1) and below a line of decoration, which has been hacked away. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1981 (81.54). Unpublished.

entry.title: Fragment, perhaps funerary
entry.summary: White marble fragment, probably from a sarcophagus front, with back but no edges (0.105 × 0.135 × 0.055). Inscribed on the face. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1987 (87.397). Unpublished.

entry.summary: Fragment from the right side of a white marble base with upper moulding (0.31 × 0.21 × 0.45). Inscribed on a worn face. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1988 (Sebasteion 1). Unpublished.

entry.title: Building dedication to Tiberius and Livia
entry.summary: Four fragments of white marble architrave blocks, with three fasciae which have bead and reel decoration between them. a. (1.54 × 0.45 × 0.58) has left edge, but the right end is broken; b. (1.0 × 0.42 × 0.58) is broken to the left, but the right edge survives; c. (1.54 × 0.45 × 0.58) has left edge, but the right end is broken; d. (1.0 × 0.42 × 0.58) is broken to the left, but the right edge survives. Inscribed on three fasciae. Date: A.D. 14-37 (reign). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition (83.151, Village 9). c published by Reynolds, PCPS 206, 1980, 79, no. 10, whence SEG 1980.1248, AnnEpig 1980.872, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 103; discussed by Reynolds, StudClas 24, 1986, 110, note 12 (l. 2).

entry.title: Sculptor's signature: Koblanos
entry.summary: White marble bust of a boy, on a simple plinth: for publication, see bibliography. Inscribed on the plinth. Date: Middle or late 1st century A.D. (sculpture). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1981 (81.113). Published by Erim-Reynolds, 'Sculptors' no.12, whence SEG 40 1990.935. Published, with the bust, by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, no. 110.

entry.title: Fragment of funerary verse
entry.summary: Left hand fragment from a white marble panel (0.11 × 0.12 × 0.045). Inscribed on the face in well set out lines. Date: second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1980 (80.40). Published by Roueché (2004), 242.

entry.title: Gameboard
entry.summary: A loose fragment of a white marble entablature block, with a triglyph decoration. Cut on the two faces at either side of the triglyph. i on the right, ii on the left. Date: Second-sixth century A.D. (context). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (inventory no.S.220-6). Published by Roueché, Gameboards 8.

entry.summary: White marble revetment fragment (0.275 × 0.21 × 0.03-0.035) with, apparently, lower edge surviving; there is a trench cut below l. 2. Inscribed on the face. Date: second century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1979 (79.183). Unpublished.

Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, nomenclature). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1979 (79.191). Unpublished.

entry.title: Fragment from Sebasteion
entry.summary: Fragment from the lower edge of a white marble plaque (0.11 × 0.21 × 0.035). At least two lines, 0.05 apart. Date: 4th century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1982 (82.148). Unpublished.

entry.title: Epitaph of Kyriakos, priest
entry.summary: Fragment from a white marble sarcophagus, broken above and below (0.17 × 0.65 × 0.37), with a tabella ansata in light relief on the front. Inscribed within the tabella. Date: Fourth century or later (terminology). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1981 (81.143, renumbered as 88.15). Roueché, Aphrodisias 168, and plate xxxix, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 749.

entry.title: Panel fragment: funerary
entry.summary: Lower right corner of a white marble panel (0.10 × 0.17 × 0.04); the back is polished, and has a rim below, suggesting that an earlier piece is being re-used. Inscribed on the face. Date: Fourth to sixth century or later (lettering, content). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition (81.7). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 227, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 759.

entry.title: Monogram of Theochares, donor
entry.summary: A large white marble console (no measurements) with a moulded upper rim, with a cross in a relief medallion in the centre. Cut on the curved area. Date: Fifth/sixth century (form of monogram). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1982 (82.110). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 102 and plate xxvii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 618.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Titles on philosopher portraits
entry.summary: A group of nine 'shield busts', of which numbers 1, 3, 5, 6 and 7 are inscribed; 5 is grey marble; the rest are white marble. For full description see Smith (1990), especially 132-147. Inscribed on the rim below the bust. Date: Late fifth century (style, lettering, context). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1981: 1: 81.115; 3:81.136; 5: 81.97; 6: 81.135; 7: 81.114. Published by R. R. R. Smith (1990) 127, whence SEG 1990.950, BE 1991.519, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 516 (1 only); discussed, R. R. R. Smith, 'Late Roman philosophers', Aphrodisias Papers 2, 144-167; republished by Roueché (2004), 251.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedicatory poem
entry.summary: Four white marble fragments from the same crowning feature, of which two join, to form c. The original feature was a slightly convex white marble block (H. 0.145, D. 0.40), and decorated with relief patterns on the underside; the block was therefore designed to be seen from below, and perhaps served a purpose similar to that of 1.37. Length: a: 0.50. b: 0.53. c: two joining fragments. 0.65. Inscribed in one line on the outer edge, which has a slight slope upwards. Date: Twelfth century (lettering). Photos. All recorded by the NYU expedition (a, 83.161; b, 84.181; c, unnumbered). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 110, whence Steinepigramme 02/09/99 not in PHI.

entry.title: Gladiator memorial for Kaistillos
entry.summary: Altar-stele with a releif of a gladiator. No description. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (content). Recorded by Gaudin. Cited from Gaudin's notebooks by K. T. Erim, 'De Aphrodisiade', AJA 71 (1967), 243, whence BullÉp 1968.507. Published by Roueché, PPA 28.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Gladiator memorial for Margaretes
entry.summary: A white marble altar-stele with moulding above and below (0.84 x 0.37 x 0.28). The relief is of a heavily armed gladiator, with short sword in right hand, long shield in left, and a helmet which obscures his face, advancing right. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D.(content, lettering). Copied by G. Doublet and G. Deschamps in 1887; copied by Reichel in 1892 'im Felde vor der Südmauer' (R.I.23) and mentioned by Kubitschek (K.III, endpaper); not reported subsequently. published by Doublet and Deschamps, BCH (1890), 613, no.12. Cited by Kubitschek and Reichel, no.2, whence Robert, Gladiateurs no.161; published from Reichel's notebook by Robert, Hell. V.93-5, no.16; published by Roueché, PPA 32.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Votive offering to a goddess (Aphrodite)
entry.summary: White marble round altar or base (diam. 0.35 × 0.45) with moulding above; broken below, and damaged at the back. There is a dowel hole in the top for an attachment. Inscribed below the moulding. Date: Perhaps second century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1985 (Museum 112; 85.154; SBI 88). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Theseus
entry.summary: White marblesarcophagus front: 'Marble slab with incised panel, broken on right and chipped below' (0.515 x 0.185 x no depth given) (MAMA). Inscribed on the face. Date: No indication. Photo. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. Published by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 569, whence Hellenica 13, 184-192, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 398 , BE 1966.409, Steinepigramme 02/09/32.

entry.title: ?Posthumous honours
entry.summary: White marble block (0.43 × 0.39 x depth not measurable) broken above and to left, complete below. Inscribed on the face; the text must have continued onto a lower block. Date: Probably 1st century B.C. (lettering). Recorded in 1904 by Gaudin (174); by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, no. 108; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 422, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 34 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication by Dionysios on behalf of Ammia
entry.summary: Small white marble altar (0.16 × 0.325 × 0.14) moulded above and below. The upper moulding has spaces on either side of reliefs, probably of breasts. Two olive branches are sculpted on the front. Inscribed on the face, enclosed by the olive branches. Date: Presumably before the Edict of Caracalla (lettering, nomenclature); but cf. lettering of 8.904 (=68.51) which refers to a M. Aurelius. Photos. Brought in to the NYU expedition in 1965 (65.51). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Panphilos Krokion
entry.summary: Plain white marble base, weathered (0.42 × 0.66 × 0.39), with holes in the top for attachment of a capital. Inscribed on the lower fascia (0.51 × 0.10). The main text containing the decision must have been inscribed on a base below. Date: Probably first century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Village 2). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Papulos, contest-president
entry.summary: Two adjoining white marble blocks from a composite monument, complete above and below, but damaged at edges (0.195 x 0.81 x 0.34). Inscribed on the face; the text must have begun on the upper blocks of the monument from which these blocks came. Date: First century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1978 and 1979 (79.25). Published by Roueché, PPA 48.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Posthumous honours for Papylos son of Iason
entry.summary: White marble block (0.57 × 0.285 × 0.33) with light moulding along the left and bottom edges, chipped on all sides, and worn. The text is inscribed on the face and impinges on the moulding on the left side. Date: First century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by K&R (KIII.52, Abklatsch 32); by Gaudin (22); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition in 1970 (70.212; SBI 155). Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 136, no. 68; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 488, whence BE 1966:400, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 316.

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Fragment from the top of a burnt white marble panel (0.17 × 0.25 × 0.08). Scratched on one face. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1983 (83.166). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary for Attalos son of Menippos
entry.summary: White marble block (1.235 × 0.635 × 0.20). Inscribed at the centre right of one face; from a complex of which this was the right hand element. There is a very slight drafting onto which some letters impinge. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1987 (87.377). Unpublished.

entry.summary: White marble block damaged at all edges (0.41 × 0.29 × 1.04). Inscribed at right edge of face; clearly part of a composite monument. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1987 (87.378). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Alypos
entry.summary: White marble block, broken to right (0.545 x 0.026 x depth not measurable), with tabella ansata (0.175). Inscribed on the face. Date: First to second centuries A.D. (lettering, nomenclature). Photo. Copied by Fellows; ? by Bailie; recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Fellows, Acct. 356-357, no. 58, whence CIG 2825b (p. 1115), Bailie, Fasc. ii 64-65 and 333, no. 85, Waddington, LBW 1644; published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 535, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 416.

entry.summary: White marble block (0.32 x 0.18 x ?). Inscribed on the face, within a panel (0.25 x 0.13). Date: first to second centuries A.D. (lettering, phonetics, nomenclature). Photo. Copied in 1705 by Sherard (f.16v) and by Picenini (10102 20v and, from Tisser, 54v, cf. also 77 ); recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Boeckh, from Sherard, CIG 2844; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 536, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 508.

Published by Henzen, from Falkener, 9, whence LBW 1641, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 525. Published by Henzen, from Falkener, 9, whence LBW 1641, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 525.

entry.summary: Fragment ? from the lower edge of a white marble block without moulding (no measurements); but perhaps cut down. Inscribed on the face. Date: First century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Museum 38). Unpublished.

entry.summary: White marble fragment without back or sides, probably from a statue base. Inscribed on the face. Date: First to second centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Museum 39). Unpublished.

entry.title: Honours for Tiberius Claudius Diogenes
entry.summary: Right side of a white marble block, statue base, broken above and below (0.287-0.23 x 0.695 x depth not measurable). Inscribed on one face, which has been pitted to facilitate covering with plaster. Date: First to second centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Copied by Kubitschek (K III, 60; Abklatsch ); recorded by Gaudin (25); by the NYU expedition. Published by Reinach, 49, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 295 .

entry.title: Honours for Adrastos
entry.summary: Block (0.91 x 0.37 x 0.46), damaged above, down the left hand side and at the lower left corner, with holes on the top for the attachment of an upper feature, inscribed on one face. The block looks like a building block and, if that is right, what stood above it may well have been another block (rather than an architectural element) both being part of the wall of the tomb implied in the text. Inscribed on the face. The inscription began on the wall or feature above, and we have no means of telling just how much of it is lost. Date: First century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Museum 57). Published by J. M. Reynolds, Honouring benefactors at Aphrodisias: a new inscription, in Aphrodisias Papers 3 (1996), 120-126, whence SEG 1996.1393, BullEp 1999.477.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Eusebes son of Menandros
entry.summary: Upper part of a white marble base without moulding (0.45 x 0.42 x 0.40). The stone was damaged above when recorded in 1904; more was missing in 1934, and it is now further damaged. Inscribed on the face. Date: First century A.D. (prosopography). Recorded by Gaudin (24); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (SBI 18). Published by Reinach, from Gaudin, REG 19, 1906, 127, no. 53; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 489, whence PHI 276.

entry.summary: Fragment from the left side of a white marble panel (0.47 × 0.52 × 0.13). Inscribed on the face. Date: First to second centuries A.D. (nomenclature). Photo. Copied by Paris and Holleaux; by K&R (no notebook reference); recorded by the NYU expedition in 1962 (catalogue no. 62.265). Published by Paris and Holleaux, BCH 9 (1885), 77-8 no. 7, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 501 .

entry.title: Imprecation formula from funerary text
entry.summary: White marble fragment with back but no edges, perhaps from a sarcophagus front (0.49 × 0.16 × 0.095). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by K&R (K III, 42 a & b); by Gaudin (125); fragment from the right end found by the NYU expedition in 1975 (75.136). Published from Gaudin's squeeze by Reinach, REG 19, 1906, 283-284, no 179, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 556.

entry.summary: Right edge fragment from a base (0.13 × 0.17 × 0.145), with no other edges. Inscribed within a moulded panel. Date: Perhaps second century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (75.144). Unpublished.

entry.title: List of prizes for a contest
entry.summary: The upper left corner of a white marble block or panel (0.275 x 0.75 x 0.14). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by an unnamed Armenian, whose copy came, via Gell and Rosius, to Boeckh. Copied by Deering (f. 6v, 28); a fragment by the MAMA expedition; found by the NYU expedition. by Boeckh from the copy sent by Rosius, CIG 2759; by Leake, from Deering 22, from which LBW 1620d, Liermann, Analecta 20a, J. Frei, De certaminibus thymelicis (Basel, 1900), 77, no.14, Pickard-Cambridge, Festivals 2, 321, no.16b; translated by T.R.S. Broughton, Economic survey of Ancient Rome IV (Baltimore, 1938), 856-7. published by J. M. R. Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA VIII.420, whence discussed by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 60; published by Roueché, PPA 53.

entry.title: Posthumous honours for Zenon son of Zenon
entry.summary: Fragment from the right hand side of a white marble statue base shaft (0.20 × 0.47 × 0.36). Inscribed on the face. The upper edge appears to survive; the text will have begun on a crowning feature. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition in 1964 (64.241). Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 500, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 334.

entry.title: Posthumous honours for nios, who has established a foundation
entry.summary: White marble statue base without moulding (0.36 × 0.79 x 0.365), broken away above and to right, damaged at left. On top, a rectangular cutting in the centre. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Under a single emperor. Photos. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (SBI 5). Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 525, whence Hellenica 13, 210 (ll. 6-7), BE 1966.403, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 336.
