entry.title: Fragment
entry.summary: Fragment of white marble panel with lower edge surviving (0.18 × 0.15 x 0.05). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1982 (82.144). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Building inscription of Melition son of Pythion
entry.summary: Two white marble architrave blocks, one complete (1.57 × 0.42 × 0.58) and one broken away at the right end and damaged above (0.99 x 0.42 x 0.59), slightly curving, both with simple moulding above and between the two fasciae. The first is inscribed on both fasciae (ll.1 and 2 on upper, l. 3 on lower), the second on the upper one only; the texts have been erased at the left end of ll. 1 and 2, and are interrupted by a bad flaw in the stone. Date: Probably first half of second century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition while clearing for the Museum (Village 11). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment of building inscription, found in village
entry.summary: White marble block with curved moulding from an entablature cornice, broken at the right end (0.99 × 0.42 × 0.59). Inscribed on one face of the two fasciae; part of the moulding has been broken away. Date: First half of second century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition (74.261). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary formula from house east of Theatre
entry.summary: Lower right corner of a panel (0.18 × 0.16 × 0.06). Inscribed on one face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1971 (71.344). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Aurelia Menandris
entry.summary: 'In urna sepulchrali' (Picenini); so a sarcophagus. No description. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (nomenclature). Recorded in 1705 by Picenini (10102, 21) whence by Sherard (10101, 32); not recorded subsequently. Published by Boeckh, CIG 2843, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 439; discussed by Reinach p.262, on no. 155 (13.156).

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Aurelius Kal[ . . .], a veteran
entry.summary: Two fragments, not adjoining, of a white marble sarcophagus, undecorated except for a wide tabella ansata, which is inscribed. a.: fragment from the upper part of the tabella, cut down for re-use, with upper moulding but no other sides suviving (0.275 × 0.26 × 0.105). b. lower part of the sarcophagus (1.89 × 0.40 × 0.69). The sarcophagus was re-used in a fountain, so the face is worn. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. b. copied by K. G. Anthopoulos, in 1872; by Choisy, in 1875; by Paris and Holleaux; by K&R (no notebook reference); recorded by the MAMA expedition. a. and b. recorded by the NYU expedition (a. catalogued as 77.153). b published by Anthopoulos, Homeros 2, 1874, 38; by Perrot, from Choisy, RA 32, 1876, 39-40, no. 5; by Paris & Holleaux, BCH 9, 1885, 81-82, no. 12, whence ILS 9477; by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 522; a and b published by Speidel & Reynolds, ' A veteran of legio I Parthica from Carian Aphrodisias', EA 5, 1985, 31-35, whence SEG 1985.1084, BE 1988.883, AnnEpig 1985.800, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 453.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for anonymous
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus 1.93 × 0.46 × 0.66 with upper edge worn away; lower moulding carved with a central rosette. Inscribed the full length of the front face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Copied by Fellows; by Reichel (R I, 27, mention at 24v); recorded by Gaudin (133); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (Sarcophagus catalogue 36). Published by Fellows, Acct. 345, no. 48, whence CIG 2850c (p. 1118); by Reinach, from Gaudin, REG 19, 1906, 284, no. 180; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 550, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 430.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Chrezimos son of Hermias
entry.summary: White marble block 0.57 × 0.32 × 0.22. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, prosopography). Photos. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published from the MAMA records by Cormack, MAMA 8, no. 537., whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 467.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Tib. Cl. Anteros
entry.summary: 'marble block' (0.097 × 0.325 × 0.13) 'complete above and below' (MAMA). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Recorded by K&R (KIII.14, Ablatsch 72); by Gaudin (171); by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 259, no. 153; by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 539, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 496.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for son of Papias
entry.summary: Fragments from a white marble sarcophagus front, with a simple moulding above. Fragment a (lines 2-11) complete to right and below (0.75 × 0.55 × 0.14); b fragment from upper edge (lines 1-3) with moulding; c fragment (left end of ll. 5 ff.) with lower edge surviving; d. fragment, without edges, lines 3-7. Inscribed on the moulding (l.1) and across the face. Date: second to early third century A.D. (lettering). Photos. a and b were still part of one stone when copied by Sterrett; a recorded by the MAMA expedition; c and d recorded by Kubitschek (KIII, 40, Abklatsch 106); ; a, b, c and d by the NYU. Published by Sterrett, Epigraphic Journey no. 9; by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 547, whence Hellenica 13, 198-204 (ll. 9-10), BE 1966.405, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 535 .

entry.title: Funerary inscription for anonymous
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus ( 2.09 × 0.84 × 0.84) with columnar arcade design. A full length male portrait in the centre, within an arch, is is flanked by two figures on either side. Those on the extreme right and the second from left hold masks; the second from the right holds a lyre; that on the extrme right apparently also holds palms. The columns between the figures uphold a cornice. Inscribed on the cornice (l. 1) and on the lower moulding (l. 2). The text must have begun on the lid. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded K&R (RI.24); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 584, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 550 .

entry.title: Funerary inscription
entry.summary: Left side of a broken white marble stele or panel with a clamp-hole in the right side (0.55 × 0.445 × 0.16). Inscribed on one face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by K&R (RI.37, KIII.4, Abklatsch 28); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (71.42). Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 590. whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 552.

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: White marble fragment 0.38 × 0.14 × 0.23, perhaps complete to left. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Copied by Reichel (1.17 and squeeze 73); recorded by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. : Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 593, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 555.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for and Aelia Aurelia Neike
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus with moulding above and below (2.03 × 0.74 × 0.76) and side pilasters. Fluted façade, with tabella ansata; there are gorgonaia on the two ends. Inscribed on the upper moulding of the tabella (l. 1), on the panel (ll. 2-14) on the lower moulding of the tabella (l. 15) and on the lower moulding of the façade (l. 16). Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, nomenclature). Photo. Copied by Texier; by Loew; by K&R (no notebook reference); recorded by Gaudin (xx); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (Sarcophagus catalogue 23). Published by Texier, As. Min. iii 165-166; by Franz, from Loew, Ann. d. Inst. 19, 1847, 114-115, no. b.10, whence LBW 1631; mentioned by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 258, no. 151; published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 568, whence BE 1966:408, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 408.

entry.title: Funerary verse
entry.summary: White marble fragment of a sarcophagus (1.15 × 0.35 × 0.45) with a bust in relief. Inscribed to the right of the bust. Date: probably Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Copied by Waddington; by K&R (no notebook entry); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (Sarcophagus catalogue 237). Published by Waddington, LBW 1648, whence Ramsay, Cities & Bishoprics 556, no. 430, Kaibel 429, Grégoire, Rec. 279, Cabrol, Dict. vol. 14, col. 796, no. 24; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 601, whence Peek, GVAK 28, no. 12, SEG 30, 1256, BE 1982:359, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 400 , Steinepigramme 02/09/93.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Aurelius Aroulios
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus lid (1.89 × 0.36 × 0.68). Inscribed in one line along the front rim and (last 6 letters) left side rim. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (nomenclature). Photo. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. Published by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 587, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 445.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Aurelius Menekrates
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus lid ; no measurements. Inscribed on the fascia of the moulded rim. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Recorded by K&R (KIII.40, Abklatsch 98); by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 581, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 456.

entry.title: Funerary fragment, re-used in Mosque
entry.summary: Fragment of white marble panel from a sarcophagus front, very worn (0.55, 0.90), with a rebate on three edges. There is a relief of a circular object in the centre below the text and a vertical object to its left. Inscribed on the face. The drawing suggests that there may have been a scroll to the left of l. 4. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, prosopography). Recorded by Kubitschek and Reichel (K iii.37), whence Cormack; not reported subsequently. Published from Kubitschek's copy by Cormack, ABSA 59 (1964), 20, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 573 .

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Meltinianos
entry.summary: Plain white marble sarcophagus (no measurements). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (sarc. catalogue 44). Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 595, whence BE 1966:413, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 507.

entry.title: Funerary inscription
entry.summary: Left side fragment of a white marble tabella ansata 0.45 × 0.305 × 0.15 . inscribed on the upper moulding (l.1) and within the panel; the surfaces are badly damaged. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (107); by the NYU expedition in 1972 (72.485). Published by Reinach from Gaudin, REG 19, 1906, 283, no. 178, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 478.

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: A fragment, ? from a white marble sarcophagus front, very worn (0.55 x 0.90). Inscribed on the face of the sarcophagus; there are designs—a circle and what looks like a shovel, below. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Recorded by Kubitschek (K III.37); not reported subsequently. Published from K's notebookx by Cormack, no. 20, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 573 .

entry.title: Funerary fragment naming Statilius Zotikos and Aelius Heliodoros
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus front, worn and hard to read; right edge apparently survives. No measurements. Apparently inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (nomenclature, lettering). Recorded by Kubitschek (III.49); not reported subsequently. Published from K's notebook (iii.49) by Cormack, no. 28, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 498 . not reported subsequently.

entry.title: Fragment from honours
entry.summary: Two joining fragments from the left side of a white marble statue base without back or edges (together 0.27 x 0.14 x 0.10). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1966 and 1971 (66.257, 71.2). Unpublished.

entry.title: Honours for Dionysios son of Mo .
entry.summary: Probably left side of small white marble base or base capital (0.175 × 0.16 × 0.255) with simple moulding above and below; resembles 400 (=70.216) etc. Inscribed in two lines on a prepared surface. Date: Perhaps second century (lettering, especially Μ). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1970 (70.225). Unpublished.

entry.title: Honours for Apollonios son of Eidaios
entry.summary: A fragment, from a white marble statue base shaft, broken to left and above; (0.27x0.58x0.20). Inscribed on the surviving face. Date: First to second centuries A.D. (lettering). Copied by Kubitschek (iii.43b) and by Reichel (R I.16, Abklatsch 11); not reported subsequently. Published from Kubitschek's notebook by Cormack 1964, no. 26.

entry.title: Honours for Claudia Paulina
entry.summary: Plain white marble base with a very slight offsetting down both sides, lacking a moulded top which might have carried the first line of the text. Broken above and below, but the lower left corner survives, and without any moulding (0.505 × 0.83 × 0.57). Inscribed on the face. Date: Probably later second to early third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU excavation in 1963 (63.434). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication by Tiberius Claudius Apollonios Aurelianos
entry.summary: Plain white marble statue base shaft (0.42 × 0.98 × 0.39), whose bottom surface has been hollowed out to form a basin with a drain hole. Top not visible. Inscribed on the face, which is chipped. Date: Late second century A.D. (lettering; nomenclature). Photos. Recorded in 1705 by Picenini (10102, f18, no. 30) whence Sherard (10101, f.29); by Kubitschek and Reichel (partial squeeze, Abklatsch 8; no notebook entry); by Gaudin (66); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Boeckh from Sherard papers, CIG 2784; by Reinach, from Gaudin, no. 36; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, 454, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 143.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription of Pereitas and Melition
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus, broken in two; a garland decoration has been hacked away, but traces of two winged figures at the corners remain; for full description see Isik 187. ll.1-12 cut on the tabella, whose mouldings have been erased, ll.13 ff on a prepared panel below. Date: Late second to early third centuries (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Village 4 ). Reynolds and Isik 187.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Monumental fragment
entry.summary: Fragment from the left side of a white marble block without moulding (0.195 × 0.34 × 0.27). Inscribed on the face. Date: ? Severan or later. (lettering). Photos. Copied by Kubitschek (iii.53, Abklatsch 100); a stray find by the NYU expedition (Museum 3). Published from Kubitschek's notebook by Cormack, no. 30.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for MMM. Aurrr. Peritianos, Eutyches and Herakleios
entry.summary: A white marble sarcophagus lid (0.30 × 2.19 × 0.99) which was intact when the MAMA expedition found it, but is now in two halves and chipped. Inscribed along the front edge. It is not obvious at what point in the sentence order to take the letters inscribed on the projecting supports beneath the rim (on which l.1 is cut); these letters are shown below between pairs of double verticals ||. Date: Third to fourth centuries (formulae, penalty). Photos. Copied hastily by Fellows in 1840; recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Fellows, no. 67 whence CIG 2850e (p.1119); by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 580, whence L. Robert, Hellenica 13, 18, BE 1966.412; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 149 and plate xxxv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 460.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: List of Jews and godfearers
entry.summary: A white marble block, tapering a little towards the top (width across faces a. and c., 0.45-0.43 × 2.80 × width across face b. 0.46-0.425). Surface smoothed on faces a., b., and c. but left roughly dressed on face d. a., concentrated on upper part of stone, with fillet (0.085 wide) down the left side and margin down the right. b., the text is arranged in two parts, separated by a sizable vacant area (0.15 in height). Date: Early third century A.D. (Reynolds/Tannenbaum, lettering); fifth century A.D. (Chaniotis, nomenclature). Photos. Found in the winter of 1975-6; recorded by the NYU expedition in 1976 (76.1). Discovery reported in K. T. Erim, AJA 81 (1977), 306 and Erim, AS 27 (1977), 31. Published by Reynolds & Tannenbaum, Jews and Godfearers at Aphrodisias principal inscription, whence BE 1988.888; SEG 1976.970, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 188 ; mentioned by K. T. Erim and J. M. Reynolds, 'Sculptors of Aphrodisias', 529-31, nos. 21, 22, 23; for discussion and full bibliography see Chaniotis, Scripta Classica Israelica 21 (2002), 209-242.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Tiberius Julius ?
entry.summary: White marble block (1.00 × 0.76 × 0.37). Inscribed on the face. Date: Early third century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Copied by Fellows; perhaps by Bailie; by Sterrett; by K&R (no notebook reference); recorded by Gaudin (23); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Fellows, Acct. 357, no. 59, whence CIG 2832b (p. 1116), Bailie, Fasc. ii 63-64, no. 84; by Sterrett, Epigraphic Journey no. 10; by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 276-277, no. 170; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, 551, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 492.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for anonymous
entry.summary: 'An inscription from a pedestal'; 'A statue base' (Bailie). Inscribed on the face. Date: ? After 212 A.D. (nomenclature). Photo. Copied by Bailie, (Researches 34 and 82: 'in truth, I may be said to have excavated in search of it, it lay so concealed in rubbish and underwood'); not reported subsequently. Published by Bailie, no 61, whence LBW 1596bis, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 349 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for anonymous, boy runner victor at the fifteenth Philemoniea
entry.summary: A white marble statue base shaft with moulded panels (0.99 x 0.40 x 0.37), chipped on all edges; there is a hole on the top for the attachment of a crowning feature. Inscribed on the face. L.1 is inscribed on the upper moulding, but was not seen by earlier copyists; the text must have begun on the crowning feature. Date: A.D. 226 (contests). Photo. Recorded by H. P. Borrell, and perhaps also by Bailie; by Le Bas; by the NYU expedition in 1976 (excavation inventory no. 76.84, SBI 63). Published, from Borrell's copy and possibly one of his own, by Bailie, no. 49; by Waddington, from Le Bas, LBW 596, whence Liermann, Analecta 25. Published by Roueché, PPA 83.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Aurelius Zenon
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus 1.95 × 0.81 × 0.78 with a central tabella ansata, supported by putti. On either side, garlands, with a bust above. See further Isik, loc. cit. a. Inscribed around the bust to the left, b. around the bust to the right, c. on the tabella; inscription c. must have begun on the lid. Date: Probably middle third century A.D. (lettering, nomenclature). Photo. Copied in 1705 by Picenini (10102, 20v and, from Tisser, f. 68) whence Sherard (10101 31v -32); by K&R (KIII.39, Abklatsch 104); part recorded by Gaudin (148; photograph only); recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (Sarcophagus catalogue 29). Published from Sherard's papers, A. Boeckh, CIG 2828, 2838; from Gaudin's squeeze, T. Reinach, REG 19 (1906), 269-270, no. 164 (part); from the MAMA records, J.M.R. Cormack, MAMA VIII. 575, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 463; Reynolds & Isik 110.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for anonymus, boy boxer
entry.summary: Apparently a statue base shaft (0.69 x 0.22), perhaps (but not certainly) in two pieces. Inscribed on the face. Date: c. 241 (contests). Photo. Recorded by Kubitschek and Reichel (K.III.33; Abklatsch 78); not reported subsequently. Published, from Kubitschek's records, by J. M. R. Cormack, ABSA 59 (1964). Published by Roueché, PPA 86.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Sculptor's signature, Alexandras
entry.summary: A fragmentary white marble foot, slightly over life-size. Inscribed round the ankle. Date: late third century (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1975 (75.2). Published by Erim-Reynolds, 'Sculptors' no.1, whence SEG 1990.924.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Cornelia Salonina
entry.summary: A white marble statue base shaft without moulding (1.04 × 0.44 × 0.45); complete, but worn along the upper edge, and pierced for later use as a well-head. Inscribed on the face; the text must have begun on a crowning feature. Date: A.D. 253-260 (reign). Photos. Copied by Loew; copied by Waddington; copied by Reichel (R.I.25); recorded by the MAMA expedition; recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Franz, no. b.6, from Loew; published by Waddington, LBW 1625; published by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, 453. Published by Roueché (1981), no. 1, whence BE 1982.357; An.Ép. 1981.765; republished by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 2, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 210.

entry.title: Acclamation for Scholastikios
entry.summary: A white marble column capital, with the bust of a man protruding from it (0.25 × 0.62 × 0.705). The head, which has been broken, interrupted the upper rim of the moulding. The inscription runs in one line on the upper rim, which is broken at the right. Date: Fourth/fifth century (lettering). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition in 1969 during destruction of village houses (69.308). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 79, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 807.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Prayer of Damocharis, cursor
entry.summary: A thick panel of blue marble (0.52 × 0.57 × 0.18) with a crack down the left side of the face. Inscribed on the face. Date: Fourth-fifth century (lettering, terminology). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1975 (75.5). Published by Reynolds & Tannenbaum, J&G, 137-138, no. 10 and plate, whence SEG 1987.852, BE 1988.888; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 116 and plate xxx, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 637.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for anonymous
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus 2.00 × 0.78 × 0.81 with a tabella ansata, flanked by garlands. For further description see Isik 142. Inscribed in the upper two thirds of the tabella, impinging on all mouldings. The text must have begun above, perhaps on the lid or the upper rim of the chest. Date: Monument: mid third century (Isik). Text: Probably fourth century (lettering, spelling, unit of reckoning, size of fine). Photos. Recorded by K&R (KIII.41, Abklatsch 41); by Gaudin (170); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published from Gaudin's squeeze, T. Reinach, REG 19, (1906) 274-6, no. 184; from the MAMA records, supplemented by the notes of Kubitschek and Reichel, J.M.R. Cormack, MAMA VIII. 578, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 576 and a comment by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity (London, 1989) p. 192; by Reynolds and Isik 142.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication by Flavius Eusebios
entry.summary: Two adjoining pieces of a white marble panel / masonry block, which is slightly concave (together, 1.35 × 0.53 × 0.24). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second quarter of the fourth century (titulature). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1974 (74.262). Published by Reynolds and Tannenbaum, 136-137, no. 9, whence SEG 1997.851, BE 1988.888; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 10, and plate iv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 606.

entry.title: Name
entry.summary: A white marble column base fragment, apparently cut down for re-use, perhaps to crown an aperture (c. 0.60 × 0.21 × 0.18). Inscribed across what was the top, is now apparently the face. Date: Fifth-sixth century or later (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition (16.IX.90). Published by Roueché (2004), 247.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Verse posthumous honours, apparently , for Asclepiodotus
entry.summary: A re-used white marble statue base (0.99 × 0.52 × 0.515) originally intended for architectural decoration; the rear face has elaborate mouldings at each side. The stone is broken at the top left corner and the right side, and the surface is worn. Inscribed on the face, which is very slightly concave as seen from the sides. Date: Late fifth century (prosopography). Photos. Apparently copied in the Byzantine period; copied by Picenini (BL Add. 10102, 20v, no. 39) whence Sherard (BL Add. 10101 f. 31); recorded by Gaudin (9); by the MAMA expedition; by J and L. Robert; recorded by the NYU expedition (SBI 70). Lines 5-8 published in Anthologia Palatina 9.704; the full text published by Boeckh, CIG 2851, from Sherard papers, whence Welcker, 'Inedita et nuper primum edita' RhM 4 (1836), 393-423, 416-418, no. 31, Kaibel EG 889; by Reinach, no. 84, from Gaudin; by Robert, Hellenica 4, 115-126, whence BE 1949.178; by Cormack, MAMA 8, no. 486, from the MAMA records, whence Robert, Hellenica 13, 170-1; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 53 and plate xiii whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 730, Steinepigramme 02/09/05.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary verse, for Asklepiodotos
entry.summary: A white marble funerary stele, cut in one piece, in the form of a pyramid surmounting a rectangular base (0.95 × 0.50 × 0.50); all four sides of the pyramid and of the base are cut as panels within moulding. The top of the pyramid is broken away, but there are traces of a hole which would have held an insertion at the apex. Line 1 is inscribed on the front panel of the pyramid, lines 2-3 within the front panel of the base. Date: Late fifth century (prosopography). Photos. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition in 1979 (79.12). Published from the MAMA records by Cormack, MAMA 8, no. 487, whence Hellenica 13, 170-171, BE 1966.399; published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 54 and plate xiii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 731, Steinepigramme 02/09/06.

entry.title: Acclamation for Pytheas
entry.summary: Upper right corner of a white marble statue base shaft without moulding (0.20 × 0.36 × 0.36) which has been re-used; the top has been hollowed out. Inscribed on the face, above which two holes have been cut. Date: Late fifth century (prosopography). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1975 (75.259). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 55 and plate xiii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 840.

entry.title: Monogram inscription
entry.summary: An octagonal white marble column base (broken, 0.76). Cut on one panel. Date: Sixth century, or later (form of monogram). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1988. Published by Roueché (2004), 244.

entry.title: Storage jar: measurement
entry.summary: A large white marble storage jar (no measurements); cracked, but complete. Inscribed on the shoulder. Date: Late imperial (context, lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 215, and plate xliv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 870 .

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Fragment (0.15 x 0.13 x 0.075) probably from the bottom of a panel - or a sarcophagus front - without edges, but showing traces of a clamp hole on the underside. Inscribed on the surviving face. l. 1, ΚΙ or Η? Only seriph of omega survives. l. 5, Only upper horizontal of Ε and Τ survive. Date: I (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1984 (84.25). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Tiberius Claudius Diadoumenos
entry.summary: A white marble block broken at the back (0.38 x 0.50 x 0.24). Inscribed on the face. Date: First to second centuries A.D. (terminology, nomenclature). Recorded by Kubitschek (K III.51, Abklatsch 103); not reported subsequently. Published from K's notebook by Cormack, no. 29 (whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 497 ), on which see L. Robert, Ant. Class. (1966) 385-6, BE 1967:545.

entry.title: Honours for an emperor, Augustus Germanicus
entry.summary: Four fragments perhaps from a white marble panel. Text i fragment b (b 0.40 × 0.42 × 0.11); text ii fragments a, b and c; text ii fragment d, broken on all sides, (0.21 × 0.42 × 0.12). Inscribed on the face in at least two, probably three, columns. Date: Flavian (titulature, lettering). Photos. a-c copied by Paris and Holleaux; a-c seen and d copied by K&R (K iii.30a, Abklatsch 67); one fragment (b) found by the NYU expedition (excavation inventory number 75.13). a-c published by Paris and Holleaux, no. 10, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 177, 178, cited by P. Veyne, Latomus 21 (1962), 94; d published, from K&R, by Cormack, ABSA no 13a, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 189.

entry.title: Dedication by Kallikles son of Kallikles via his brother Molossos

The text must have begun on a lost block or capital above. Date: Second century A.D. (prosopography). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1983 (Village 14). Unpublished.

entry.title: Honours for the father of Marcus Aurelius Polychronios, who established a foundation
entry.summary: Large statue base, broken above. Inscribed on the face. Date: Probably third century A.D. (nomenclature). Photo. Recorded by Paris and Holleaux; not reported subsequently. Published by Paris and Holleaux, BCH 9 (1885), 76-7, no. 6, whence Ziebarth no. 61, Laum no. 12, Robert in Holleaux, Et. d'épig. VI 7, no. 6 (l. 2), BE 1969.542, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 27.

entry.title: Invocation
entry.summary: 'sur un pied-droit' (Texier); it is not clear whether this refers to an upright support in the wall or to a loose column/base. No description. Date: Fourth century or later (content). Copied by Texier; not reported subsequently. Published by Texier, As. Min. iii 159, no. 3, whence Kirchhoff, CIG 8919, Ramsay, Cities & Bishoprics 554, no. 425, Grégoire, IGC 250, Cabrol, DACL. 14, col. 795, no. 19, Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 141, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 639.

entry.summary: White marble block (0.95 × 0.63 × 0.38) with a border demarcated by an incised line on three sides; the central area is hatched, as if for plastering, and perhaps once bore some decorative element to which the inscription may refer; it may be that there are traces of some letters in this area. Inscribed along the upper border and down the right border (last three letters). Date: Second to first centuries B.C. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1962 (Water Channel 2). Unpublished.

Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to first centuries B.C. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Water Channel 1, 84.10, SBI 62). Unpublished; referred to by Reynolds, A&R p.150, no.7.

entry.title: Relief panel illustrating munera
entry.summary: A white marble fragment (0.26 x 0.38 x 0.13) with part of the left edge surviving, from a relief panel with a simple raised edge. In relief, two figures of gladiators confront one another. That on the right has a long shield, and leg-guards; that on the right has a casque and body armour, and is holding a short sword in his right hand (his left is lost). No text. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (content). Photo. recorded by the NYU expedition in 1984 (excavation inventory no. 84.9). Published by Roueché, PPA 39.

entry.title: Titles for images on the funerary monument of Zoilos
entry.summary: White marble relief panels from a monumental public tomb, with sculpted figures ; 1.85; width of panels 0.75-1.30. The maximum depth of the panels is 0.40-0.50. Inscribed on the face next to the figures. Numbers for fitting the blocks survive (0.02-0.03) normally on the upper face of the blocks, but in some cases on the face. Date: Late first century A.D. (career, sculpture, lettering). Photos. 2, 3 5 and 7 recorded by A. Guiliano in 1956: other fragments recorded by the NYU expedition over several years: 1: 61.61; 4, 61.62; 8, 77.147; 9 found 1984; 12 66.234. 13 64.242. Published by Reynolds, A&R 34 whence BE 1983.391, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 895 . Republished, with the whole monument, by R. R. R. Smith, Aphrodisias I. The monument of C. Julius Zoilos (Mainz, 1993).

entry.title: Honours for Andreas, son of Androneikianos, boy runner
entry.summary: A plain statue base shaft (1.00 x 0.365 x 0.335) with a recessed edge. The upper edge survives. Inscribed (A) on the face, and (B) on the right side. The first element of the victor's name must therefore have been inscribed on a crowning feature. Date: A.D. 190 (contests). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1963 (Museum 103; SBI 3). Published by Roueché, PPA 80.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for anonymus, son of Artemidoros, boy boxer
entry.summary: A simple white marble statue base shaft (0.35 x 0.965 x 0.33) with all edges surviving, but top right corner lost. Inscribed on the face; the text presumably began on a crowning feature. Date: 190 A.D. (contests). Photo. Recorded by Paris and Holleaux; by Gaudin (106); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition in 1966 (66.103; SBI 10). Published by Paris and Holleaux, no. 2, whence Liermann, Analecta 22; cited by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, no. 144; published by J. M. R. Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA VIII.505; discussed BullEp 1972, 414; discussed by J. M. Reynolds, A&R 58, whence BullEp 1983.392. Published by Roueché, PPA 79.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for anonymous, boy runner
entry.summary: A plain statue base shaft with recessed edges (h. 0.65, w. 0.335, d. 0.335) broken above and below. Inscribed on the face. The inscription was apparently left unfinished; but it is also possible that the carver started on the familiar formula τὴν δὲ ἀ[νάστασιν τοῦ ἀνδριάντος ποιησαμένου κτλ, and then discovered that it was not required. Date: c. 196 A.D.(contests). Photo. Recorded by Paris and Holleaux; by Gaudin (105); by the MAMA expedition. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1964 (excavation inventory no. 64.238, SBI 14). Published by Paris and Holleaux, no. 3, whence Liermann, Analecta 23. Cited by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, no.145. Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA VIII.506, whence BullEp 1972.414, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 344 . Published by Roueché, Performers and Partisans 81.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Prayer of Theodoros, 'the Bell'
entry.summary: A masonry block (0.58 × 0.73 × 0.25) pierced with five holes - the largest is in the centre, surrounded by four others arranged in a square. The holes do not impinge on the text, and could conceivably form part of the original monument, but it seems more probable that the stone was re-used. The surface is worn, especially at the lower left corner. The inscription runs along the edge, below the holes. Date: Fifth-tenth century A.D. (lettering, content). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition (68.269). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 115, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 636.

entry.title: Statue dedication by Kallikrates
entry.summary: Six fragments (five adjoining) from a white marble statue base, without moulding (together 0.46 × 0.57 surviving x 0.22). Inscribed on the face. Date: Augustan (lettering very similar to 12.402, 12.701). Photos. Found by the NYU expedition in 1967 and 1971 (62.267, five fragments; 71.29, one fragment). Published by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 31, whence BE 1983.387, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 160.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Building dedication to Demos by Eupolemos son of Artemidoros
entry.summary: White marble block (0.51, no other measurements). Apparently inscribed on the face. Date: Perhaps first century B.C. to first century A.D. (lettering). Recorded by K&R (V.1a); not reported subsequently. Published by K&R, Anz. Wien. Akad. (1893), 101, no. 4, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 125.

entry.title: Fragment
entry.summary: Very rough white marble fragment of a paving stone. Inscribed in one line. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1989 (89.j). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment, first /second century
entry.summary: Fragment from a white marble architrave (0.20 × 0.18 × 0.11). Two fasciae, inscribed on the upper one. Date: Probably first to second century (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1992 (92.22). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: List of prizes for contests
entry.summary: White marble block in six fragments, two joining (C and F). No description. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (content). Seen by Sherard in 1705 (when he copied A, B, C, E, and F) and in 1716 (when he copied D, and recopied F with C) , BM ADD. 10101, 46-48v. A and B also copied by Wood in 1750 (vol.15, 46). not reported subsequently. Published by Boeckh from Sherard, CIG 2758 A-G; G is derived from the copy of C and F made in 1716. Published from CIG by Liermann, Analecta 37; see also the discussion by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 61, Wörrle, Stadt und Fest, 230-6. Published by Roueché, PPA 52.

entry.title: Fragment
entry.summary: White marble fragment with no edges. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1989 (89.h). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary verse
entry.summary: White marble building block without moulding (0.948 × 0.27 × 0.36), broken below and at the right end; surface damaged at lower left corner. Lightly inscribed on a roughly dressed surface, worn all over. The text certainly began on a block above. Date: Second century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1992 (92.2). Published by R.R..R. Smith, 'Aphrodisias 1992', KST XV-2 (1994), 355, whence BullEp 1996.385.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Aurelius high-priest
entry.summary: Part of the right end of a. white marble sarcophagus front (0.56 × 0.43 × 0.16) with relief below showing winged figures and a palm branch;. Inscribed on the upper margin, in an area which is in poor condition. Date: Second century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1969 (69.387). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment of building inscription
entry.summary: No description. No description. Date: Fourth-fifth century (lettering). Recorded by Gaudin (173); not reported subsequently. Published by Reinach, no. 220 from Gaudin, whence Grégoire, IGC 254 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 881; published by Roueché (2004), 232.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Statue and altar dedication by Titus Flavius Staberianos, doctor
entry.summary: Plain white marble statue base shaft (0.46–0.43 × 0.83 × 0.445–0.43). Inscribed on one face within a panel outlined by an incised line. Below is a slightly rougher area clearly not intended to be visible. The text must have begun on a crowning feature. Date: First to second centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Found by the NYU expedition in 1974 (74.255; SBI 46). Published by Nutton, PBSR 45, 1977, 192, no. 1, whence SEG 1977.716; Horsley, New Documents 2, p. 11, ad no. 2a , McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 163.

entry.title: Funerary fragment; I cent., from stone dump
entry.summary: Fragment of a white marble sarcophagus front, fluted 0.37 × 0.0225 × 0.085. Inscribed on the face within a moulded panel of which only the upper right corner survives. Date: Perhaps first century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1974 (74.145). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Zenon
entry.summary: White marble block: fragment 0.31 x 0.78 x 0.30. Inscribed on the face. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (terminology). Recorded by Fellows. Bailie gives a location not in Fellows, which suggests that he did see this stone; K&R saw a fragment of lines 1-4 ( K V.8, Abklatsch ; see Cormack, Notes, fig. 10) ; not reported subsequently. Published by Fellows, no. 53, whence CIG 2836b; by Bailie, Fasc. ii 56-58 and 324-325, no. 80, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 538 ; by Laum, 109; referred to, Arch. Delt. 1921/22, 294.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Ateimetos Petignas
entry.summary: A white marble columnar statue base shaft with moulding at top and bottom (1.12, diam. 0.48); there is a channel (0.095) down one side from just below the upper moulding to the bottom, and a clamp hole cut in the lower moulding approximately opposite it. Inscribed on two sides with almost identical texts each within a raised tabella ansata. Date: First century A.D. possibly Julio-Claudian (lettering). Photos. Recorded by Gaudin, 61 and 64; by the NYU expedition (88.6; SBI 39). Published from Gaudin by Reinach, i 41, ii 42 (whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 432 and 433).

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for a priest of Athena Polias
entry.summary: A very badly worn block perhaps a statue base); perhaps complete at the left in some places. Inscribed on one face. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (terminology). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (179); not reported subsequently. Published from Gaudin by Reinach, 83, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 351.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment
entry.summary: A white marble block (0.38 x 0.59 x 0.39) with a moulding or a rim lost above. There is a clamp hole at the right end. Inscribed on a slightly concave surface—could be the riser of a seat. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Walls 152). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Building dedication to Aphrodite
entry.summary: White marble architrave block (2.24 × 0.405 × 0.636) with cornice and three fasciae (0.125, 0.10 and 0.01), and face and simple intercolumniar decoration below. Inscribed on the uppermost fascia. Date: Late first century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Part copied by Kubitschek (K iii.47, Abklatsch 40). Found again by the NYU expedition (catalogue no. 88h). Published by Cormack, fromKubitschek, 27, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 136; mentioned L. Robert, Ant. Class (1966) 391.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for anonymous
entry.summary: Fragment from a white marble statue base capital (H. 0.22, W. 0.60, D. 0.76) with moulding on at least 3 sides. Reichel describes it as 'Pilasterkapitell', but the measurements do no bear this out. Inscribed on two fasciae of the moulding. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by Reichel (R. i.40; Abklatsch 57); not reported subsequently. Published from Reichel's copy by Cormack, ABSA 59 (1964), 43, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 377 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Chaireas
entry.summary: White marble block with moulding chipped away above (0.515 × 0.75 × 0.46). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by Kubitschek (III, 44) and noted by Reichel (I, 16v)l; by the MAMA expedition; and by the NYU expedition in 1973. Published from the MAMA records by Cormack, MAMA 8, no. 466 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 263.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Right side of a white marble console (0.28 × 0.40 × 0.38). Inscribed on a panel sunk within a moulded frame, with S shaped motifs in relief at the side. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1990 (90.r). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary formula fragment
entry.summary: Feature with traces of pediment above and moulding below (0.51 × 0.20 × 0.35). Inscribed on one face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1968, brought in in 1970 (70.219). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Letters from Hadrian to the city
entry.summary: A white marble panel, with a simple moulding (0.035) on all sides (0.815 × 0.89 × 0.075); the upper left corner and the lower part are lost, and the stone is broken across the centre. Inscribed on the face. Date: 119-125 (titulature). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1994 (94.46). Published by Reynolds, JRA (2000), nos 1-4, whence SEG 50 2000.1096. Comments by D. Campanile, ZPE 135 (2001) 136-138, whence SEG 51 2001.1491.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Neikopolis and her children
entry.summary: Fragment from a white marble sarcophagus front 0.65 × 0.51 × 0.125, with the right side of a panel (0.29 × 0.37) supported by a winged putto. l. 1 on what survives of the rim, ll. 2-13 within the tabella, of which only part of the right side survives. If the standard formulae were completed the text was probably concluded on the lower moulding of the chest. Date: Perhaps first half of the third century A.D. (lettering, spelling). Photo. Recorded by the MAMA expedition, who appear to have conveyed it to the temple; by the NYU expedition, before 1966. Published by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 542, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 543 (both omitting l.1); Reynolds and Isik 155.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Lucius Egnatius Victor Lollianus, proconsul
entry.summary: White marble statue base shaft ( 0.55 x 1.22 x 0.55) with fully cut moulded panels on three sides and a roughed out moulding at the back, chipped along all edges; there are clamp holes on top for the attachment of a crowning cornice which no doubt carried a statue and was also inscribed. Inscribed on one face (panel 0.385 x 1.04). Date: 241-248 (career). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition in 1988 (88.7; SBI 40). Published by Reynolds in Y. Le Bohec ed, L’Afrique, la Gaule la Religion à l’époque romaine: Mélanges Le Glay (Brussels, 1994), 675-80, 675-6, whence BullEp 1996.39, SEG 44, 1994.863.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Monograms of donors, Mamas and Pakos
entry.summary: Two flat-sided white marble column capitals, each inscribed on the long side, a: H. 0.55, W. 1.10; b: H. 0.50, W. 1.20. Arranged around a cross. Date: Sixth century A.D., or later (form of monogram). Photos. Rcorded by the NYU expedition in 1983. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 103 and plate xxvii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 629, 630.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Gladiator memorial for Secundus
entry.summary: A white marble altar-stele with moulding above and below on three sides (0.865 x 0.43 x 0.37). The relief, worn, is of a gladiator with a long shield, advancing to his left; his right arm is bent, but whatever it held is lost. On the face in front of the figure is the outline of ?a palm branch. Inscribed on the face. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (content). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. published by Roueché, PPA 35.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Gladiator memorial for Menandros, bestiarius
entry.summary: A white marble altar-stele with moulding above and below on three sides (0.81 x 0.43 x 0.355). The relief, very worn, is of a bestiarius facing towards his left, from where a beast - - ?a bear - - is springing up at him. Inscribed on the face. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (content). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition. published by Roueché, PPA 36.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Gladiator memorial for [ . . .]pes, bestiarius
entry.summary: A white marble altar-stele with moulding above and below on three sides (0.80 x 0.37 x 0.37) The relief, which is largely lost, is of a bestiarius standing, facing to his right; one arm can be made out, held behind his back. He confronts a creature, which is jumping up at him. Above the man's head is a triangular area in relief, from which all features have been lost. Inscribed on the face. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (content). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1973; brought into the Museum in 1985. Published by Roueché, PPA 37.

entry.title: Fragment
entry.summary: Piece from lower left corner of a white marble moulded panel without edges (0.19 x0.30 × 0.095). Inscribed on the die and (l.7) on the lower moulding. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1990 (90.f). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Fragment of white marble sarcophagus moulding (0.605 x 0.195 x 0.23). Inscribed on the moulding. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Village 8). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Fragment of a white marble sarcophagus lid (0.36 x 0.50 x 0.70). Inscribed on hanging projection, and also above. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1988 (Village 17). Unpublished.

entry.title: Gladiator memorial for familia of Zenon Hypsikles
entry.summary: A white marble block with a decoration of three simple acroteria above a recessed panel within a simple moulding. Inscribed on panel, and on lower moulding (l.8). It is not clear where the last line would have been inscribed. Date: ?Late first/ early second century (lettering, prosopography). Photo. Copied by Fellows; recorded by the NYU expedition (excavation inventory no. 76.192). Published by Fellows, no. 20, whence CIG 2759b, Liermann, Analecta 5, Robert, Gladiateurs no. 157; discussed by Baunack, RM 38 (1883), 299, Robert, 'Πυκτεύειν', RA 30 (1929), 24-41, 28 (= OMS I, 691-708, 695). Published by Roueché, PPA 14.

entry.title: Posthumous honours for Muon and Peritas
entry.summary: No description. The masonry block on which this was inscribed formed part of a tomb (μνημεῖον, I, 14). No description. Date: 98-117 A.D. (priesthoods, reign). copied by Sherard in 1716 (BM Add. 10101, 123-125). Not reported subsequently. Published by Boeckh, from Sherard papers, CIG 2771, whence Liermann, Analecta VIII, p.47ff, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 511 (i) and 522 (ii).

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Fragment from the lower edge of a white marble sarcophagus (0.11 × 0.18 × 0.10). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Museum 73). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Fragment from the base of a white marble sarcophagus front (0.44 × 0.43 × 0.21). Inscribed on three fasciae of moulding. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1988 (Village 16). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Lower right hand corner white marble fragment 0.40 × 0.33 × 0.34 from a sarcophagus base. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Walls 143). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for M. Aurelius Stephanos
entry.summary: A white marble bench-like feature, still partly buried, with flange above 0.46 × 0.445 × 1.32. Inscribed on the exposed short end (which tapers from 0.46 to 0.29). In its original position, as part of a tomb, it adjoined a stone to the right (at the back of the bench) on which the text continued; that stone was apparently wider below than above. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (DM; Walls 157). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication by M.. Fl. Antonius Lysimachos
entry.summary: White marble statue base capital. Inscribed on two fasciae with approx 3 lines of moulding between them. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, prosopography). Photo. Recorded by Paris & Holleaux; by Gaudin (67); by the NYU expedition. Published by Paris & Holleaux, BCH (1885), no. 11; from Gaudin's squeeze by Reinach, 63, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 85 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Fragment of a fluted white marble sarcophagus front (1.06 x 0.81 x 0.03). Inscribed on the upper moulding, which is very worn. Date: Probably second half of second century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1988 (Village 15). Unpublished.

entry.title: Honours for Rhodopaios, for the third time
entry.summary: A white marble statue base shaft, now in at least 7 fragments, with panels within moulded edges on three sides; the back is lost (approx. 0.88 × 0.59 × 0.34). Inscribed on upper moulding (l.1) and face (ll. 2ff.) of central panel. The last letters of ll. 5 and 13 are cut on the moulding. Date: Sixth century(prosopography, titulature). Photos. The complete block copied by Sherard in 1716 (BL Add. 10101, f. 122-3). Six fragments found by the MAMA expedition. Four of those fragments, and one other, found by the NYU expedition (Museum 151). Published from Sherard by Boeckh, CIG 2804, whence Robert, Hellenica 4, 128, BE 1949.178; from the MAMA records by Cormack, MAMA 8, no. 504, whence BE 1966.401; published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 87 and plate xxii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 672.

entry.title: Text at an entrance
entry.summary: Two blue marble columns (diam. 0.53 × i: H. 0.85, ii: H. 3.62). i: Inscribed at 0.37 above base. ii: repaired in antiquity at the right. Inscribed at 0.96 above the lower end. Date: Sixth-tenth century A.D. (monogram). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 219, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 879, 880.

entry.title: Voussoir fragment
entry.summary: Apparently a white marble voussoir block, 'Wölbungstück (eines Bogens?') ? complete (0.88 x 0.65 above, 0.44below, x 0.10). Inscribed on the front face. Date: No date possible. Recorded by Kubitschek and Reichel (K iii.6; Abklatsch 76); not reported subsequently. Published from Kubitschek by Cormack, ABSA 59 (1964), no. 5, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 958 .

entry.title: Honours for an anonymous contest-president
entry.summary: White marble statue base shaft fragment (0.86 x 0.17 x at least 0.15; the right side apparently survived (K&R) but the alignment on the squeeze and the drawing suggests that the right ends of the lines are not all complete. Inscribed on the face. Date: First century A.D. (content). A fragment copied by Kubitschek, but not published (K III.11a, Ablatsch 3); recorded by Gaudin (no number given). Published from Gaudin by Reinach, 106, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 352 ; by Roueché, PPA 49.

Recorded by K&R (KIII.11, Abklatsch 6); by Gaudin (94); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 215, no. 103; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 483, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 310.

entry.title: Posthumous honours for Ammia daughter of Attalos
entry.summary: A white marble statue base, without moulding, of which only fragments survive. Inscribed on the face. Date: First century A.D. (lettering). Photos. The complete stone was copied by Sherard in 1705 (10101, 43) and by Falkener; one fragment, c (ends of lines 12-22) was copied by Kubitschek (KIII.13a, Abklatsch 1) and recorded by Gaudin (92); b (ends of lines 5-10), and a small fragment of c were recorded by the MAMA expedition; b, c, and a further fragment, a (ends of lines 1-4), were recorded by the NYU expedition. Complete text published by Boeckh, from Sherard, CIG 2814, corrected by Henzen, from Falkener, Ann. d. Inst. 23, 1852, 120, no. 3, republished by Liermann 100-101, no. 18; b published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 214-215, no. 102, discussed by Cormack, Notes 13-14 and 59 fig. 7; full text published by Cormack, from the MAMA records and from K&R, MAMA 8, no. 528, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 231.

Published by Boeckh from Sherard papers, CIG 2756; published by Cormack from the MAMA record, MAMA 416, whence Robert, Hellenica XIII, 116-9, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 920 .

entry.title: Honours probably for Kallikrates son of Molossos
entry.summary: Part of a white marble stele, broken away above and to the left (0.55 × 1.05 × 0.12-0.15). with a relief below of a lion apparently with hind legs on a base, a dog below, and a winged victory to the right, her hand upholding the lower right corner of a moulded panel. Inscribed on the moulded panel above. Date: Late first or early second century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1979 (Museum 49). Unpublished.

entry.title: Gladiator memorial for Patroklos
entry.summary: A white marble altar-stele, with simple moulding above on three sides, and below on face (0.88 x 0.36 x 0.34). Relief on the face (damaged) of a gladiator advancing to his left. He has body armour, boots, and a helmet with a crest, and holds a long shield in front of him; his sword arm is lost. Inscribed on the face, above a relief. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, content). Photos. Copied by Reichel (R.I.10) with 12.15, 12.16 and by Kubitschek (K.IV, endpaper); recorded by the NYU expedition. mentioned by Kubitschek and Reichel, no.2, whence Robert, Gladiateurs, no. 159; published from Reichel's notes by Robert, Hell. V, 93-5. Published by Roueché, PPA 26.

entry.title: Gladiator memorial for Xanthos
entry.summary: A white marble altar-stele, with simple moulding above on three sides, and below on face only (H. 0.85, W. 0.36, D. 0.40). On the face is a relief (damaged) of a gladiator (retiarius); he has body armour and ?a helmet; he holds the trident in both hands, across his body, facing left. Inscribed on the upper moulding. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, content). Photos. Copied by Kubitschek (K V 21), and by Reichel (R.I.11) with 12.13, 12.16; recorded by the NYU expedition. mentioned by Kubitschek and Reichel, no.2, whence Robert, Gladiateurs, nos 158, 159, and 160; published from Reichel's notes by Robert, Hell. V, 93-5. Published by Roueché, PPA 25.

entry.title: Gladiator memorial for [?Margar]eites
entry.summary: A white marble altar-stele, with moulding above and below (H. 0.88, W. 0.43, D. 0.38). The relief is of a heavily armed gladiator, with a short sword in right hand, a long shield in the left, and a crested helmet, advancing to the right. Inscribed on the upper moulding, which is broken. Date: Second to third centuries A.D.(content, lettering). Recorded by Reichel (R.I.21) with 12.15, 12.13 and by Kubitschek (K.III, endpaper); not reported subsequently. Mentioned by Kubitschek and Reichel, no.2, whence Robert, Gladiateurs, no 160; published from Reichel's notes by Robert, Hell. V, 93-5. Published by Roueché, PPA 27.

Eck, ZPE 42 (1981), 235-6, whence SEG 1981.902, BE 1981.517.

entry.title: a: Funerary inscription and b: consolatory decree
entry.summary: White marble block (1.37 × 0.60 × 1.37) complete on all sides. a: is inscribed at the left side of the stone, and must have continued from an adjacent block; b: is inscribed to the right and must have continued onto the next block. Both texts must have begun on upper blocks. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Copied in 1705 by Picenini (10102, 13v and 53) and by Sherard, (10101, 24); by Fellows; by Waddington in 1850; by K&R (no notebook entry); recorded by Gaudin (130); recorded by the MAMA expedition. Published by Boeckh, from Sherard, CIG 2836 and 2776; by Fellows no. 52 and 28, whence CIG p. 1111, (b) Bailie, no. 55; Waddington, LBW 1633a and 1633b, whence discussed by Buresch, 'Die griechische Trostbeschlüsse', RhM 49, 1894, 424-460, 428-429, by O.Gottwald, 'Zu den gr. Trostbeschlüssen,', Commentationes Vindobonenses 3 (1937), 5-18, 10, by L. Robert, Ét. Anat. 102; mentioned by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, no. 11a and 11b; published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, nos. 541 (a) and 409 (b), whence L. Robert, Hellenica 13, 208, 231 (b ll. 3-4, 9), BE 1966.383, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 427 and 22.

entry.title: Letter from Iulius Celer, quaestor, and petition to the emperor Trajan.

Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1969 (69.364). Published by Reynolds, A&R 52 whence BE 1983:391; AnnEpig 1984.881, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 66 and 139.

entry.title: Testament of Attalos Adrastos
entry.summary: White marble block (broken) with projections at both ends (0.645 x max. 1.415 x max. 0.35). Inscribed on front and sides, a on the left side, b on the face, of the left projection; c on the centre panel (0.85); d on the face and e on the right side of the right projection. Date: a-d: A.D. 117/138; e A.D. 117/150 (content). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (35); by the MAMA expedition in 1934; not reported subsequently. Published by Reinach from Gaudin, 138, 139, 140, 141, whence Laum, no. 102.1-4; c only published from Gaudin's squeeze, Robert, La Carie II 232-234, no. 148, whence BE 1955.200, BullEp 1956.277; published by Cormack from the MAMA records, no. 413.a-e, whence BullEp 1966.385, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 140, 141, 142; cf. Hellenica XIII 119-125, 176-7.

entry.title: Honours for C. Julius Longianos, poet
entry.summary: Three texts, all inscribed on a single white marble block; the block (0.81 x 0.77) has an area of rough tooling along the lower edge, which breaks into iii.16, suggesting that there was a moulding below, which was broken away to fit the stone for use in the wall (as is found on other re-used blocks in the wall). The stone must come from a composite monument of some kind, perhaps the wall of a building. The texts of i and ii must have started on the blocks above, and most of i, with much of iii was inscribed on a block to the left. i and ii both contain twenty-six lines, but these are not completely aligned with one another; l.26 of i ends on the same line as the first line of iii, while l.26 of ii ends above it; this probably indicates that the three documents were not inscribed simultaneously (although the lettering shows no marked variations). Date: iii: 127 A.D. (consuls). Photos. First recorded by Waddington, using a ladder, in 1850; by Gaudin (96). Copied, squeezed and measured by the MAMA team. Photographed and read with binoculars by the NYU expedition. Published by Waddington, LBW 1618 (i and ii), 1619 (iii), whence Curtius, Arch.Zeit. 3 (1870), 104, Lüders, Dionysische Künstler, no. 95. Described by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, 10. Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA VIII. 418, on which see Robert, Hell. XIII, 173-4. Published by Roueché, PPA 88.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Posthumous honours for Tiberius Claudius Ktesias, who established a foundation
entry.summary: White marble block, with moulding (later cut away for re-use) below, perhaps cut away to the left (0.90 × 1.32 x depth not measurable). The text is inscribed on the face and must have begun on an adjacent block, or on a section of this block which has been cut away. Date: Second half of the second century, perhaps already into the third century, on the basis of the β (lettering). Photos. Recorded by Falkener; by Waddington; by K&R (no notebook reference); by Gaudin (101); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Henzen, from Falkener, Ann. d. Inst. 23, 1852, 132-133, no. 8; by Waddington, LBW 1603, whence Ziebarth, ZVRW 16, 1903, 292, no. 63, Laum, no. 110; mentioned by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 131-132, no. 60; published by Cormack from the MAMA records and from Kubitschek and Reichel, MAMA 8, no. 497, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 298.

entry.title: Honours for Attalos son of Pytheas and Tatas daughter of Diodoros
entry.summary: A large white marble block from a composite monument (1.12 × 1.38 × depth not measurable). Text i ends at the left side of the block; text ii occupies the centre, and text iii starts at the right end of the block. A further fragment, (0.17 × 0.32 × 0.35) contained the ends of iii, lines 1-7. Inscribed on the face. Date: Late second century A.D. (lettering). Photos. ii recorded by Sherard (10101, 11v) and Picenini (10102, 18v) in 1705; i, ii and iii by Deering (p.13); by Falkener; by Waddington; by K&R (no notebook entry); by Gaudin (103); by the MAMA expedition, together with a further fragment (iii, ends of lines 1-7); by the NYU expedition. ii published by Boeckh from Sherard, CIG 2820; I, ii and iii published by Henzen, from Falkener, Ann. d. Inst. 23, 1852, 127-131, no. 7; by Waddington, LBW 1602, whence ii, Liermann 99-100, no. 17; by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 143-144, no. 76; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 492, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 246, 328, 267.

Published by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 494, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 413.

entry.title: Honours for ?, son of Apollonios, victor in a contest for sculptors at the first celebration of the Lysimachea Tatianea
entry.summary: A plain statue base shaft, complete on all sides (1.06 x 0.58). Inscribed on the face; the text must have begun on a crowning feature. Date: early third century (contests). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (97); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, no. 147, whence M. Squarciapino, La scuola di Afrodisia (Rome, 1943) 11, no.1; by J. M. R. Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA VIII.519; by K. T. Erim and J. M. Reynolds, 'Sculptors of Aphrodisias', 529-31, no. 17; by Roueché, PPA 76. Discussed by T. Ritti, Rend. Acad. Lincei (1971), 189-97, on which see BullÉp 1972.414; by M. Donderer in Fremde Zeiten. Festschrift für Jürgen Borchhardt (Vienna, 1996), 329-38, with BullÉp 1997.94.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Diomedes and Neikephoros
entry.summary: Apparently two texts on one monument, which was a block: ' in lapide quadrato'. No description. Date: Third century A.D. (nomenclature). Copied by Picenini in 1705 (10102.15v and, from Tisser, 62), whence Sherard (10101, 25v); not reported subsequently. Transcribed, less well than usually, by Müller, whence published by Boeckh, CIG 2835, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 469 (A), 458 (B) .

entry.title: Honours for the proconsul, Sulpicius Priscus
entry.summary: A white marble statue base; no measurements.. Inscribed on the face. Date: A.D. 222/235 (reign). Recorded by Gaudin (161); not reported subsequently. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 84, no. 4, whence Abbott & Johnson, no. 138, Veyne, Mél. Piganiol 1395-1396, BE 1967.554; by Reynolds, from Gaudin, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 47, whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.391, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 327 .

entry.title: Letter from a proconsul to Aphrodisias.
entry.summary: White marble statue base shaft. Inscribed on two adjacent faces. Date: A.D. 222-235 (reign). Recorded by Gaudin (59); not recorded subsequently. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin, REG 19, 1906, 84-87, no. 5, whence Abbott & Johnson, no. 137, Robert, Ét. Anat. 303; from all these by Reynolds, A&R 48 whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.391, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 71 .

entry.title: Honours for Antonius Antiochos, boy boxer
entry.summary: No description; probably a statue base shaft. No description; the dedicating authority may have been named on a crowning feature. Date: A.D. 226 (contests). Photo. Copied in 1716 by Sherard (BM ADD. 10101, 125v); not reported subsequently. Published by Boeckh, from Sherard, CIG 2812, whence Liermann, Analecta 24; referred to by Oikonomos, Arch.Delt. (1921/22), 293. Published by Roueché, PPA 84.

entry.title: Honours for anonymous, contest-president for life of the Gordianea Attalea
entry.summary: No description. No description. Date: Third century, after 238 (titulature). Copied by Sherard in 1705 (BM Add. 10101, f. 28, 10102, 18 and 53v); not reported subsequently. Published from Sherard by Boeckh, CIG 2801, whence Liermann, Analecta 29, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 578 . Published by Roueché, PPA 56 .Discussed, Ramsay, CBP, 366, n.3; L. Robert, Rev. de Phil. (1934) 286, n.1, Et.Anat., 165, n.3, Bull.Ep. 1978.491.

entry.title: i. Honours for Flavius Constantius, governor, for building the wall; ii. Flavius Ampelios restores the gate
entry.summary: A white marble lintel block with egg and dart moulding above two stepped fasciae (0.75 × 4.95 × 0.95); the condition of the stone appears not to have altered since it was first recorded. i. is cut on the upper fascia, and ii. on the lower. A cross flanked by an alpha and an omega within a circle was later cut over i., probably at the time that ii. was cut, or perhaps when it was emended. Date: i: A.D. 365/370 (titulature) ii (and i.b): Mid fifth century (titulature, prosopography). Photos. Copied in 1705 by Sherard (BM Add. 10101, f. 11); by Wood; by Sestini; by von Richter; by Deering; perhaps by Texier; by Fellows; probably by Bailie (since he gives the wrong line divisions, different from those in earlier editions, the mistake may originate in his own note-book); copied by Le Bas; by Kubitschek and Reichel; recorded by Gaudin (1); by the MAMA expedition; by L. Robert; by the NYU expedition. Published by Sestini (Viaggi, 113); by F. Graese from Gell (Act. Acad. Petrop. VIII, 706); by Francke from Gell and von Richter, 428 nos. 74 and 75; by Boeckh, CIG 2745, 2746, from all these and the Sherard papers, whence Texier, As. Min. iii 159, no. 2; cited by Fellows,pp. 35-6, no. 17; published by Bailie, Fasc. ii 16-17 and 272-274, no. 45; by Waddington, from Le Bas, LBW 593, 594; cited by Kubitschek and Reichel (Anz. Wien. Akad. 1893, p. 103); published from Gaudin's squeeze, Reinach, REG 19, 1906, 227-230, no. 136, whence Grégoire, Rec. 270; cited and a photograph published by Robert, Hellenica 4, 61 note 2 and 130 note 5, whence BE 1949.178, BE 1956.277; published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 427; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity nos. 22 (i), 42 (ii) and plate vi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 609, 619.
