entry.title: Decree of honours for Kallikrates son of Diogenes,pancratiast
entry.summary: A plain white marble statue base shaft (0.84 x 0.465 x 0.50) without moulding, broken above; the right side has been damaged since it was recorded by Loew and Gaudin. Inscribed on the face; the text must have started on a crowning feature. Date: 117-138 (reign). Photos. Copied by Loew. Part (lines 14-33, right end) recorded by Kubitschek and Reichel (RI, 45; Abklatsch 55);recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Recorded by H. Wankel, and by the NYU expedition. Published from Loew by Franz, p. 112, no. b.4, whence LBW 1620, Liermann, Analecta 13, Lüders, Dionysische Künstler no.96. Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records and Reichel's record, MAMA VIII.417, revised by Robert, Hell. XIII, 134-47. Observations by R. Merkelbach, ZPE 6 (1970), 47-9 (on which BullÉp 1971.614), ZPE 13 (1974), 276 (on which BullÉp 1974.535), 31 (1978), 134 (on which BullÉp 1979.447). Published by H. Wankel, I.Eph. Ia, no.11; by Roueché, PPA 89.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Aba
entry.summary: White marble block (0.41 x 0.37 x depth not measurable). The upper left corner and all edges are chipped, and there is a crack across the lower right corner. Inscribed on the face, within a partly smoothed area. Date: First century B.C. to first century A.D.(lettering). Photo. Copied by Radet; by Reichel (R.I.36a); recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Radet, BCH 14, 1890, 237, no. 12; published by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 532, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 402 , Robert, BCH 107 (1983), 505.

entry.title: Honours for female stephanephorus
entry.summary: White marble base, weathered (0.25 × 0.75), possibly broken away above, damaged down left side, slightly moulded down right side. Inscribed on the exposed face. Date: First century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by K&R. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Walls 8). Unpublished.

entry.title: Decree of honours for Aristokles Molossos
entry.summary: A text in four parts, apparently on three or four blocks. Measurements of a. given by Kubitschek: (0.53 x 0.78 x 0.19; of c. given by Anthopoulos (0.46 x 0.79 x 0.12) and Reichel ( 0.40 x 0.37 x 0.08). Inscribed on the face, in columns. Date: First century A.D. (content). a. seen by Wood (14 p.46); A-D copied in 1813 by Deering (p. 10v-11v, no. 37); b. was squeezed (in two parts) by Fellows, but no text published, see 60 & 61; a.-c. copied by Falkener; b. and c. copied by Loew; c. copied at Aphrodisias by Waddington in 1850 and at ; d. copied at Pirlibey in 1872, by K. G. Anthopoulos and in 1893 by Reichel (R.I.3); a., severely damaged in re-use, copied at Aphrodisias by Kubitschek (KIII.20). a.-d. published by Leake, from Deering, no. 14. b. mentioned by Fellows 60 & 61; A-C by Henzen, from Falkener, no. 5; b. and c. by Franz, from Loew, b.3; a.-d. by Waddington, LBW 1611. c. by K. G. Anthopoulos, Homeros III (1875) 80, whence Papadopoulos, Ath.Mitt. (1880) 340 no. 12, and cf. L. Robert, Hellenica 13, 114; cf Cormack, Notes, from notebooks, fig. 13. From these published by Laum, no.100, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 32 . Discussed: Liermann p.24, Wilhelm, Neue Beiträge II, 49, L. Robert, Rev. de Phil. (1930) 27 n.1, Bull. Ep. 1953.187, whence SEG 13, 491, SEG 1980.1244.

Inscribed on the front on two fasciae: l. 1 above moulding, ll. 2-4 below. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Walls 120); Lines 2-4 copied in 1975, line 1 in 1976. Unpublished.

entry.summary: Upper part of a white marble base with heavy moulding above (0.030) and traces of a moulding below. Inscribed (l.1) on the upper fascia and (ll.2 ff.) on the face, which is badly chipped. One loose fragment joins to provide the end of ll. 2-4. Date: Second century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Walls 121). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Julius Aurelius Charidemos Ioulianos
entry.summary: Fragments of a white marble block a: Left side fragment 0.94 × 0.745 × 0.36; b: upper right side fragment (1.75 0.55 x 0.34) c: lower left corner fragment (0.46 × 0.195 × 0.115). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (nomenclature, lettering). Photos. The complete text copied by Sherard in 1716 (f.126v) and Rochette; by Deering ( f 6v, no.27); by Fellows (perhaps by Bailie); by Choisy. Fragment of ll. 7-9 copied by K&R (R.I.6); fragment recorded by Gaudin (no number); three larger fragments (a, b and c) recorded by the MAMA expedition (all discussed by Cormack, Notes 17 and 62 fig. 11); a and b recorded by the NYU expedition in 1972. Published by Boeckh, from Sherard and Rochette, CIG 2845; by Fellows, Acct. 343-344, no. 47, whence CIG p.1117, Bailie, Fasc. ii 58-59 and 325-331, no. 81, Liermann 144, n. 3 ; fragment published by Reinach, REG 19, 1906, 279 no. 173 and 291 no. 197; published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 564, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 490 ; discussed by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 40.

Published by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, 419, whence Robert Hellenica 13, 125-126, BE 1966.390. entry.title: Honours for Marcus Aurelius Gaitulikos
entry.summary: Fragment from the left side of a white marble statue base without moulding (0.20 × 0.50 × 0.20); surface is lost at the left. Inscribed on one face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. The whole text copied by Sherard in 1716 (10101, 128). A fragment, lines 2-6, copied by Kubitschek (K.V.18) and found by the NYU expedition in 1988. Full text published by Boeckh, from Sherard, CIG 2800, whence Oikonomos, ArchDelt 7, 1921-1922, 293 and 296, no. 6; by Reynolds, from Sherard, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 56, whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.391, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 257; fragment unpublished.

entry.summary: Fragment from the left side of a white marble statue base (H. 0.74, W. 0.58, D. 0.27) with moulding surviving to left. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by Reichel (unpublished R I, 7, and squeeze 45); recorded by Gaudin (38b); recorded in 1934 (so Cormack, Notes p.36) but not published in MAMA; recorded by the NYU expedition. entry.title: Honours for Aelius Aurelius Menandros
entry.summary: A statue base shaft apparently with moulded panels. A fragment from the base capital survives (0.25 x 0.25 x 0.22). Inscribed on three faces: a (Text i, 7 ff.), b and c (Text ii) (from left to right). i, ll.1-6 are on the base capital fragment, inscribed on three fasciae of the moulding (ll.1-2, l.3, l.4) which are broken away at both ends, and on the face below (ll.5-6) which is broken to the right. While it cannot be proved beyond doubt that this is the opening of i, it seems overwhelmingly likely. It is implied, at least in Fellows' description, that l.7 was the first line of the base; if so, the last line of the capital can be considered to precede it immediately. The opening letters of ll.19, 27, 29-32 appear to have been cut on the moulding. Date: A.D. 138-69 (emperor). Photo. a and b copied (and a squeeze taken) by Fellows; a, b, and c copied by Deering (8v-10, nos. 34, 35 and 36); copied by Loew; by Falkener. A fragment (h. 0.42, w. 0.22, d. 0.26) from the upper left side of I, lines 10-21 copied by Reichel (R I, 38, Abklatsch 56), and by the MAMA expedition. a and b published by Fellows, as nos 21 and 22 whence CIG 2811b, 2810b; a, b, and c published by Leake, from Deering, nos 12 and 13a & 13b; from these LBW 1620a (i) and 1620b (ii). a and b published (apparently from Fellows) by Bailie, no. 248. Corrections noted by Franz, from Loew, nos a.7 and a.8; observations by Henzen, from Falkener, no.2. From all these i and ii published by Liermann, Analecta 15 and 16, ii by Moretti, IAG 72 (both with mistaken line divisions for c). Published by Cormack, from Kubitscheck and Reichel and the MAMA expedition, MAMA VIII. 421, on which see Robert, Hell. XIII, 147-54. Published from all these and surviving fragment, Roueché, PPA 91.

Complete block recorded by Sherard in 1716 (10101.129); two fragments by Reichel (I.39); a third fragment by the NYU expedition in 1980. Published by Boeckh (from Sherard), CIG 2742, whence Liermann, Analecta, 114. Fragments identified by Cormack, Notes 7 and 55 fig. 2, whence BullEp 1970.538. Anat. 314-319 and BE 1938.396.

entry.title: Honours for the People of Keretapa
entry.summary: Fragment of a white marble statue base without moulding, (0.94 x 0.30 x 0.45) with upper edge surviving, cut down at both sides ?for re-use. Inscribed on the face. Date: Mid third century (prosopography). Photo. Copied by Kubitschek and Reichel, (K V, 11; Abklatsch 24); recorded by Gaudin (40); by the MAMA expedition; found by the current expedition in 1975 (SBI 44). Published by Kubitschek and Reichel, no. 12; from Gaudin's squeeze by Reinach, 32, whence L. Robert, Villes d'Asie Mineure2 (Paris, 1962), 107; , by J. M. R. Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA VIII.512; by Roueché, PPA 58.

entry.title: Honours for the People of Hierapolis
entry.summary: Fragments from a white marble statue base shaft without moulding. Inscribed on the face. Date: Mid third century (prosopography). Photos. Complete text copied by Sherard in 1716 (10101, 128). A large fragment copied by Reichel (R I, 8);a smaller fragment, from the left side of ll.5-9, was recorded by Gaudin (38a). That fragment has not been found again, but the larger fragment found by Reichel and another small fragment were found by the NYU expedition in 1975. Published by Boeckh, from Sherard, CIG 2763, whence Liermann, Analecta 33. Fragment published, from Gaudin, by Reinach, 194, and recognized by J. M. R. Cormack, Notes on the Inscribed Monuments of Aphrodisias (Reading, 1955), p. 9. Published by Roueché, PPA 59.

entry.title: Honours for Aurelius Gaius, centurio frumentarius
entry.summary: Plain white marble statue base (0.53 × 1.09 × 0.50), broken at the upper corners and upper right side. Inscribed on the face. The upper edge, although chipped, is complete; the text must have begun on an upper feature. Date: Third century A.D. (lettering, nomenclature, content). Photos. Recorded by Gaudin (39); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 145-147, no. 78, whence ILS 9474; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 508; by Roueché, JRS 71, 1981, 113-117, no. 7, whence SEG 1981.905, col. 1, BE 1982.357, AnnEpig 1981.771, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 256.

entry.summary: Presumably a statue base. No description. Date: Third century A.D. (terminology, comparanda). Transcribed by Sherard in 1716 (10101, 128); not reported subsequently. Published by Boeckh, from Sherard papers, CIG 2802; by Roueché, JRS 71, 1981, 113-117, no. 8, whence SEG 1981.905, col. 2, BE 1982.357, AnnEpig 1981.771, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 360.

entry.title: Dedication to Constantius II and a Caesar by Fl. Quint. Eros Monaxios
entry.summary: A large white marble lintel block (0.87 × 4.20 × 0.50) broken in two diagonally across the face (as it probably was when Sherard saw it, and certainly when Bailie did) and broken away at the bottom (where no earlier visitor could read any more than we could). Inscribed on the face. Date: A.D. 355-360, dependent on dating of Caesar (see commentary). Photos. This inscription, which confronted every traveller who arrived at Aphrodisias before the construction of the new road to Tavas in the late 1960s, is one of the most frequently published from the site. It was copied by Sherard in 1705 (BM Add 10101 f.9); by von Richter; by Fellows ; the first four lines were copied by Wood in 1750. Bailie copied the inscription and checked it later; from this he produced a new and inaccurate distribution of the lines, which he presented with pride as an improvement on the text of Boeckh (Researches, 35-42); by Waddington. Recorded by Gaudin (180); by the MAMA expedition; recorded and restored by the NYU expedition. Published by Francke, 73, from von Richter; by Boeckh, 2744, from Sherard and von Richter; by Fellows, no. 18, whence CIG add. p. 1109; from these Texier, no. 1; by Bailie, 46; by Waddington, LBW 1626; mentioned by Reinach, 137, from Gaudin; by Jacopi, p. 170; published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, 426 ; by L. Robert, Hellenica 13, 158-167 whence BE 1966.393, BE 1968.507; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 19 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 607.

Copied (lines 2-10) by Sherard in 1716 (10101, f. 127); complete text recorded by K&R (not in notebook); recorded by Gaudin (134). Not reported subsequently. (1930), 26-7, whence SEG 30, 1244, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 306 .

entry.title: Posthumous honours for Iason son of Menodotos
entry.summary: Large white marble statue base shaft, with shallow moulding along lower edge, broken in two: upper fragment 0.865 high, lower 1.12 high; 1.00 x 0.48. Chipped along the right side and at the break. On the top there is a large lewis hole and two square dowel holes on either side. Inscribed on the face. Date: Mid to late first century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Copied by Reichel (R.I.4-5; Abklatsch); lower part recorded by Gaudin (135); both parts recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (SBI 100). Published by Kubitschek & Reichel, AAWW 1893, 100-101, no. 1; lines 16-31 published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 98-100, no. 13; full text published by Wilhelm, from Reichel, JÖAI 28, 1933, 57-61; by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 498, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 279; discussed Robert, AC 35, 1966, 392-394.

Delt. 1921/22, 294, Robert, Hellenica XIII, 164-6, BE 1966.416, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 23 . Inscribed on the exposed face; from a composite monument, in which the inscription continued on a block to the right, and the lower parts of the letters in l.14 were cut on the block below. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Copied by Kubitschek (KIII.4, Abklatsch 85); recorded by Gaudin (103); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 263-264, no. 157; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 579, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 410.

Inscribed on one face within a recessed panel, intruding onto the moulding; ll. 2-12 impinge on the right side moulding; initial letters of ll. 6 and 12 on the left side moulding; l. 13 on the lower moulding. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering), but before the edict of Caracalla (212). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (118); by the NYU expedition (71.48). Published from Gaudin's squeeze by Reinach, REG 19, 1906, 270, no. 165, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 483.

Copied by Picenini in 1705 (10102, 15), by Sherard in 1705 and 1716 (10101, 12 and 127v); recorded by the NYU expedition. The face is very worn. Inscribed on the face. The upper edge is complete; the text may have begun on an upper feature. Date: Middle to later second century A.D. (lettering and prosopography). Photos. (lettering). Photo. Both blocks copied by Sherard in 1705 (ff. 25, 39v-40); by Raoul Rochette; by Fellows; by Waddington. entry.summary: White marble block (1.44 x 0.66 x depth not measurable). Inscribed on the face. Date: Probably second to early third century A.D. (lettering, nomenclature). Photo. Copied by Sherard in 1716 (f. 127); by Fellows; ?by Bailie; lines 9-11 copied by Waddington; recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Boeckh, from Sherard, CIG 2832; by Fellows, Acct. 348-349, no. 51, whence CIG pp. 1115-1116 + 2815, l. 1, Bailie, Fasc. ii 55-56 and 322-324, no. 79, Waddington, LBW 1636 (majuscule copy wrongly numbered 1436); by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 545, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 500.

Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Recorded by Kubitschek (K.III.8, Abklatsch 82). not reported subsequently. Published from K's notebook (iii.8) by Cormack, no. 6, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 571 .

entry.title: Honours for M. Ulpius Carminius Klaudianos
entry.summary: No description. No description. Date: Second century A.D. (prosopography). Copied by Sherard ( 10101, 10v-11) and Picenini (10102, 16-16v, and, from Tisser 72v-73) in 1705; by Deering (p.16-16v, no number); a copy by Leake, now in Cambridge, is from Deering's). Not reported subsequently. Published by Boeckh, from Sherard papers, CIG 2782, and p. 1112, whence CIG as Liermann 73-86, no. 14, Ziebarth ZVRW 16, 1903, 292, no. 64, Laum 108, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 315 . Discussed by Haussoullier, Rev. de Phil. 1920, 72; Derenne, AC 2 (1933), 74 with Phil.Wochenschr. (1934), 213 (l.27); Ferri, Riv. Fil. (1938), 59; Jacopi, JdAI (1938), 744-52; L. Robert, Et.Anat. 542, n.2; Rev. de Phil. (1929), 138 n.2; Bull.Ep. 1939.358, 1973.475 (ll. 25-26), 1980.472; C. Foss, GRBS 16 (1975), 217; A. D. Macro, AJP 100 (1979), 94-8, (ll. 9-10); SEG 29, 1068; AnnEpig 1980, 865.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Ulpius Claudius Chariton
entry.summary: White marble stele with traces of a moulding above (0.86 x 1.02 x depth not measurable). Surface prepared but not highly polished for the inscription; stele left roughly dressed towards the base. Inscribed on the face. Date: Probably late second to early third century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Copied by Sherard in 1716 (f. 126); by Walpole; by Fellows; ?by Bailie; by Waddington; recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Walpole, Memoirs 462, no. 11 (part) ; by Boeckh, from Sherard, CIG 2846; by Fellows, Acct. 354-355, no. 55, whence CIG add. p. 1117, Bailie, Fasc. ii 61-63 and 332-333, no. 83; by Waddington, LBW 1640; published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 552, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 518 . Comments by Buresch, RhMus 1893, 139.

entry.title: Honours for Menekrates
entry.summary: White marble block (0.42 × 0.99 × 0.65) without moulding; broken above and on the upper left side, chipped at the right. Inscribed on the face.The left side appears complete; the text must have begun on an adjacent block of a composite monument. Date: First to second centuries A.D. (lettering). Copied by Loew; noted by Reichel (RI.16v); recorded by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. published by Franz, from Loew, b.2, whence LBW 1595, Liermann 14-16, no. 2; published by Cormack, from the MAMA records MAMA 8, no. 460, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 303.

entry.title: Gladiator memorial for familia of M. Antonius Apellas Severinos
entry.summary: A large stele (1.46 x 0.87 x 0.28) with a central panel, within simple moulding, topped by a decorated pediment and acroteria and flanked by scrolls. The panel is supported by two winged victories, holding palms; between them is a smaller figure, with a wheel, identified by Robert as Nemesis. Inscribed within the panel. Date: Late second/early third century (prosopography). Photos. Recorded by W. H. Buckler; by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published from Buckler by Robert, Gladiateurs, no. 156, with discussion 56-9, 64; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA VIII.507, on which see Robert, Hell. XIII, 154-5, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 232 ; cf. BE 1966.402. Published by Roueché, PPA 15.

entry.summary: White marble statue base shaft, without moulding (0.52 × 0.84 × 0.52), damaged below. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second half second century A.D. (lettering, nomenclature, family history, funding). Photos. Ll. 1-18 recorded by Sherard in 1716 (10101, 125v); recorded by Gaudin (98); recorded by the MAMA expedition; recorded by the NYU expedition in 1973. Published by Boeckh from Sherard, CIG 2775 whence Laum, no. 105; reference in Ziebarth's discussion of funds, ZVRW 16, 1903, 292, no. 63; ll. 19-20 published by Doublet/Deschamps, BCH 14 (1890), p. 613, no. 13; mentioned by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 121, no. 48; published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 482, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 265.

entry.summary: Two pieces from the left side of a white marble statue base shaft apparently without moulding. a: lines 1-13, (0.29 × 0.65 × 0.14), upper left corner complete; b: lines 11-27, (0.29 × 0.80 × 0.12), left edge survives in part, although much chipped. Inscribed on the face. Date: Late second/early third century A.D. (lettering, nomenclature, family history, ). Photos. Both parts recorded but not published by Kubitschek (a. K.III.10, Abklatsch 2a; b. III.13, Abklatsch 1d); recorded as separate texts by Gaudin (92e and 92h); a recorded by the MAMA expedition; both parts recorded and joined by the NYU expedition in 1973. a published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 140-41 no. 72; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 481, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 322b published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906,140-141 no. 74, whence Laum, no 114, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 580.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Aurelia Tate, also called Epithymia
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus, with lid, (length 2.13). On either side of the central tabella (0.80-0.73 × 0.41) are standing draped figures of a woman (left) and a man. Below the tabella are two roughish downward projections at either side and, between them, a relief scene in which two men sit on either side of what appears to be an oven. The left-hand man holds something rectangular and flat which appears to be fed into the 'oven'; the right-hand one holds a tubular object up to his face and down to the 'oven' perhaps a glass-blower's tube (? or a bellows). Inscribed on the lid (lines 1-2), on the upper rim (l. 3), on the tabella including its upper and lower mouldings (lines 4 ff). An erased area beside the relief of the woman could have contained an additional short text (perhaps ζῇ, which might have been erased when she died). Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1994 (Sarcophagus catalogue 415). Inscription unpublished; sarcophagus published by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, Sarcophagus 6.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.

Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, nomenclature). Photos. Sarcophagus box recorded byKubitschek (KIII.18, Abklatsch 26); by the MAMA expedition; with lid, by the NYU expedition (Sarcophagus catalogue 47). Published by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 571, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 438.

entry.title: Funerary honours for Peritas Kallimedes and his wife Tatia
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus (2.66 × 1.19 × 1.36: interior 2.15 × 0.87 × 1.00). The front face has an elaborately carved garland running along the upper edge and part-way down the two sides, and a simple moulding below. On the face busts, a bearded male (to the left) and a veiled female (to the right), are carved in relief profile, facing one another, each on a rectangular pedestal, with moulding above and below. See further Smith (below). The texts are inscribed on the face to the left of the male bust (i); between the two (ii) and to the right of the female bust (iii). Date: Late second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, sculpture). Photo. Copied by K&R (K.III.19, Abklatsch 107); recorded by Gaudin (160); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Kubitschek & Reichel, AAWW 1893, 102, no. 8, whence Buresch, RhMus 1894, p.431; by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 137-139, no. 70, a-c; by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 499, a-c whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 523, 446, 534; sarcophagus published by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, Sarcophagus 10.

entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus, decorated with columns and garlands, and with a recumbent figure on the lid, which is broken to right (2.25 × 1.35 × 0.93). See now Isik 157. Inscribed (l.1) along front of lid (1.50 × 0.07) and in tabella ansata (0.29 × 0.45); apparently reused. Date: Perhaps late second to early third centuries (lettering, nomenclature). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1977 (77.140; sarcophagus catalogue 1). Published by Isik and Reynolds, no. 157.

entry.title: Jewish graffiti in a bath-building
entry.summary: Marble panels in a threshold within the bath-building beside the extra-mural "Nymphaeum". Incised on the top face; while a. may be complete on its stone, b. is certainly not, and must originally have extended onto flanking panels. Date: Third century A.D. or later (nomenclature). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Reynolds & Tannenbaum, Jews and Godfearers at Aphrodisias, appendix, 7.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Aurelia Zotike and her father
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus, with lid, with garlands surrounding the busts of a woman (left) and a man. For a fuller description see bibliography. Inscribed on the central tabella (0.44 x 0.48), l.1, on the upper moulding, ll. 2 ff. in the tabella impinging on all its mouldings. The lower moulding of the sarcophagus has been damaged, and may once have carried the concluding phrases of the funerary formulae which are missing here. Date: Probably first half of the third century (lettering, nomenclature, spelling). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1994 (Sarcophagus catalogue 411). Published by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, Sarcophagus 12, by Reynolds and Isik, no. 179.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Aurelius Alexandros and Aurelia Tatia
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus, with lid, (2.00); for description see Isik 178. a. ll. 1-2 inscribed on the lower moulding of the lid, excluding the projections, ll. 3-21 on the tabella impinging on all mouldings, ll. 22-23 on the lower moulding of the sarcophagus. Text b. is on the projections on the lid. Date: Perhaps first half of the third century (lettering, nomenclature). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Sarcophagus catalogue 412). Published by Reynolds and Isik, no. 178.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Aurelius Apollonios and his son
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus, with lid, (length 2.10); for full description see Isik 116. Inscribed on the lid, lines 1-3, on the upper rim, l. 4, on the tabella including its upper and lower mouldings (0.58 x 0.56) lines 5-19, and on the base, lines 20 ff. Date: Probably first half of the third century (lettering, nomenclature). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Sarcophagus catalogue 414). Published by Reynolds and Isik, no. 116.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Aurelius Zotikos son of Dionysios
entry.summary: A white marble sarcophagus, with lid, decorated with swags between pilasters. ll. 1-3 inscribed on the lid, on the lower moulding, including the projections, ll. 4-6 on the sarcophagus, on the lower edge of the chest. Date: After 212; perhaps first quarter of the third century (lettering). Photos. Found by the Aphrodisias Museum in winter 1993-4 (Sarcophagus 410). Published by Reynolds, in G. Schmeling ed., Qui miscuit utile dulci, Festschrift for Paul MacKendrick (Wauconda Illinois, 1998), 287-296 whence An.Ép. 1998.1372SEG 48 1998.1326.; by Reynolds and Isik, no. 173.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for M. Aur. Polychronios Charmides
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus 2.12 × 0.94 × 0.94 with fluted front and sides, plain back. There is a central tabella on the front, inscribed on the upper moulding (ll. 1-2) and in the panel. Inscribed on the face. Date: Shortly after 212 (nomenclature). Photos. Recorded by Kubitschek (V.4, Abklatsch 108); by the MAMA expedition, by the NYU expedition in 1977 (Sarcophagus catalogue 26). Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 576, whence Robert, Hellenica 13, 196, 232, BE 1966.411, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 461.

entry.title: Epitaph of Theopropios, bishop
entry.summary: 'Coarse marble masonry block, with incised tabella ansata. H. 0.15, W. 0.95' (MAMA); depth presumably not measurable. Inscribed within tabella. Date: Fifth century or later (lettering). Recorded by Gaudin (55); by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. Published by Reinach, no. 221, from Gaudin, whence Grégoire, IGC 254bis; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 602 and plate 21, whence Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 165, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 755.

entry.title: Epitaph of Theopropios, bishop
entry.summary: A white marble lintel block, broken in two (0.15 × c. 1.15 × 0.455) over the entrance to a tomb chamber. A second chamber was subsequently constructed at right angles to the first, and the lintel over its entrance abuts on to our inscription, partially obscuring the right end. Inscribed along the face. Date: Fifth century or later. Photos. Exavated by the Department of Antiquities in 1978. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias 166, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 754.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: No description. No description. Date: No indication. Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (no number); not reported subsequently. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, 193, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 955 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Restoration, by Kallikrates of the dedication made by his ancestors
entry.summary: Four adjoining fragments from the upper part of a white marble statue base shaft without moulding (together 0.50 x 0.79 x 0.24). Top and bottom are lost, but both sides survive. Inscribed on the face. Date: Document i: Late first century B.C. for ll. 1-2, Reynolds first favoured Julius as Caesar, but came to think of Octavian; Document ii: early second century. (prosopography, lettering). Photos. Two fragments recorded by the MAMA expedition; found again by the NYU expedition, together with further fragments (62.268 a and b, 69.328). Two fragments published by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 446, whence Lane, Berytus 15, 1964, 27-28, no. 3, Robert, Hellenica 13, 128-131, BE 1966.397, Lane, Corpus Mon. Dei Menis I no. 120, ll. 1-2. Published with new fragments Reynolds, PCPS 206, 1980, 71-73, no. 1 whence SEG 30, 1980.1244-1245, BE 1982.355, AnnEpig 1980.866; republished by Reynolds, Aphrodisias & Rome, doc. 32, whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.387, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 147 McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 148.

entry.title: Honours for anonymous
entry.summary: a. fragment from the upper edge of a plain white marble block (0.19 × 0.22 × 0.23); b. probably lower right corner (0.22 × 0.16 × 0.10). Inscribed on the only surviving face; a. is very worn. Date: First century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition (Walls 155 (a), and Walls 154(b). Unpublished.

entry.title: Monumental revetment fragment
entry.summary: Two fragments of white marble revetment. a: broken to left, other edges survive (0.285 × 0.244 x ?); b: one edge survives (0.14 × 0.16 x ?). Inscribed on the face. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition in 1968 (68.129). Unpublished.

entry.title: Votive dedication by children of Hermias
entry.summary: A white marble altar (0.305 at top, 0.265 centre, 0.35 at base × 0.84 × 0.56) with moulding above and below on three sides, which has been cut away on the left side. The back is rough. Inscribed (l. 1) on the upper moulding, and (ll. 2-5) on the face, above a relief of a swag with a pendant object. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (terminology). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (56); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin, REG 19, 1906, 108, no. 23, whence Weinreich, MDAI(A) 37, 1912, 20, no. 94; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, 456, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 173.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Artemidoros son of Artemidoros
entry.summary: 'Marble block' (0.70 × 0.22 × 0.48). 'With tabella ansata' (MAMA). Date: First to second centuries A.D. (nomenclature). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin; by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 262, no. 156; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 534, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 429 .

entry.title: Funerary inscription for ? and Antonia Kalliniane
entry.summary: White marble fragment from a block (0.85 x 0.29 x depth not measurable). Inscribed on the face. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (terminology). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (53); by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. Published by Reinach from Gaudin, REG 19, 1906, 279-280, no. 174; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 583, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 420.

entry.title: Fragment (of honours) from city walls
entry.summary: Fragment from the left side of a plain white marble block (0.28 × 0.32 × 0.26). Inscribed on the only surviving face. Date: First to third century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (DM) (Walls 156). Unpublished.

entry.title: Gladiator memorial, for Unio
entry.summary: An altar-stele, with moulding above and below on three sides, badly worn (0.71 x 0.37 x 0.42). On face, relief of a heavily armed gladiator with shield, advancing right. Inscribed on the face above the relief. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1978 (East Cemetery 3). Published by Roueché, PPA 17.

entry.title: Opening of a decree by the city and by the sacred victors
entry.summary: A white marble statue base capital, with moulding broken (0.40 x 0.93 at top, depth not measurable). Inscribed on upper fascia of moulding (l.1) and on the face (ll.2-3). Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, institutions). Photo. Recorded by the MAMA expedition in 1934; not reported subsequently. Published by Cormack, MAMA VIII.495, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 347 ; by Roueché, PPA 93.

entry.title: Funerary verse for Eupeithios
entry.summary: White marble block without moulding or decoration, chipped along all edges and missing the lower right corner (1.14 × 0.265 × 0.55). Inscribed on one face, which is itself chipped approximately in the centre. Line 1 is very close to the upper edge, suggesting a composite monument. Date: second century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1992 (92.1). Published by R.R..R. Smith, 'Aphrodisias 1992', KST XV-2 (1994), 355, whence BullEp 1996.385; from Reynolds, Steinepigramme 02/09/12, whence SEG 48 1998.1327.

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Fragment from the left side of a white marble columnar sarcophagus front (0.305 × 0.40 × 0.43). On what survives of the left short end part of a draped female figure is visible beside a column at the corner. Inscribed on the lower part of the front face, above a carved lower edge; there are traces of sculptured decoration above. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1992 (92.36; sarcophagus 211). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Two adjoining pieces of a white marble sarcophagus base, partially adapted with a view to re-use (1.92 × 0.28 × 0.83). Inscribed on the moulding, which was already faulty or damaged (the lettering in lines 2 and 3 dips into a chipped area). Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1992 (92.31, Sarcophagus 203). Photograph published by R. R. R. Smith, Aphrodisias Papers 3, 69, whence text published SEG 1996.1396.

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Fragment from the left end of what is probably a white marble sarcophagus lid (0.49 × 0.20 × 0.20). Inscribed along lower panel. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1992 (92.35). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary fragment from Turkish Cemetery
entry.summary: Moulded white marble fragment (0.37 × 0.26 × 0.73) from sarcophagus lid. Inscribed, l.1, on upper moulding, l.2 on inset face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (East Cemetery 1). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Aurelius Statilius Apollonios
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus lid (2.11). Inscribed on the lower edge, which is damaged. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1993/94 (Sarcophagus 421). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: White marble column sarcophagus, with five standing figures within arcaded embrasures (2.19 x 0.92 x 0.98): a central male figure flanked by two muses on either side. For full description see bibliography. Inscribed a. along the upper edge (which is worn and damaged), and b. on either side of the head of the central figure. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1994 (Sarcophagus 432). Sarcophagus published by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, Sarcophagus 7.

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Lower part of a broken white marble sarcophagus (1.53 × 0.62 × 0.84). Inscribed in an area much damaged. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1994 (Sarcophagus 435). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Fragment from the bottom of a white marble sarcophagus (0.31 × 0.23 × 0.30). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1994 (Sarcophagus 436). Unpublished.

entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus lid (2.05 x 0.35 x 0.94), broken away to right. Inscribed on the edge, which is interrupted by the vertical projections. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition, in 1994 (Sarcophagus index 443a). Unpublished.

entry.summary: White marble fragment (0.36 × 0.31 × 0.36). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. entry.summary: Left side fragment from a white marble sarcophagus 0.90 × 0.45 × 0.74, with a reclining figure in the upper left coner. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (nomenclature). Photo. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 582, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 443.

entry.summary: A fragment (no measurements). Inscribed ?on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Recorded by Kubitschek (K iii.36); not reported subsequently. Published from Kubitscheck's copy by Cormack, ABSA 59 (1964), 18, whence with 17 McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 572 and 960.

entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus lid (2.09 × 0.40 × 0.84). Inscribed along the rim. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering, nomenclature). Photo. Recorded by Kubitschek (KV.1); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. MAMA 8, no. 563, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 462.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for M. Aurelius Ioulianos
entry.summary: Fragment from a white marble sarcophagus lid (0.69 long); the right end has been lost since Kubitschek recorded it. On the front mouldings of the lid, interrupted by a projecting panel with ΣΙΝ (from ζῶσιν) in large letters. The text must have continued on the face of the sarcophagus. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by Kubitschek (III, 17; Abklatsch 89); by the NYU expedition in 1994 (Sarcophagus 446). Published from Kubitschek by Cormack, no. 10, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 451 .

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: A fragment of a sarcophagus lid (no measurements). Apparently on the rim of the lid. Date: Second to fifth centuries A.D. (lettering). Recorded by Kubitschek (iii.36); not reported subsequently. Published from K's notebook by Cormack, no. 17, whence, with 18 McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 572 and 960.

Recorded by Kubitschek (III.43); not reported subsequently. Published from K's notebook by Cormack, no. 25, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 480 ; discussed by L. Robert, Ant. Class. (1966) 386-8, BE 1967.546.

entry.title: Honours for L. Cl. Iberinos Eudaimon
entry.summary: A white marble statue base shaft with moulding; surviving fragment cut from the left side, with traces of moulding above (0.18 × 0.675 × 0.14) 'On an oblong square marble' (Sherard). Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Copied by Sherard (10101, 16v) and Picenini (10102, 26 and, from Tisser, 77v) in 1705; recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Boeckh, from Sherard papers,CIG 2791, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 297 .

entry.title: Sarcophagus of [...] and his wife [...] daughter of Menandros
entry.summary: White marble garland sarcophagus 2.23 × 1.01 × 1.09. For description see Isik 99. Inscribed along the upper edge (l.1) and in the tabella and its upper and lower mouldings. The text must have begun on the lid. Date: Perhaps late second to first half of the third century (lettering, spelling). Recorded by Kubitschek (KV.3, Abklatsch 110); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (Isik). Published from the MAMA records, with consultation also of Kubitschek's papers, J.M.R.Cormack, MAMA 8. 553, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 547 ; Reynolds and Isik 99, with photograph.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for anonymous
entry.summary: White marble garland sarcophagus 2.06 × 0.68 × 0.77; see full description at Isik 98. Inscribed on the damged front face within a panel broken away above (0.265 × 0.185). The text must have begun above, perhaps on the lid and on the upper edge of the sarcophagus. The upper right corner of the panel has been damaged since 1904, when Gaudin's squeeze recorded more in l. 1. Date: Probably first half of the third century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (164); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published from Gaudin's squeeze, Reinach, REG 19 (1906), 285, no. 182; from the MAMA records, Cormack, MAMA 8. 589, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 551; Reynolds and Isik 98.

entry.title: Funerary formula from sarcophagus
entry.summary: Left side of a white marble garland sarcophagus; for full description see Isik 104. Inscribed on the upper moulding (l.1) and within the tabella of which only the left side survives (0.15 x 0.39). The text must have begun on the lid. Date: Probably first half of the third century A.D. (lettering, stephanephoros). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1994 (Sarcophagus 433). Published by Isik and Reynolds, no. 104.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Polydeukes Kamisenos son of Salvios
entry.summary: White marble garland sarcophagus; for further description see Isik 156. On the sarcophagus, l. 1 along the upper rim, ll. 2, 3 on the lower moulding (both areas damaged). The text must have begun on the lid. Date: Perhaps the first half of the third century (lettering, spelling, nomenclature). Recorded by Reichel (R.1.30, Ablatsch 42); recorded by Isik; not seen by Reynolds. The text published, from R's notebook, and squeeze, by Cormack, ABSA1964, 27, no. 41, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 529 ; the monument published by Isik and Reynolds, no. 156, with a photograph.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Aurelius Menandros and his wife's family
entry.summary: White marble garland sarcophagus; see Isik 162 for description. The text must have begun on the lid. ll.1-12 within the tabella, ll.13-15 probably on its lower moulding, perhaps also on a prepared space below it (illegible on the xerox of the photograph), the remainder on the lower moulding of the chest. The text must have begun on the lid and/or the upper rim of the chest, and there may have been one more line below what survives, where the photograph suggests that the lower edge has been broken away. Date: Perhaps first half of the third century (lettering, spelling, nomenclature). Copied by Kubitschek (K V.2; Abklatsch 60); recorded by Isik, but not seen by Reynolds. The text published from K's notebook (v.2) by Cormack, ABSA 59, 1964, 24-25, no. 32, whence comment by L. Robert, AntClass 1966, 385-6, BE 1967:545; McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 455 ; monument published by Isik and Reynolds, no. 162, with photograph.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Zenon son of Zenon, boy runner Victor at the ninth Philemoniea
entry.summary: A plain statue base shaft (1.09 x 0.34 x 0.34). Inscribed on the face; the dedicating authority may have been named on a crowning feature. Date: c. 208 (contests). Photos. Recorded by Gaudin (58); by the NYU expedition. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, no. 146, whence cited by Oikonomos, Arch. Delt. (1921/2), 295. Published by Roueché, PPA 82.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Aurelius
entry.summary: White marble garland sarcophagus (2.13 × 0.84 × 0.915). For further description see Isik 141. i. along the upper rim of the chest (badly worn) continued on the upper moulding of the tabella and originally within the tabella with an overlap on either side onto the side mouldings and on the right hand side sometimes beyond that (with an awkwardly imprecise alignment), ii. within the tabella after the erasure of i from its surface. Text i may have begun on the lid. Date: i. Perhaps towards the middle of the third century A.D. (lettering); ii. probably second half of the third century (lettering). Photo. Recorded by K&R (RI.32); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published byCormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8. 586, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 505 (i), 437 (ii); Reynolds and Isik 141.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Menippos
entry.summary: White marble garland sarcophagus (2.40 × 0.99 × 1.20) with tabella ansata; for full description see Isik 84. Inscribed within the tabella and on its lower moulding (ll. 20, 21); the text must have begun on the lid. Date: Mid third century (lettering, stephanephoros). Photos. Recorded by Gaudin (149); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (Sarcophagus catalogue 4). Published from Gaudin's squeeze, Reinach, REG 19 (1906), 274-276, no. 169 (l.3 discussed by L.Robert, BCH 1928, 411); from the MAMA records, Cormack, MAMA 8. 555, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 509; Reynolds and Isik 84.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for M. Aurelius Papias
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus (2.14 × 0.90 × 0.90) and lid; for further description see Isik 106. Inscribed in the moulded central tabella. Date: Middle to late third century A.D. (lettering and nomenclature), but this inscription is probably secondary, since the sarcophagus was certainly intended for a husband and wife. Photos. Recorded by Gaudin (169); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (Sarcophagus catalogue 45). Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 277, no. 171; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 556c, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 459 ; by Reynolds and Isik 106.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Antonius Antiochos and Antonia Eiphianassa
entry.summary: White marble garland sarcophagus with lid (box: 2.42 × 1.06 × 1.18; lid: 2.50 × 0.64 × 1.30). For description see Isik 171. ll. 1-6 on the lid, on the lower moulding, including the two projections. ll. 7-8 on the sarcophagus, on the lower moulding. The lid has been badly damaged, with loss of the text at both sides. Date: Perhaps the mid to late third century A.D. (total size of fine). Photos. Recorded by Gaudin (178); by the NYU expedition in 1973. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, REG 19, 1906, 261-262, no. 155; by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 565, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 421 ; by Reynolds and Isik, no. 171.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment of funerary verse
entry.summary: A white marble fragment, apparently of a sarcophagus front, (0.78 × 0.85 × 0.16), broken above and below. Inscribed a above and b within a tabella ansata. Date: Fourth century or later. Copied by Kubitschek, 9 June 1893 (K. III, 16, Abklatsch 83); not reported subsequently. Published by Cormack (1964) 19, 9, and fig. 1, whence Robert, AC 35, 1966, 38; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 160.a, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 757 and b, whence PHI 739, Steinepigramme 02/09/34.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Epitaph of Theodoros, ceromatitites
entry.summary: Plain white marble stele reshaped as a Moslem tombstone (H. 0.34, W. 0.30). Inscribed on the face. Date: Fourth century or later (content). Recorded by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. Published by Cormack, MAMA 8, no. 605, from the MAMA records, whence L. Robert, Hellenica 13, 167-170 (discussion), BE 1966.415, published Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 169, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 752.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Aurelius Epinikos and Aurelia Zenonis and family
entry.summary: White marble garland sarcophagus with lid; for full description see Isik 118. i. a. inscribed on the lid, (length 2.09); i. b on the tabella, impinging on the moulding (0.29 x 0.41), l. 1 on upper moulding, ll. 17-18 on lower moulding; i. c on the projections. On one of the vertical projections an earlier text has been erased and ii has been added..]. Date: For i. perhaps the first half of the third century (lettering, nomenclature); ii. presumably relates to a secondary use at a later date. Photos. Excavated by the Aphrodisias Museum in 1992 (Museum inventory 92/2; Sarcophagus 309). Published by Mahir Atici, IV. Müze Kurtama Kazilari Semineri Marmaris, 1993, (Department of Antiquities, Ankara, 1993), 101-108, whence mentioned SEG 1995.1506, BullEp 1995.513; by Reynolds and Isik, no. 118.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary stele for Amyntas and family
entry.summary: A white marble stele, with a pediment; very worn and scarcely legible in places. (H. 0.97, W. 0.50). Inscribed on the face below the pediment. Date: second-early 1st century B.C. (lettering, nomenclature). Recorded by Kubitschek (K iii.58; Abklatsch 70); not reported subsequently. Published from Kubitschek's copy by Cormack, ABSA 59 (1964), 31; discussed L. Robert, Ant. Class. (1966) 384-5, BullEp 1967.544; from these McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 418 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Aurelius Athenagoras
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus, with lid, (2.13). Inscribed a. on the vertical projections of the lid, lines 1-2, and b. across the sarcophagus front, which is otherwise undecorated (1.88 x 0.585), and broken to left. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Sarcophagus 419). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Attalos
entry.summary: A stele (Grabplatte) with a gable drawn above, and a relief below ( 0.41 x 0.21 x 0.07). There is a rosette in the gable. The relief is of a shepherd, with a cloak on his shoulders and a staff; beside him are ?a sheep and a dog. Inscribed on either side of the shepherd. Date: Second to fourth century A.D.(lettering). Recorded by Reichel (R.I.33, Abklatsch 69); not reported subsequently. Published from Reichel by Cormack, no. 42, on which Robert, AC (1966), 383, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 472 , BullEp 1967.543.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for [Julius] Aurelius Charidemos
entry.summary: Fragment from the upper right side of a white marble statue base shaft. (H. 0.48, W. 0.19). Inscribed on the face. Date: Late second century (lettering, prosopography). Recorded by Kubitscheck and Reichel (K v.17; Abklatsch 99); not reported subsequently. Published from Kubitscheck's copy by Cormack, ABSA 59 (1964), 35; discussed L. Robert, Ant. Class. (1966) 395-8 (and 424 n.3), BullEp 1967.549; from these McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 281 . Cited A&R p. 165, 12. From all these, republished by B. Puech, Orateurs et sophistes, no.63.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Epandios and his family
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus 1.95 × 0.78 × 0.73; for a full description see Isik 107. Inscribed in central tabella (0.31 x 0.40), ll. 1-14 within it and l. 15 on its lower moulding, and on the lower rim (ll. 18-19). The text must have begun on the lid, which is lost. The surface has become more worn than in the 1934 photograph. Date: Middle to second half of the third century (lettering, stephanephoros). Photos. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (Sarcophagus catalogue 178). Published from the MAMA records, J.M.R.Cormack, MAMA 8 566, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 474 ; Reynolds & Isik 107.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary honours for Neaira and Metrodoros
entry.summary: A plain white marble block (2.06 × 0.59 × depth not measurable). Both texts inscribed on the face, which is cracked, i. to the left, ii. to the right. The block is complete above, though chipped; i. must therefore have begun on an upper block. Date: i. first half of first century A.D.; ii. second half of first century A.D. Photos. Recorded by Sherard in 1716 (10101 121-2); by Wood (14, f47); by Deering (1v, nos 4 and 5); by Fellows; by Bailie (see Researches, 51-2, 83-4); by Choisy; by Loew; by Waddington; mentioned by K&R (RI.14v);recorded by Gaudin (154, 147); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. a: Published published by Boeckh from Sherard, CIG 2816 and 2779; by Fellows, Acct. 323-324, no. 31 and 30, whence CIG p. 1114, Bailie, Fasc. ii 24-25 and 283, no. 51.i and h. Mentioned by Franz, from Loew, Ann. d. Inst. 19, 1847, 114-115, nos. a.1 and a.6; Published by Reinach, REG 19, 1906, 125-127, nos. 67, 65; from the MAMA records, by Cormack, MAMA 473, 472 , whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 309, 305 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary honours for Kallippos, Athenagoras and
entry.summary: A plain white marble block (0.335 × 0.475 × depth not measurable) without moulding, but with a recessed edge on all sides, serving as panels in the tomb at the East gate. The inscriptions are cut on the face, and run into the frames on both sides. i: the stone is badly worn at the upper right corner, and damaged at the lower edge, which survives; it could have continued on a lower block. ii: the text should have continued below. Date: First to second century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by Sherard in 1716 (10101 121-2); by Wood; by Deering (4 and 5); by Fellows; by Bailie (see Researches, 51-2, 83-4); by Choisy; by Loew; by Waddington; by Gaudin (154, 147); by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition (inv?); mentioned by K&R (RI.14v). Published from Gaudin's squeeze by Reinach, REG 19, 1906, 135, no. 58, 34, 82 ; from the MAMA records, by Cormack, MAMA 8, no. 474, 475, 476 , whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 287, 242, 343 ; published by Reynolds, 'The first known Aphrodisian to hold a procuratorship', Steine und Wege (Vienna, 1999), 327-334, Appendix B.3 B.1, B.2,..

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Ti. Claudius Achilleus

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Gladiator memorial for Podenemos
entry.summary: A white marble altar-stele, with very simple moulding above and below on three sides (0.84 x 0.395 x 0.32). There is no trace of carving on the face, which probably carried a painted image. Inscribed on the upper moulding (l.1) and at the top of the face (l.2). Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by Gaudin (14); by the NYU expedition in 1976 (excavation inventory no. 76.85, SBI 64). Published from Gaudin by Reinach, no. 190, whence Robert, 'Πυκτεύειν', 40 (= OMS I, 707), Robert, Gladiateurs no. 162. Published by Roueché, PPA 16.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Lower right corner of a white marble sarcophagus front ? or lid (0.70 × 0.45 × 0.40). Inscribed on the moulding. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Walls 10). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: White marble block, partly buried and broken at right side (0.85 x 0.66 visible x 0.22). Inscribed in one line across on one face, whose surface is lost to left. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Walls 128. Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Right hand side fragment from a white marble sarcophagus (0.42 × 0.53 × 0.30); no decoration visible. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Walls 140). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Upper left corner white marble fragment from a sarcophagus (0.54 x 0.33 visible) , partly buried; complete to left, a projection (broken) to right. Inscribed on the moulding, each line on a different plane. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Walls 146). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Epitaph of Philosophia
entry.summary: A white marble column (no further description and no dimensions). On the face of the column. Date: A.D. 551. Recorded by Gaudin (46); not reported subsequently. Published by Reinach, no. 203, from Gaudin, whence Grégoire, IGC 255; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 164 and plate xxxviii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 742 . Discussed by D. Feissel, 'Une épitaphe d'Aphrodisias et le calendrier de la province d'Asie au Bas-Empire', BCH 119 1995, 375-79.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours, perhaps funerary, for Julianos and Flavia Apphia Iuliane
entry.summary: White marble block or statue base (0.44 × 0.67 × 0.44) with drafted edges on the left and right sides. The stone is chipped above and to the right, but complete above. The inscription impinges on the right edge. The text must have begun on an upper feature. Date: First to second A.D. lettering. Recorded by Kubitschek (V.5, Abklatsch 111); by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 510 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 489.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication of a foundation by Titus Aelius ]dianos
entry.summary: White marble block incorporating a simple moulding, (1.02 × 0.48 × 0.33). Part of a composite monument; the probable restoration of l. 2 strongly suggests that a block of equal size constituted the missing right half of the monument. Inscribed on one face, in two planes. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Walls 142); brought in in 1989. Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Publia Calvisia Peritiane
entry.summary: A white marble sarcophagus lid (1.90 × 0.35 × 0.87). Beside it is the sarcophagus, broken and badly damaged, with columns at the corners; the tabella ansata has been erased. Inscribed on the upper rim (l. 1) on two pendants (l.2) and on lower rim (l.3); the state of the surface suggests that ll.1 and 3 were cut over an earlier, erased, text. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Walls 17). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for M. Aurelius
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus lid: 'couvercle de sarcophage (brisé)' (Gaudin), 2.09 (Kubitschek). Inscribed on the rim. Date: Third century A.D. (lettering). Recorded by Kubitschek (K III, 28; Abklatsch 7); by Gaudin (18); not reported subsequently. Published from Gaudin by Reinach, 149, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 466 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus with lid (2.275 x 1.545 x 1.11), decorated with three garlands with busts between, and two standing figures below; for fuller description see bibliography. It was once inscribed along the edge of the lid, along the upper front edge of the box and on either side of the busts, but the texts have been carefully erased, leaving only a few letters along the front edge. Date: Third century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1971; an accidental find by a villager. (Walls 5, 71.100). Text unpublished; sarcophagus published most recently by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, Sarcophagus 13.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Aurelius Glykon and Alexandros
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus 2.35 × 1.00 × 1.03 and lid 2.385 × 0.42 × 1.12. Decorated with victories and putti holding garlands, with a bust above each garland. In the centre, a tabella ansata; for a full description, see Isik 137. Inscribed on the tabella. Date: Perhaps middle of the third century (lettering, formulae). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (153); by the NYU expedition; broken in the 1990s. Published from Gaudin's squeeze, T. Reinach, REG 19 (1906), 264-265, no. 159, whence M.Squarciapino, La scuola di Afrodisia (Rome, 1943) 11, no. 3; from the MAMA records, J.M.R. Cormack, MAMA VIII. 574, whence BullEp 1961.666, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 450 ; from the stone, K.T.Erim and J.M.Reynolds, 'Sculptors of Aphrodisias in the inscriptions of the city', Festschrift Jale Inan (Istanbul, 1989), 517-538, no. 24, whence SEG 1990.944; Reynolds and Isik 137.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary verse for Zenon son of Artemidoros
entry.summary: A white marble stele, slightly damaged (1.42, 0.525, 0.20). There is a pediment above, outlined with moulding and flanked by small acroteria. For a full description see Smith, l.c. Inscribed on the lower part of the face, 0.54 below the pediment (so presumably below a painted image). The layout is compressed and irregular. Date: Second to early first century B.C. (monument, lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1990 (90.16; museum inv. no. 5677). Published by C. P. Jones and R. R. R. Smith, 'Two inscribed monuments of Aphrodisias', Arch. Anz. (1994), 455-72, 455-61, whence SEG 1994.865, BullEp. 1995.514, Steinepigramme 02/09/33; discussed by K.J. Rigsby, ZPE 1333 (2000), 114-115, whence SEG 2000.1099.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscriptions for Tatis and Herodotos (mother and child)
entry.summary: White marble block with a narrow rebate at either side of face (0.485 × 0.56 × 0.58). Inscribed on the face; surface to left in area between ll. 4 and 5 has been scratched but suggestion of letters on the photograph is probably misleading. Date: Late Hellenistic to Augustan (lettering); perhaps even second century B.C. Photos. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition in 1976. Published from the MAMA records by Cormack, MAMA 8, no 533, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 533.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Building dedication to Demos
entry.summary: A single block of white marble Architrave block (2.59 × 0.39 x depth not measurable). Date: Late first century B.C. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. Published by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8. 441, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 117.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: A white marble fragment of moulding, broken to left, complete to right, and worn (0.41 x 0.53 x 0.29). The first two lines are written in large letters, and below them is a line, suggesting that the next three lines are written on another face of moulding. Date: Perhaps First century A.D. (lettering). Recorded by K&R (notebook K. III.5, Abklatsch 63), in 1893; not reported subsequently. Published from Kubitschek by Cormack, no. 4, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 570 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Upper right corner of a white marble sarcophagus lid with anta at corner. Inscribed on fascia below moulding. Date: First century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Walls 13). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Epitaphs of anonymous, tabernarius, and of Euarestos
entry.summary: Upper right corner of a white marble funerary stele (0.43 x 0.47 × 0.10) in the form of an aedicula, with simply moulded gable and plain acroteria, supported on columns with Corinthian capitals. Within the recess is the bust of a boy in relief. ii is cut on either side of the bust and is presumably the original inscription of the monument; i is cut in irregular lettering on the gable. Date: i. Third/fourth century (formulae, penalty); ii. Second/third century (lettering). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition in 1962 (62.24). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 147. and plate xxxiv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 476, 577. Published by Smith, Roman Portrait Statuary from Aphrodisias, Relief 5.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary verse for a girl, Thea[ . . .
entry.summary: A white marble masonry block (0.30 × 0.52 × 0.64) chipped at upper and right edges, but otherwise complete. There is a rough protrusion on the underside, which presumably fitted into masonry below. Inscribed on one face; the text must have continued on an adjacent block as part of a substantial monument. There are some gaps to avoid faults in the stone, which was not very carefully prepared to receive the inscription. Date: Fourth-sixth century (content,metre). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1972 (72.157). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 154 and plate xxxv, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 738, Steinepigramme 02/09/92 (partial).

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Heliodoros, builder or donor
entry.summary: Fragment from a blue-grey marble lintel or cornice block (0.25 × 0.14 × 0.38) with a moulded profile. Inscribed in one line on one fascia (H. 0.05) of front moulding. Date: Fifth to seventh centuries A.D. (lettering, terminology). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition in 1973. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 106 and plate xxviii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 611.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus fragment 0.47 × 1.00 × 0.19. Inscribed on the face. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (formulae, nomenclature). Photo. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. published by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 597, whence, L. Robert, Hellenica 13, 13 and 133-134 (on l. 2), BE 1966:414, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 541.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Aurelius Zenon
entry.summary: White marble garland sarcophagus whose decoration was roughed out, but not carved; see description at Isik 81. Roughly inscribed on a recessed central tabella (0.25 × 0.34) which is only approximately rectangular and not parallel to the sides. The lower part of its surface damaged. Date: Probably third century A.D. (lettering, nomenclature). Photos. Excavated by the Aphrodisias Museum in 1989-90 (90.g, Sarcophagus catalogue 8). Published by A. S. Tulay, 'Kabalar kurtama kasısı 1989', Müze Kurtama Kazıları Semineri I (Ankara 1990), 25-39, 28, whence SEG 1990.948, BullEp 1992.437; by Reynolds and Isik, no. 81.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Aurelius Attikos
entry.summary: White marble garland sarcophagus (with lid) with 2 eagle medallions; for full description see Isik 127. Inscribed on a tabella (0.46 × 0.58, die 0285 × 0.40). In the inscribed area the spaces between guide lines for ll. 2-6 are slightly sunk; at the right (and possibly the left) end of the sunk area containing l. 6 the cutter has added a 'handle', as if under the impression that he was supposed to make a tabella ansata here. Date: Probably third century A.D. (lettering, nomenclature). Photos. Excavated by the Aphrodisias Museum in 1989 (Sarcophagus catalogue 10). Published by A. S. Tulay, 'Kabalar kurtama kasısı 1989', Müze Kurtama Kazıları Semineri I (Ankara 1990), 25-39, 27, whence SEG 1990.947, BullEp 1992.437; by Reynolds and Isik, no. 127.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Aemilius Aristeas
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus complete with lid and an iron clamp repairing an ancient break; total (0.96 x 2.38 x 0.91); chest (0.73 x 2.38), lid (0.24 x 2.36). For a full description see Smith, l.c. Line 1 is inscribed on the front moulding of the lid; line 2 along the upper front edge of the sarcophagus, but leaving a substantial area blank at the right-hand end, where the sarcophagus is damaged; lines 3-19 in the area between the two busts, from which an earlier inscription has been erased; line 20 on the flange below. Date: Late third century A.D. (hairstyles)nomenclature, lettering). Photo. Excavated by the Aphrodisias Museum in 1989 (Sarcophagus catalogue 11). Published by C. P. Jones and R. R. R. Smith, 'Two inscribed monuments of Aphrodisias', Arch. Anz. (1994), 455-72, 461-72, whence BullEp 1995.514, SEG 1994.866; by Reynolds and Isik, no. 6.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for okles son of Diogenes
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus lid broken and worn (0.70 × 0.30 × 0.19). Inscribed on the moulding in a single line. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (West Cemetery 1). Unpublished.

entry.summary: Fragment of white marble sarcophagus lid (0.33 × 0.17 x depth not measurable). Inscribed within a panel. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (West Cemetery 3). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary fragment from nr. West Gate
entry.summary: White marble fragment from a sarcophagus lid. Inscribed (l. 1) on upper moulding and (ll. 2-3) on recessed fascia below, which is interrupted by a projection to right. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (West Cemetery 8). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: No description; very probably a sarcophagus fragment. No description. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (formulae). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (no number); not reported subsequently. Published by Reinach, from Gaudin's squeeze, 198, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 583 .

entry.title: Edict of Silius Italicus, proconsul
entry.summary: Upper part of a white marble statue base shaft ( 0.53 x 0.37 x 0.58). Inscribed on the face. Date: 77 A.D. (prosopography). Recorded by the MAMA expedition in 1934; not reported subsequently. Published by Calder, CR 49, 1935, 216-217, whence BE 1938.395, Campbell, CR 50, 1936, 56-58; published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 411, whence L. Robert, Hellenica 13, l4, BE 1966.384, Sokolowski, LSAM 189, no. 86, SEG 15, 660; Robert, JS 1971, 81-97; published, from all these, Reynolds, A&R 46 whence SEG 32, 1982.1097; BE 1983.391, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 75 . Discussion by D. J. Campbell, CR 50 (1936), 56 f. (on the prosopography) ; E. Bikermann, Syria 25 (1948), 83; J. and L. Robert, Bull. Ep. 1971.613 ; M. Guarducci RAL 1973, 587 f. ; J. and L. Robert, Bull. Ep. 1976. 90 (all on the doves).
