entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: White marble block with upper corners lost, some damage on all edges and on the face (0.875 x 0.675 x c 0.435). Ιnscribed on the face, within a drafted margin. Date: Perhaps first half of I cent. A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Walls 164. Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Lucia Antoniane
entry.summary: Two adjoining pieces of the lower part of a white marble sarcophagus; traces of figures above. Inscribed in four lines on a broad lower border; the text must have begun on an upper feature. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (West Cemetery 4; sarcophagus catalogue 199 and 196). Unpublished.

entry.summary: Right end of a white marble sarcophagus lid broken in two (1.30 × 0.76 × 0.17). Inscribed on the moulded edge which is badly worn. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (West Cemetery 5). Unpublished.

entry.title: Funerary for descendant of Diogenes
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus lid (1.17 × 0.24 x depth not measurable). Inscribed on the moulding which is badly worn; the inscription may well replace an earlier one. Date: Second to fourth centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (West Cemetery 6). Unpublished.

entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus lid (0.94 x 0.24 x depth not measurable) inscribed on the moulding; the text must have begun on an upper area.Sarcophagus lid. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. Published by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 588, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 519.

entry.title: Honours for anonymous, wrestler
entry.summary: No description: apparently a white marble statue base shaft: Height unmeasurable; 0.38 x 0.35. Inscribed on the face. Date: ?early third century (contests). Photo. Recorded by Kubitschek and Reichel (K V, 10; Abklatsch 18); not reported subsequently. Published by Kubitschek and Reichel, no. 11; published, independently, from their copy, Reinach 146bis, on which see Robert, Et. Anat., 432 n.5. Cited by Cormack, ABSA 59 (1964), 26, no.33, on which see Robert, 'Inscriptions d'Aphrodisias', 380 n.1 (=OMS VI, 4).. Published by Roueché, PPA 77.

entry.title: Votive offering to an unnamed God
entry.summary: White marble block, broken to right (0.61 × 0.25 × 0.29). Inscribed on the face. Date: Possibly third century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; not reported subsequently. Published by Cormack from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 457, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 172.

entry.title: Funerary inscription of Aurelia Tertulla
entry.summary: a: Part of a white marble garland sarcophagus front 0.81 × 0.48 × 0.32, showing a central moulded panel with curving handles upheld by putti. b: part of a sarcophagus lid (0.50 × 0.16 × 0.51); for further description see Isik 194. a. Inscribed on the face; ll. 1 - 12 within the panel upheld by putti, and ll. 13-15 on the moulding below. b. inscribed on one side. Date: Perhaps second quarter of the third century (lettering, spelling, nomenclature, monument). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1975 & 1989 (Walls 132). (a) published by Isik and Reynolds, no. 194; (b) unpublished.

entry.title: Posthumous honours for Epicharmos son of Chrysaor
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus (no further description). Presumably inscribed on one face. Date: First century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by Gaudin (65); not reported subsequently. Published from Gaudin's squeeze by Reinach, 51, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 475.

entry.title: Funerary inscription, partly in verse, for Aurelius Zenon
entry.summary: A fragment, which was later overcut with a carefully cut cross. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Recorded by Gaudin (60); not reported subsequently. Published by Reinach from Gaudin, REG 19, 1906, 267-269, no. 163, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 464 ; discussed by Robert, AC 35, 1966, 385 and 390 note 1 (ll. 0-1).

entry.title: Building inscription fragment, undated.
entry.summary: Fragment of white marble entablature, with moulding surviving above (0.23 × 0.26 x 0.36). Inscribed on the face within the moulding. Date: Imperial (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1979 (Museum 50). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Hermolaos
entry.summary: On the box of a white marble garland sarcophagus, within the central garland, on a surface which is in very poor condition; for further description see Isik 10. Inscribed on the face. Date: Probably second half of the second century (lettering, nomenclature). Recorded by Isik; read from the photograph by Reynolds. Reynolds and Isik, 10.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Aurelius Attalos Bonbei
entry.summary: On the box of a white marble garland sarcophagus; for description see Isik 112. Inscribed on the upper moulding of the tabella, within it, and on its two lower mouldings, with some initial letters and some concluding ones impinging onto the side mouldings. The text must have begun on the lid, and ended on the lower moulding of the chest. Date: Perhaps middle third century (lettering, nomenclature). Recorded by Robert; by Isik. Recorded at Hirka and published L. Robert, La Carie II (Paris, 1954), 113, no 19, whence PHI Tabae 19; Reynolds & Isik 112.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Aimilia Meltine wife of Alexandros
entry.summary: Large sarcophagus lid (1.05 × 0.62 × 0.65). l. 1 inscribed along the rim of the lid; l. 2 on the surviving projection. Date: .I-IV (lettering). Photo. Recorded by A. Salač in 1925; not reported subsequently. Published by A. Salač, BCH 51, 1927, p. 396, no. 22, whence SEG 4.400, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 414.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Gladiator memorial
entry.summary: A white marble panel-stele, broken away above (0.55 x 0.595 x 0.21), with a simple moulding. On the central panel the relief figure of a gladiator advancing to his left survives up to the shoulders. He has a long shield on his left arm and a short sword (broken away) in his right hand; he seems to be wearing leg-guards. No text. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (content). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1968. Published by Roueché, PPA 22.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription of Peritas, on base or altar;
entry.summary: A white marble base or altar (0.64 x 0.64, 0.54) with moulding above and below. Inscribed on three sides. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (nomenclature). Photo. Copied by Paton; not recorded subsequently. Paton, JHS 20, 1900, 78, no. 7, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 521.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Adrastos and Rhodine
entry.summary: A small altar (height 0.32 W. 0.17). Inscribed on the face. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (terminology). Photo. Recorded by Paton; not reported subsequently. Published by Patton, JHS 20, 1900, 79, no. 8, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 405.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Gladiator memorial for Euplous
entry.summary: White marble panel-stele (0.895, W. 0.50, D. 0.24). The relief is of a gladiator advancing to his left. He wears body armour, which stretches down to his wrists, leg-guards, and a helmet with a crest; in his left arm he has a long shield, and in his right hand a short sword. Inscribed on upper moulding. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. recorded by the NYU expedition in 1968. Published by Roueché, PPA 20.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Gladiator memorial of Eupithanos
entry.summary: A white marble panel-stele (0.88 x 0.64 x 0.21). The relief is of a nude facing gladiator, who still wears arm-protectors on his right upper arm, and shin-guards. He holds a palm with his right arm, which is partly lost; his left arm is stretched out horizontally, and the hand rests on a helmet placed on what is either a smooth column or a tall shield. Below are two small figures: that on the man's right has shin-guards and a long shield, and looks up at him; that on his left is winged and naked, and holds his right arm down, and left arm raised, while regarding the central figure. Inscribed on upper (l.1) and lower (l.2) mouldings. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. recorded by the NYU expedition in 1968. Published by Roueché, PPA 21.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Gladiator memorial for Kalandion
entry.summary: White marble panel-stele, broken below (0.705 x 0.575 x 0.17). The relief is of a gladiator (a retiarius) with very light armour, and bare legs, carrying a short sword in his right hand and advancing right; behind him lies a long implement, perhaps a trident. Inscribed on upper moulding. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1983. Published by Roueché, PPA 23.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary formula for Valeria Claudia Aurelia Kaste
entry.summary: A sarcophagus lid (2.06, 0.85). Inscribed along the rim; the text is interrupted by supports. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (nomenclature). Seen by K&R in 1893; not reported subsequently. Published from Kubitschek's notebook (iii.3) by Cormack, no. 3, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 515 .

entry.title: Honours for the people of Aphrodisias
entry.summary: White marble statue base shaft (0.53 x 1.13 x 0.53) broken above and chipped at all edges, especially badly on the lower half of the right side. Inscribed on the exposed face, which is badly eroded in the lower part. Date: Late second or third century (lettering). Photos. Recorded by Paton; by the NYU expedition in 1976. Published by Paton, JHS 20, 1900, 77-78, no. 6, whence Robert, RPh 4, 1930, 27 (= OMS II.127), AntClass 1966, 410; republished byReynolds, A&R 43 whence SEG 1982.1097, BE 1983.390, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 214.

entry.title: Honours for Tiberius Claudius Capitolinus
entry.summary: Plain white marble statue base (0.52 × 1.36 × 0.51) which has had the back hollowed out for reuse as the basin for a fountain. There is a grafitto on the upper right side. Inscribed on one face. Date: Third century A.D. Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Museum 70, SBI 16). Unpublished.

entry.title: Epitaph of bishop of Stratonicaea
entry.summary: A marble masonry block, broken above and to right (0.32 × 0.69 × 0.09). Inscribed on the face; an iron clamp obscures part of the text. Date: Seventh century or later (lettering). Copied by Kubitschek (K.III.2, Abklatsch 97); not reported subsequently. Published from Kubitschek by Cormack (1964), no. 2, and p. 18, whence Robert (1966), 381 n. 4, Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity 167; not in PHI.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for son of Chrestos
entry.summary: Sarcophagus. Inscribed in the tabella, which is very worn. Date: Second half of the third century A.D. (lettering). Recorded by Isik; not seen by Reynolds. Reynolds and Isik 184.

entry.title: Funerary verse for Stephanos
entry.summary: A white marble plaque (0.295 × 0.53 × 0.04), with the back left rough; chipped at upper and lower edges. Inscribed on the face; the initial Σ of Στέφανος was cut above the line. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries A.D. (lettering, metre). Photo. Found by the NYU expedition during survey work in 1979/80. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 155 and plate xxxviii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 737, Steinepigramme 02/09/31.

Published by Anthopoulos Homeros 3 (1875) 80, no.4, whence Cormack, ABSA 59 (1964) 29 no. 46 on which L. Robert, Ant. Class. (1966) 389-91, BE 1967.547, and McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 563 .

entry.title: Honours for ? T. Cl. Aur. Zelos
entry.summary: Perhaps a statue base shaft (0.48 × 1.16 × 0.10 (given by Anthopoulos)). Inscribed face 0.40. If the block was complete, the text will have begun on a crowning feature. Date: Probably soon after 212 A.D. (nomenclature, if the name is correctly restored). Recorded by Deering (page 3, unnumbered); by Waddington; by K. G. Anthopoulos in 1872. Not reported subsequently. Published, from Deering, by Leake 5; by Waddington, LBW 1598bis, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 260 ; by K. G. Anthopoulos, Homeros III (1875) 80, on which see L. Robert, Hellenica XIII, 114.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Tatia
entry.summary: White marble sarcophagus 2.08 × 0.70 × 0.74 with a central panel supported by putti. On either side, garlands, with busts above. Inscribed below each bust (i, ii) and on the panel (iii); the text of iii must have begun on the lid. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the MAMA expedition; by the NYU expedition. : Published by Cormack, from the MAMA records, MAMA 8, no. 594, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 556.

entry.title: Funerary inscription of Aurelia Dionysia
entry.summary: Three joining fragments of a white marble sarcophagus front, which was fluted, with a central tabella ansata, flanked on either side by a smoother area with curving outlines. i, which is cut on the simple flat moulding along the top of the tabella, must have begun on an upper feature, and must represent all that remains of a previous inscription, erased from the tabella. ii is cut on the tabella and beyond it on the right. Date: i: Second/third century (lettering); ii: Third/fourth century (formulae, penalty). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition; main pieces before 1980, the third fragment in 1989 (Museum 101). Two fragments published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 148 a and b whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 575, 436.

entry.title: Votive to Hekate Euantetos
entry.summary: A rectangular white marble altar (stained), with simple moulding above and below, worked on all four sides, with a relief of a triple Hekate on the front face (0.14 × 0.28 × 0.20) . Inscribed on the right side. Date: Perhaps first to second century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Found at Aphrodisias in or before 1894, when it entered the collection of the Vienna Museum. Published by Rudolf Noll, Die griechischen und lateinischen Inschriften der Wiener Antikensammlung (Vienna 1962, republished 1986), no. 67, whence L. Robert, Hellenica 13, 285 and pl. 25, BE 1966.507, McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 164.

entry.title: Invocation
entry.summary: A white marble head, broken off from a lost statue, of a bearded male, probably of the first half of the fifth century. The text is cut on the top of the head, on the smooth area immediately behind the ridge of curly hair crowning the face, to be read from the front. Date: Fourth to fifth centuries A.D. (content, location). Photo. Excavated by Gaudin: on the provenance see K. T. Erim, 'De Aphrodisiade', AM 71 (1967), 236. Published by F. Cumont, Catalogue des sculptures et inscriptions antiques des Musées Royaux du Cinquentenaire (Brussels, 1913), 51, no. 41, whence Graindor, Marbres et textes, Rec. de trav. de la fac. de phil. de Gand, fasc. 50, 18-19; Grégoire, IGC 248bis; by K. T. Erim in lnan-Rosenbaum, Porträtplastik, 232, no. 204, whence SEG 1982.1108; SEG 1985.1082; Spätantike & Frühes Christentum, Ausst. Frankfurt (Frankfurt, 1984) 454-456, no. 62 with plate; Goette, MDAIRA 92 (1985), 318, no. IV.3. Text published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 145 and Plate xxxiii whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 655. Text and statue discussed most recently by Smith (2002).

Date: Perhaps 4th-5th century (lettering). Photo. Recorded by Wilhem (notebook iv.66) in Smyrna, in 1891; not reported subsequently. Published from Wilhelm's copy by Cormack, ABSA 59 (1964), no. 38, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 963 .

entry.summary: White marble stele/votive relief tapering towards the top (0.225–0.19 × 0.35 × 0.075). Inscribed on one face above a relief of a pair of sandals. Recorded by the NYU expedition before 1966 (Museum 108). Unpublished.

entry.title: Relief panel illustrating munera
entry.summary: A white marble relief panel, with a simple moulding at the edge, which survives above, below, and to the right. On the face, in relief, two heavily armed and helmeted gladiators confront one another. The figure on the left has a long shield on his left arm, and is extending his right arm, with a short sword, threatening his opponent; the other has a casque over his face, and something hanging down to the ground from his left hand. His right arm is extended to grip the shoulder of his opponent. No text. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (content). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, PPA 38.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Relief panel illustrating munera
entry.summary: Two fragments from a white marble relief panel (0.10 ) decorated with crude relief sculpture within a series of rectangular areas enclosed within a simple flat moulding. These two both come from the upper edge of the stone; traces survive below of a second register of decoration.a. ( 0.49 x 0.50) has a border surviving above and below, but both sides are lost. In the upper tier are running animals ?an ox pursued by a dog or wolf. Below, a man with a spear fights off a bear; to his left, a humped animal (probably another bear) springs away, and below it a creature bends its head to the ground.b. (0.48 x 0.56) has border surviving above, below and to the right. In the top right corner an ox flees. Below it, to the left a man (largely lost) confronts ?a bear, which is ?pursued by two running dogs. Below, in the lower right corner a ?boar is seated, facing two reclining creatures. That to the left is lost; in the centre a creature whose head is elongated, like that of a bear holds in an uplifted hand a rope which appears to be fastened to its neck, and to that of the creature behind. No text. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (content). Photos. recorded by the NYU expedition (museum inventory no. 82/2/1183). Published by Roueché, PPA 40.

entry.title: Relief panel illustrating munera
entry.summary: Fragment of white marble relief panel (0.35 x 0.34 x 0.22) with bottom edge surviving. To the right, a man (broken away from shoulders upwards) is kneeling, supported by his left hand; he is naked except for a loin-guard, and perhaps a strap on his upper chest. With his right hand he is pulling at the harness worn by a creature - - either a bear or a very heavy dog - - which is biting his right thigh. No text. Date: First to third centuries A.D. (content). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1963 (63.234). Published by Roueché, PPA 41.

entry.title: Funerary inscription for Adrastos Polychronios
entry.summary: A white marble sarcophagus, with two busts above the inscribed panel, now in fragments. Inscribed on the front face, within a simple moulding; lines 10-11 are on the lower moulding. Date: First to fourth centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded in 1705 by Picenini (10102.21), whence Sherard (10101, 33); by Wood in 1750 (lines 1-9; vol. 15, 45); by Fellows, no. 41; perhaps by Bailie. K& R found 2 fragments, A. Wilhelm saw a fragment in Smyrna. At least 15 fragments found again by the NYU expedition, including 70.238, 70.312, 70.338, 71.98, 71.102, 71.103; 72.257 (several fragments). Published by Boeckh, from Sherard, CIG 2824; by Fellows, no 41, whence CIG p.1115; by Cormack, Notes 15 and fig. 8; from these McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 407.

entry.title: Gladiator memorial
entry.summary: A white marble altar-stele (0.79 x 0.43 x 0.41) with moulding above and below on three sides; the upper moulding, which may have been inscribed, is worn away. On the face a gladiator, of the Thracian type, advancing to his left. He wears a helmet, and has a round shield on his left arm and a ?sword in his right hand. He is dressed in a belted tunic, and has ?boots. No text. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (content). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition. published by Roueché, PPA 33.

entry.title: Gladiator memorial for Narkissos
entry.summary: A white marble altar-stele with very simple moulding above and below on three sides (0.83 x 0.42 x 0.395). The upper right corner is broken, and the entire face has been pitted to take plaster. On the face the very damaged relief of a gladiator, facing right. Inscribed on the upper moulding (ll.1-2) and on the face (l.3) above the relief. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Stray find by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, PPA 18.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Gladiator memorial for Pheropes
entry.summary: The right side and lower edge of a white marble panel-stele without raised moulding (0.44 x 0.325 x 0.165). The relief shows the lower part, from the chest downwards, of a gladiator (a retiarius) wearing body armour, with bare legs, advancing to his left; he holds a short sword in his right hand and the staff of a trident (whose head is lost) in his left. Inscribed on the lower edge. Date: Second to third centuries A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1968 (excavation inventory no. 68.721). Published by Roueché, PPA 24.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.

entry.title: Second decree of the synod of athletes in honour of Kallikrates
entry.summary: Fragment (0.22 x 0.36 x 0.18) broken on all sides, from a block, perhaps part of a composite monument which bore another copy of the same text as 12.719. Inscribed on the face; the text must have been c. 2.20 in length. Date: A.D. 117-138 (reign). Photo. . Recorded by the NYU expedition, inventory no. 70.217. Published from the NYU records, H. Wankel, I. Eph. Ia, no. 11. Published by Roueché, PPA 90.

entry.title: Funerary fragment for and wife
entry.summary: White marble fragmen, moulded above, with with upper and lower edges surviving (0.23 × 0.20 × 0.12). Inscribed on upper fascia of moulding (l.1) and on face below (ll.2-3). Date: Perhaps late second century A.D (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1979 (79.22). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Aurelia [Phron]tiniane
entry.summary: No description; ll. 9-10 indicate that this is a statue base. If the block was complete the text will have begun on a crowning feature. Date: Late second to third centuries A.D. (nomenclature). Photo. First found by Waddington; not reported subsequently. Published by Waddington, LBW 1610, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 441 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Letter of a curator, ?M. Ulpius Appuleius Eurykles, to the Aphrodisians
entry.summary: No description. No description. Date: Between 180 and 189, probably early 180s (prosopography). Photo. Copied by Deering (f.17, no number); not recorded subsequently. Published from Deering by Leake, no. 21, whence LBW 1620c, Liermann, Analecta 21, Laum, Stiftungen 101. Not found again, but republished from Leake's publication and Waddington's supplements and observation by Reynolds, A&R 59; published from these and from Deering's copy, Roueché, PPA 51.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Badly damaged right end of a white marble garland sarcophagus,showing part of a garland upheld at teh corner by a pillar and a kneeling putto, who probably upheld a central tabella to the left. For further description see Isik 95. Inscribed on the face to the left of the putto and below the tabella. The inscription probably began in the tabella. Date: Perhaps first half of the third century A.D. (lettering). Recorded by Isik. Reynolds and Isik 95, with photograph.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for anonymous
entry.summary: No description; apparently a rectangular statue base, broken above and along the left edge. Inscribed on the face. Date: Second-third centuries A.D. (terminology). Copied by Sherard in 1716 (10101, 130). Not reported subsequently. Published by Boeckh, from Sherard papers, CIG 2795, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 366 .

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for Aurelia Ammia Myrton
entry.summary: Apparently a statue base. Apparently inscribed on the face. Date: Second-third centuries A.D. (nomenclature). Recorded by Sherard in 1716 (10101, 130v); by Deering (p. 7, no. 29); Not reported subsequently. Published by Boeckh, from Sherard papers, CIG 2817, whence Laum 106; Discussed, L. Robert, Rev. de Phil. 1930, 25-6 (= OMS II, 1125-6) whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 435 ; cf. Ant. Class. (1966) 390, n.4, BE 1976.633 CHECK.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Epitaph of Bitos, also called Asterios, cursor of the phylae
entry.summary: A small stele (0.75 × 0.37 × 0.25) with only one prepared face, slightly recessed; above this a rough circle is the only trace of decoration. Inscribed on the prepared face (prepared area 0.39 × 0.255); the surface is very worn. Date: Third-fourth century (formulae, penalty). Photos. Found by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 150 and plate xxxvi, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 517; discussed, Feissel (1991), 375.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Fragment from the front of a white marble sarcophagus (0.34 × 0.56 × 0.14). Inscribed along the upper rim and within a moulded panel of which the upper left corner survives. Date: Third century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1986 (no inventory number). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Revetment fragments
entry.summary: Two fragments of white marble revetment, each with upper and lower edge surviving (i. 0.135 × 0.105 × 0.023; ii. 0.13 × 0.18 × 0.032). Inscribed on the face. Date: Third to fifth centuries A.D. (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1988 (88.j, numbered F.4 and F.8). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment of funerary formula, stray find, undated.
entry.summary: Fragment of lower moulding from a sarcophagus lid (0.25 × 0.12 × 0.18). Inscribed on two planes. Date: Third century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1970 (70.227). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment; stray, undated
entry.summary: Piece perhaps from a sarcophagus front with relief ornament (a human figure facing left) in a sunken panel (0.43 × 0.27 × 0.04). Inscribed along the upper border. Date: Third-fourth century A.D. (lettering). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1971 (71.38). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment with relief; stray, undated
entry.summary: Fragment, without edges, from a white marble sarcophagus (0.36 x 0.45) with traces of a garland above. Inscribed below, on either side of a relief showing a male head and body with left arm raised to one side. Date: Third century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Excavated by the NYU expedition in 1974 (74.237). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Marcus Carminius Jason and Statilia Diogenia
entry.summary: Part of the front of a white marble garlands sarcophagus 0.99 × 0.49 × 0.15; for description see Isik 175. Inscribed in the tabella (die 0.27 x 0.25) from which an earlier inscription has been erased; ll. 1-3 on the upper moulding, ll 4 ff. impinging on the side mouldings. Date: Perhaps first half of the third century (lettering, nomenclature). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Museum 107). Reynolds and Isik 175.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for [Marcus Aurelius] Sophronios, son of Artemidoros
entry.summary: Part of a white marble sarcophagus front from which the decorative relief and the face of the central tabella have been chiselled away (0.52 × 0.49 × 0.14). For further description see Isik 200. Inscribed along the upper edge (ll. 1, 2) and (l. 3) above the tabella, whose surface has been erased. Date: Perhaps third century A.D. (lettering, nomenclature, monument ). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Museum 8). Reynolds and Isik 200 with photograph.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Aurelius Neikois
entry.summary: Fragment from the upper part of a white marble sarcophagus front 0.90 × 0.335 × 0.16 with upper part of tabella ansata and a putto in relief to left. Inscribed (l.1) on upper edge (very worn) and within tabella (ll. 2 ff). Date: Third century A.D. (nomenclature, lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Museum 29). Unpublished.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Fragment from the upper part of the front of a garland sarcophagus (for measurements see Isik 198). Inscribed along the upper rim, possibly also on the central tabella. Date: Perhaps middle third century A.D. (lettering, decoration). Monument recorded by Isik. Published Reynolds and Isik 198, with photograph.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary fragment
entry.summary: Fragment (0.28 x 0.40 x 0.06) from a white marble garland sarcophagus, including the upper left corner of a centra moulded tabella. On the sarcophagus, within the tabella, from which it is probable that an earlier inscription has been erased. Date: The inscription seems to be secondary, and could postdate the production of the sarcophagus, which Isik dates as third century, by many years; there is insufficient evidence for dating it, but it could be as late as the fourth century A.D. Recorded by Isik. Read by Reynolds from the photograph. Reynolds, and Isik 197.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Epitaph of M. Aur. Leontius Auchenios and M. Aur. Papaios Polychronios
entry.summary: White marble garland sarcophagus. See Isik 176 for a full description. Inscribed on the tabella (0.195 × 0.345) from which a previous inscription has been erased. Line 1 on the upper moulding, lines 2 ff. inscribed within the panel; lines 3-6, 9-12 impinge on the right moulding. Very worn. Date: Late third/early fourth century (titles). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition (Museum 48). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 151, whence cited, but with the wrong text, at McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 454; by Reynolds, in F. Isik, Garland Sarcophagi, 176.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary text
entry.summary: On a white marble garland sarcophagus; for furthr description see Isik 120. Inscribed on the upper rim, on an erased surface. The photograph suggests the possibility of further letters cut on the tabella, also on an erased surface. Date: The inscription is certainly secondary, cut markedly later than the original production of the sarcophagus; perhaps fourth century, but there is no secure evidence. Recorded by F. Isik; not seen by Reynolds. Reynolds and Isik 120.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary verse for Claudia
entry.summary: A plain white marble masonry block without moulding (0.46 × 0.355 x 0.19). Face a broken at right side; b broken on left side and below. Inscribed on two opposite faces. Date: Fourth-sixth century (content, metre). Photos. Brought by village children to the NYU expedition in 1970 (70.210). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 153 a and b and plate xxxvi (a only), whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 734, 735 Steinepigramme 02/09/28.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Fragment of funerary verse
entry.summary: Fragment from a white marble plaque or a sarcophagus front, with back surviving, but no edges (0.09 × 0.13 × 0.08). Inscribed on the face. Date: Fourth-sixth century or later (lettering. metre). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1977 (77.151). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 161 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 741.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Epitaph of Zoetos
entry.summary: A rectangular white marble stele, with a simply moulded panel on the front face, supporting a rougly cut hemisphere—probably cut down to serve as a Moslem tombstone. 0.35 × 0.70 × 0.325. Inscribed within the panel (0.23 × 0.35) which is chipped to the right. Date: Fourth century or later (content). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1994. Published by Roueché (2004), 243.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Tomb of Chrestianos
entry.summary: A white marble garland sarcophagus; see Isik for full description. Inscribed along the central part of the upper rim, apparently with a vacat on either side. Date: The sarcophagus could well be markedly earlier than the letters, which are difficult to date, but perhaps of the fourth century A.D. (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Reynolds and Isik 80.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Anonymous, magnificentissimus, gives a gameboard
entry.summary: A white marble fragment (0.09 × 0.17 × 0.11) from the edge of a block with a recessed panel. A gameboard, type 3Rows.4, was inscribed within the panel; the text was inscribed on the upper moulding. Date: Fifth/sixth century (titulature). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1981. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 71, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 625; republished by Roueché, Gameboards, no. 20.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Dedication from a church (building inscription)
entry.summary: A fragment, broken on both sides and below (0.155 × 0.36 × 0.08), from the upper edge of a white marble balustrade panel which had open arcading below. Inscribed in one line along the upper rim. Date: Fifth/sixth century or later (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1979 (79.19). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 105, and plate xxviii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 711.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Invocation
entry.summary: A small clay pot (diam. 0.105 x 0.07). On the body. Date: Fifth century or later (content). Photos. Excavated by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 146 whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 874.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary verse for Makedonios
entry.summary: Left side, with upper and lower edges surviving, of a rectangular white marble panel (0.27 × 0.265 × 0.03). Inscribed on the face, which is polished, and has been prepared with a lightly-cut grid, within which the letters are cut, one letter in each square. Date: Fifth or sixth century (content, metre). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1985. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 158 and plate xxxvi whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 736.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Epitaph of Charito
entry.summary: A white marble panel, slightly chipped (0.33 × 031 x 0.05). Inscribed on the face, which is smooth. Date: Fifth-sixth century or later (dating). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity 170 and plate xxxviii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 746.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Epitaph of Ioannes and others
entry.summary: Left side of a white marble masonry block without moulding (0.28 × 0.18 × 0.20). The left, upper, and lower sides, and the back survive. Inscribed on the face (a) and on the underside (b) suggesting that the face perhaps lay upwards. Date: Fifth to sixth centuries or later (dating, lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1985 (85.103). Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias 171, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 748a.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Epitaph of Eutychia
entry.summary: White marble panel, broken below (0.44 × 0.21 × 0.03). Inscribed on the face. Date: Fifth/sixth century or later (content, lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1984. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias 172, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 747.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary inscription for Epiphanios, bull-rearer
entry.summary: A white marble panel (0.46 × 0.34 × 0.13) with worn edges; only the right side survives intact. A groove has been cut in the back. Cut on the face. Date: Probably fifth/sixth century (lettering). Photos. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1989. Published by Roueché, PPA 44; republished by Roueché (2004), 237.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Donor prayer from a church
entry.summary: White marble fragment (0.21 × 0.15 × 0.17) from the crowning feature of a balustrade; the top is smooth; one side has a moulded profile, the other is smooth, tapering inwards. The underside has been left rough. Resembles 1.12, 1.13, 1.14, 1.15, 1.16, 1.192, 5.122. Inscribed in one line on upper fascia of moulded profile. Date: Fifth/sixth century or later (lettering). Photo. Recorded by the NYU excavation in 1992 (92.47). Published by Roueché (2004), 239.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: The Carians honour Palmatos, in verse
entry.summary: No description. No description. Date: Late fifth/early sixth century (prosopography). An epigram either recorded, almost certainly at Aphrodisias, by a Byzantine copyist, or intended for inscription at Aphrodisias; not reported subsequently. Published in the Planudean Anthology (book 16 of the Palatine Anthology) 35, whence Robert, Hellenica 4, 14, Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 63, Steinepigramme 02/09/11.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary verse for Pytheas
entry.summary: No description. No description. Date: Late fifth century (prosopography). An epigram either recorded, almost certainly at Aphrodisias, by a Byzantine copyist, or intended for inscription at Aphrodisias; not reported subsequently. Published in the Anthologia Palatina 7.690, whence Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity p. 95, Steinepigramme 02/09/22; republished by Roueché (2004), 250.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Funerary verse for Euphemia
entry.summary: A plain white marble masonry block (0.235 × 0.40 × 0.56), on the face of which a tabella ansata has been incised. The face is fairly worn. The date, a, is written above the tabella and down the right side, which is worn; the main text, b, is written within the tabella, with each line of verse separated by an incised line. Date: A.D. 543 or A.D. 558 (indiction, emperor). Photo. Recorded by the NYU expedition in 1966. Published by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 157 and plate xxxvii, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 732, Steinepigramme 02/09/29.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Theophylaktos, imperial judge, witnesses a document
entry.summary: A funeral monument, with sculpture: 'This, tho' Christian, is cut on an 'ara sepulchrali', big basis, and with the basreliefs' (Sherard). No description. Date: Late sixth/early seventh century (titulature, prosopography). Copied in 1716 by Sherard (BM Add. 10101 f. 129v); not reported subsequently. Published from Sherard by Kirchhoff, CIG 8644, whence Ramsay, Cities & Bishoprics 556, no. 431, Grégoire, IGC 247, Cabrol, Dict. vol. 14, col. 796, no. 25; from Sherard by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity no. 91, whence McCabe PHI Aphrodisias 633.

entry.rights: Creative Commons licence Attribution 2.5 (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.5/). All reuse or distribution of this work must contain somewhere a link back to the URL http://insaph.kcl.ac.uk/.
entry.title: Honours for anonymus, son of Menandros, boy pankratiast
entry.summary: A block, statue base shaft, with moulded panels. No measurements. Inscribed within panel and on upper and lower mouldings (ll.1, 34-5). The opening lines must have been inscribed on a crowning feature. Date: c. 230-240 (contests). Photo. Copied by H. P. Borrell; perhaps copied by Bailie; not reported subsequently. Published by Boeckh, from Borrell, CIG 2811, whence Liermann, Analecta 26. Published, from Borrell's copy and possibly one of his own, by Bailie, no. 48. Referred to by Oikonomos, Arch. Delt. (1921/2), 293. Published by Roueché, PPA 85.
